<dd class="glossary">A portable or wearable device such as a buoyant ring or inflatable jacket designed to keep a person <a href="#afloat"><span title="See entry on this page at § afloat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">afloat</span></a> in the water.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lifeboat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">lifeboat</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Lifeboat_(shipboard)" title="Lifeboat (shipboard)">shipboard lifeboat</a>) A small boat kept on board a vessel and used to take crew and passengers to safety in the event of the ship being abandoned.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Lifeboat_(rescue)" title="Lifeboat (rescue)">rescue lifeboat</a>) A small boat usually launched from shore and used to rescue people from the water or from vessels in difficulty.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="liferaft" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Lifeboat_(shipboard)" title="Lifeboat (shipboard)">liferaft</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An inflatable, sometimes covered raft used in the event of a vessel being abandoned or in the evacuation of an aircraft after a water landing.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lift" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">lift</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A rope that supports a spar on a sailing vessel. Examples include the <a href="/wiki/Topping_lift" title="Topping lift">topping lift</a> on the boom of a fore and aft rigged sail, or the lifts on the yard of a square rigged sail, which can adjust the yard to the horizontal or cock-bill the yard to get it out of the way when unloading cargo or alongside another vessel. <sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMayne2000_24-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMayne2000-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;An enabling shift in the direction of the wind that allows a <a href="#close-hauled"><span title="See entry on this page at § close-hauled" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">close-hauled</span></a> sailing ship to <span title="See entry on this page at § point up" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#point_up" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">point up</a></span> from its current <a href="#course"><span title="See entry on this page at § course" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">course</span></a> to a more favorable one. This is the opposite of a <a href="#header"><span title="See entry on this page at § header" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">header</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="light_irons" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">light irons</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Iron bars mounted near the main <span title="See entry on this page at § shroud" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#shroud" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">shrouds</a></span> that support the navigation lights.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="light_screens" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">light screens</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Boards on which the navigation lights are hooked and which shield the direction that the red or green light shows.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lighter" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Lighter_(barge)" title="Lighter (barge)">lighter</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A flat-bottomed <a href="#barge"><span title="See entry on this page at § barge" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">barge</span></a> used to transfer goods and passengers to and from moored ships, traditionally unpowered and moved and steered using "sweeps" (long <span title="See entry on this page at § oar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#oar" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">oars</a></span>), with their motive power provided by water currents.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lightering" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Lightering" title="Lightering">lightering</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The process of transferring cargo from one vessel to another in order to reduce the <a href="#draft"><span title="See entry on this page at § draft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">draft</span></a> of the first vessel, typically done to allow a vessel to enter a <span title="See entry on this page at § port" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#port" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">port</a></span> with limited depth or to help free a <a href="#grounded"><span title="See entry on this page at § grounded" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">grounded</span></a> vessel.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lightvessel" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Lightvessel" title="Lightvessel">lightvessel</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>lightship</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A permanently anchored vessel performing the functions of a <a href="#lighthouse"><span title="See entry on this page at § lighthouse" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">lighthouse</span></a>, typically in a location where construction of the latter is impractical. These have largely been replaced by <a href="#buoy"><span title="See entry on this page at § buoy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">buoys</span></a> or, as construction techniques have improved, actual lighthouses.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="limber_hole" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">limber hole</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A channel cut in the underside of a <a href="#frame"><span title="See entry on this page at § frame" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">frame</span></a>, close to the <a href="/wiki/Keel" title="Keel">keel</a>, to allow <a href="#bilge"><span title="See entry on this page at § bilge" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">bilge</span></a> water to drain away to the pump well, rather than being trapped between each set of frames.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESteffy2013_22-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESteffy2013-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="limber_board" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">limber board</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A part of the ceiling alongside the <a href="#keelson"><span title="See entry on this page at § keelson" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">keelson</span></a>, easily removable for cleaning out the <a href="#limber_hole"><span title="See entry on this page at § limber hole" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">limber holes</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESteffy2013_22-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESteffy2013-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="line" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">line</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The correct nautical term for the majority of the <a href="#cordage"><span title="See entry on this page at § cordage" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">cordage</span></a> or "ropes" used on a vessel. An individual line will always have a more specific name (e.g. the <span title="See entry on this page at § mizzen" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#mizzen" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">mizzen</a></span> <span title="See entry on this page at § topsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#topsail" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">topsail</a></span> <a href="#halyard"><span title="See entry on this page at § halyard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">halyard</span></a>) that specifies its use.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="line_astern" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">line astern</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">In naval warfare, a <a href="#line_of_battle"><span title="See entry on this page at § line of battle" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">line of battle</span></a> formed behind a <a href="#flagship"><span title="See entry on this page at § flagship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">flagship</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="liner" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">liner</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;During the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Sail" title="Age of Sail">Age of Sail</a>, a <span title="See entry on this page at § ship-of-the-line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#ship-of-the-line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">ship-of-the-line</a></span>, or a major <span title="See entry on this page at § warship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#warship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">warship</a></span> capable of taking its place in the main <a href="#line_of_battle"><span title="See entry on this page at § line of battle" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">battle line</span></a> of fighting ships.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Any cargo or passenger ship running scheduled service along a specific route with published <span title="See entry on this page at § port of call" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#port_of_call" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">ports of call</a></span>, excluding <a href="/wiki/Ferryboat" class="mw-redirect" title="Ferryboat">ferries</a> and other vessels engaged in short-sea trading. When referring to <a href="#cargo_ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § cargo ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">cargo ships</span></a>, "liner" contrasts with "<span title="See entry on this page at § tramp" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#tramp" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">tramp</a></span>", which refers to a ship engaged in spot-market trade that does not follow a regular schedule or make regular calls at specific ports. When referring to passenger ships, "<span title="See entry on this page at § ocean liner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#ocean_liner" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">ocean liner</a></span>" refers to ships providing scheduled transportation between regular ports of call, but excludes <a href="#cruise_ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § cruise ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">cruise ships</span></a>, which voyage for recreational purposes and not primarily as a form of transportation between ports.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="list" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Angle_of_list" title="Angle of list">list</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The degree or angle to which a vessel leans or tilts to one side, on the <span title="See entry on this page at § roll" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#roll" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">roll</a></span> axos, at equilibrium, i.e. with no external forces acting upon it. The term typically refers to a lean caused by flooding or improperly loaded or shifted cargo, as opposed to <a href="#heeling"><span title="See entry on this page at § heeling" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">heeling</span></a>, which is a consequence of external forces. A vessel with such a lean is said to be <i>listing</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_3-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> Compare with <a href="#loll"><span title="See entry on this page at § loll" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">loll</span></a> </dd>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ivory_Tirupati_with_heavy_list_3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Ivory_Tirupati_with_heavy_list_3.jpg/220px-Ivory_Tirupati_with_heavy_list_3.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Ivory_Tirupati_with_heavy_list_3.jpg/330px-Ivory_Tirupati_with_heavy_list_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Ivory_Tirupati_with_heavy_list_3.jpg/440px-Ivory_Tirupati_with_heavy_list_3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="622" data-file-height="467" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ivory_Tirupati_with_heavy_list_3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A ship with severe <b><a href="#list"><span title="See entry on this page at § list" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">list</span></a></b></div></div></div>
<dt class="glossary" id="lizard" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">lizard</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A short length of <span title="See entry on this page at § rope" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#rope" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">rope</a></span> with an eye, used to hold another rope in position.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="loaded_to_the_gunwales" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">loaded to the gunwales</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Literally, having cargo loaded as high as the ship's rail. The term is also used as an idiom meaning "extremely drunk".</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lofting" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Lofting" title="Lofting">lofting</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">In boat construction, a drafting technique used to convert a scaled drawing to full size.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="loggerhead" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">loggerhead</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A bollard mounted in the <span title="See entry on this page at § sternsheets" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#sternsheets" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">sternsheets</a></span> of a <a href="/wiki/Whaleboat" title="Whaleboat">whaleboat</a> for snubbing the whale line as a harpooned whale swam away from the boat.<sup id="cite_ref-Ansel_78_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ansel_78-83">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 144">&#58;&#8202;144&#8202;</span></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;An iron ball attached to a long handle, used for driving caulking into seams and (occasionally) in a fight; hence the expression "at loggerheads".<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> </dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="loll" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">loll</dfn></dt>
<dt class="glossary" id="lolling" style="margin-top: -0.2em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Angle_of_loll" title="Angle of loll">lolling</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#list"><span title="See entry on this page at § list" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">list</span></a> to either side caused by inadequate transverse stability in the upright condition.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_3-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="long_forties" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Long_Forties" title="Long Forties">Long Forties</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An area of the northern <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a> which is fairly consistently 40 <a href="#fathom"><span title="See entry on this page at § fathom" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">fathoms</span></a> (240 feet; 73 metres) deep. On nautical charts with depths indicated in fathoms, it appears as a long area with many "40" notations.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="long_stay" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">long stay</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The relative slackness of an <a href="#anchor_chain"><span title="See entry on this page at § anchor chain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">anchor chain</span></a>; this term means taut and extended.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="longboat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Longboat" title="Longboat">longboat</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;In the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Sail" title="Age of Sail">Age of Sail</a>, a double-banked open boat carried by a sailing ship, rowed by eight or ten oarsmen, two per <span title="See entry on this page at § thwart" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#thwart" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">thwart</a></span>, although designed also to be rigged for sailing; more seaworthy than a <a href="#cutter"><span title="See entry on this page at § cutter" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">cutter</span></a> or <a href="#dinghy"><span title="See entry on this page at § dinghy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">dinghy</span></a> and with a <a href="#beam"><span title="See entry on this page at § beam" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">beam</span></a> greater than that of a <a href="#gig"><span title="See entry on this page at § gig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">gig</span></a>. Eventually supplanted by the <a href="/wiki/Whaleboat" title="Whaleboat">whaleboat</a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The largest, and thus the most capable, of boats carried on a ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="longliner" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">longliner</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A fishing vessel rigged for <a href="/wiki/Longline_fishing" title="Longline fishing">longline fishing</a> ("longlining").</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="longship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Longship" title="Longship">longship</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of ship invented and used by the Vikings for trade, commerce, exploration, and warfare, evolving over several centuries and appearing in its complete form between the 9th and 13th centuries.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lookout" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">lookout</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A member of the <a href="#crew"><span title="See entry on this page at § crew" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">crew</span></a> specifically assigned to watch surrounding waters for other vessels, land, objects in the water, hazards, threats, etc. Lookouts usually have duty stations high on a vessel's superstructure, in a specially designed <span title="See entry on this page at § top" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#top" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">top</a></span> or <a href="#crow&#39;s_nest"><span title="See entry on this page at § crow&#39;s nest" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">crow's nest</span></a>, or in her <span title="See entry on this page at § rigging" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#rigging" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">rigging</a></span>, in order to enhance their field of view.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="loose_cannon" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">loose cannon</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An irresponsible and reckless individual whose behavior (either intentionally or unintentionally) endangers the group he or she belongs to. The term refers to a hypothetical literal loose cannon which, weighing thousands of pounds, would crush anything and anyone in its path, and possibly even break a hole in the hull, thus endangering the seaworthiness of the whole ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="loose-footed" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">loose-footed</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A fore-and-aft<span title="See entry on this page at § mainsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#mainsail" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">mainsail</a></span> that is not connected to a <a href="#boom"><span title="See entry on this page at § boom" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">boom</span></a> along its foot.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lower_deck" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">lower deck</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The <a href="#deck"><span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">deck</span></a> of a ship immediately above the <a href="#hold"><span title="See entry on this page at § hold" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">hold</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;In British usage, those members of a <span title="See entry on this page at § ship&#39;s company" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#ship&#39;s_company" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">ship's company</a></span> who are not officers, often used in the plural (e.g. "the lower decks").</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lowers" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">lowers</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The lower <a href="#brail"><span title="See entry on this page at § brail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">brails</span></a> on the <span title="See entry on this page at § mainsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#mainsail" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">mainsail</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lubber&#39;s_hole" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">lubber's hole</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A port cut into the bottom of a <span title="See entry on this page at § masthead" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#masthead" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">masthead</a></span> or <span title="See entry on this page at § top" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#top" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">top</a></span> (<a href="#crow&#39;s-nest"><span title="See entry on this page at § crow&#39;s-nest" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">crow's-nest</span></a>) allowing easy entry and exit. It was considered "un-seamanlike" to use this method rather than going over the side from the <span title="See entry on this page at § shroud" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#shroud" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">shrouds</a></span>, and few sailors would risk the scorn of their shipmates by doing so (at least if there were witnesses). In practice, it is often actually quicker and easier for a fit sailor to climb outside the masthead than through the lubber's hole.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955111_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955111-84">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lubber&#39;s_line" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">lubber's line</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A line or mark inside or on a compass case or binnacle indicating the direction of the ship's head.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_3-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lucky_bag" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">lucky bag</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A locker or compartment for storage of unclaimed articles.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;<a href="/wiki/United_States_Naval_Academy" title="United States Naval Academy">U.S. Naval Academy</a> yearbook.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="luff" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Luff_(sail)" class="mw-redirect" title="Luff (sail)">luff</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The <a href="#forward"><span title="See entry on this page at § forward" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">forward</span></a> edge of a sail.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The process of pointing a sailing vessel closer to the wind.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;The fullest or roundest part of a ship's <a href="#bow"><span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">bow</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarr195160_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarr195160-86">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-smyth_58-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-smyth-58">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="luff_and_touch_her" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">luff and touch her</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To bring a vessel so close to the wind that the sails shake.<sup id="cite_ref-Naval_encyclopedia_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Naval_encyclopedia-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="luff_barge" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">luff barge</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>paddy boat</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">An 18th-century term for a sailing barge with a rounded <a href="#bow"><span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">bow</span></a> and not a <span title="See entry on this page at § swim-head" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#swim-head" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">swim-head</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarr195159_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarr195159-87">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="luff_perpendicular_(lp)" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">luff perpendicular (LP)</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The shortest distance between the <a href="#clew"><span title="See entry on this page at § clew" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">clew</span></a> and the <a href="#luff"><span title="See entry on this page at § luff" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">luff</span></a>, which is a perpendicular line from the luff to the clew. Commonly given as a percentage of the "J" measurement.<sup id="cite_ref-Uksailmakers_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Uksailmakers-88">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="luff_up" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">luff up</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To steer a sailing vessel more towards the direction of the wind until the pressure is eased on the <span title="See entry on this page at § sheet" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#sheet" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">sheet</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="luffing" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Luffing" title="Luffing">luffing</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;(of a sailing vessel) Being steered far enough to <span title="See entry on this page at § windward" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#windward" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">windward</a></span> that the sail is no longer completely filled with wind; in such a state, the <a href="#luff"><span title="See entry on this page at § luff" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">luff</span></a> of a <a href="#fore-and-aft_rig"><span title="See entry on this page at § fore-and-aft rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">fore-and-aft</span></a> sail begins to flap first.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Loosening a <span title="See entry on this page at § sheet" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#sheet" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">sheet</a></span> so far past optimal trim that the sail no longer completely fills with wind.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;The flapping of a sail from having no wind at all.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> </dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lumber_hooker" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Lumber_hooker" title="Lumber hooker">lumber hooker</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a> ship designed to simultaneously carry her own deck load of lumber and to tow one or two <a href="#barge"><span title="See entry on this page at § barge" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">barges</span></a>. The barges were big old <span title="See entry on this page at § schooner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#schooner" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">schooners</a></span> stripped of their <span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#mast" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">masts</a></span> and running gear to carry large cargoes of lumber.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lugger" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Lugger" title="Lugger">lugger</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A sailing vessel with <a href="#lug_sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § lug sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">lug sails</span></a> set on one, two, or more <span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#mast" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">masts</a></span> and perhaps lug <span title="See entry on this page at § topsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#topsail" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">topsails</a></span>, widely used as traditional fishing boats, particularly off the coasts of France, England, and Scotland; also used as privateers and smugglers.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lug_sail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Lug_sail" title="Lug sail">lug sail</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A four-sided <a href="#fore-and-aft_rig"><span title="See entry on this page at § fore-and-aft rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">fore-and-aft</span></a> <span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#sail" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">sail</a></span> supported by a <span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#spar" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">spar</a></span> along the top that is fixed to the <span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#mast" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">mast</a></span> at a point some distance from the center of the spar. A dipping lug had to be moved to the other side of the mast when <a href="/wiki/Tacking_(sailing)" title="Tacking (sailing)">tacking (sailing)</a> (in larger vessels, by partially lowering the sail and hauling down either the peak or the throat to move the <span title="See entry on this page at § yard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#yard" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">yard</a></span> across). A standing lug can be used on either tack in the same position. It was common for British fishing luggers to have a dipping lug on the <a href="#foremast"><span title="See entry on this page at § foremast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">foremast</span></a> and a standing lug on the <span title="See entry on this page at § mizzen" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#mizzen" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">mizzen</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarch1972&#39;&#39;passim&#39;&#39;_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarch1972&#39;&#39;passim&#39;&#39;-89">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lying_ahull" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Lying_ahull" title="Lying ahull">lying ahull</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Waiting out a storm by <a href="#dousing"><span title="See entry on this page at § dousing" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">dousing</span></a> all <span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)#sail" title="Glossary of nautical terms (M-Z)">sails</a></span> and simply letting the boat drift.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="lying_to" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">lying to</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#lie_to"><span title="See entry on this page at § lie to" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">lie to</span></a></i>.</dd>




<dt class="glossary" id="mack" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Mack_(naval_architecture)" title="Mack (naval architecture)">mack</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Combination <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> and <a href="#stack"><span title="See entry on this page at § stack" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stack</span></a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> </dd>
<dt class="glossary" id="mae_west" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Personal_flotation_device" title="Personal flotation device">Mae West</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A Second World War <a href="#personal_flotation_device"><span title="See entry on this page at § personal flotation device" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">personal flotation device</span></a> used to keep people afloat in the water; named after the 1930s actress <a href="/wiki/Mae_West" title="Mae West">Mae West</a>, well known for her large bosom.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="magnetic_north" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Magnetic_declination" title="Magnetic declination">magnetic north</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The direction towards the <a href="/wiki/North_Magnetic_Pole" class="mw-redirect" title="North Magnetic Pole">North Magnetic Pole</a>. Varies slowly over time.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="maiden_voyage" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">maiden voyage</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="maiden_voyage"></span>
<dd class="glossary">The first voyage of a ship in its intended role, ie excluding <a href="#trial_trip"><span title="See entry on this page at § trial trip" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">trial trip</span></a>s.</dd>
<dt class="glossary" id="magnetic_bearing" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Magnetic_bearing" title="Magnetic bearing">magnetic bearing</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An <span title="See entry on this page at § absolute bearing" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#absolute_bearing" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">absolute bearing</a></span> using <a href="#magnetic_north"><span title="See entry on this page at § magnetic north" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">magnetic north</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="main" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">main</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The high sea; the open ocean.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="main_deck" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Main_deck" title="Main deck">main deck</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The uppermost continuous <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> extending from <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> to <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mainbrace" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mainbrace</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Either of the <span title="See entry on this page at § braces" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#braces" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">braces</a></span> attached to the <a href="#yard"><span title="See entry on this page at § yard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yard</span></a> of the <a href="#mainsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainsail</span></a> (the largest and lowest sail on the <a href="#mainmast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainmast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainmast</span></a>) on a <a href="#square_rig"><span title="See entry on this page at § square rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square-rigged</span></a> vessel.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mainmast" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Mast_(sailing)" title="Mast (sailing)">mainmast</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="main"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>main</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The tallest <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> on a ship.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955111_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955111-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mains" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mains</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The main <span title="See entry on this page at § brail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#brail" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">brails</a></span> on the <a href="#mainsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainsail</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mainsheet" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sheet_(sailing)" title="Sheet (sailing)">mainsheet</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A sail control <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">line</a></span> that allows the most obvious effect on <a href="#mainsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainsail</span></a> trim. Primarily used to control the angle of the <span title="See entry on this page at § boom" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#boom" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">boom</a></span>, and thereby the mainsail, this control can also increase or decrease downward tension on the boom while sailing upwind, significantly affecting sail shape. For more control over downward tension on the boom, a <span title="See entry on this page at § boom vang" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#boom_vang" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">boom vang</a></span> may be used.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mainstay" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mainstay</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The <a href="#stay"><span title="See entry on this page at § stay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stay</span></a> running from the top of the <a href="#mainmast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainmast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainmast</span></a> to the bottom of the <span title="See entry on this page at § foremast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#foremast" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">foremast</a></span>, or from the top of the foremast to the ship's <a href="#stem"><span title="See entry on this page at § stem" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stem</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="making_way" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">making way</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">When a vessel is moving under its own power.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="man-of-war" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Man-of-war" title="Man-of-war">man-of-war</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="man_o&#39;_war"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>man o' war</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="/wiki/Warship" title="Warship">warship</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Sail" title="Age of Sail">Age of Sail</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="man_overboard" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Man_overboard" title="Man overboard">man overboard</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;An emergency call that alerts the crew that someone <span title="See entry on this page at § aboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aboard" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aboard</a></span> has gone <a href="#overboard"><span title="See entry on this page at § overboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">overboard</span></a> and must be rescued.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A person who has fallen into the water from a ship or boat – the object of the resulting rescue attempt.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="man_the_rails" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Manning_the_rails" class="mw-redirect" title="Manning the rails">man the rails</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To station the crew of a naval vessel along the rails and superstructure of the vessel as a method of saluting or rendering honors.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="man_the_yards" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Man_the_yards" class="mw-redirect" title="Man the yards">man the yards</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To have all of the <span title="See entry on this page at § crew" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#crew" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">crew</a></span> of a sailing vessel not required on <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> to handle the ship go aloft and spread out along the <a href="#yard"><span title="See entry on this page at § yard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yards</span></a>. Originally used in harbors to display the whole crew to harbor authorities and other ships present to show that the vessel<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s guns were not manned and hence her intentions were peaceful, <i>manning the yards</i> has since become a display used in harbor during celebrations and other special events.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="manifest" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Manifest_(transportation)" title="Manifest (transportation)">manifest</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A document listing the cargo, passengers, and crew of a ship for the use of customs and other officials.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="marconi_rig" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">Marconi rig</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An archaic term for <a href="/wiki/Bermuda_rig" title="Bermuda rig">Bermuda rig</a>. The <a href="#mainsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainsail</span></a> is triangular, rigged <span title="See entry on this page at § fore-and-aft rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#fore-and-aft_rig" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">fore-and-aft</a></span> with its <span title="See entry on this page at § luff" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#luff" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">luff</a></span> fixed to the <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a>. The <span title="See entry on this page at § foresail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#foresail" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">foresail</a></span> (<span title="See entry on this page at § jib" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#jib" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">jib</a></span>) is a <a href="#staysail"><span title="See entry on this page at § staysail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">staysail</span></a> hanked onto the <span title="See entry on this page at § forestay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#forestay" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">forestay</a></span>. Refers to the similarity of the tall mast to a radio aerial.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="marina" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Marina" title="Marina">marina</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A docking facility for small ships and yachts.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="marine" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Marine_(military)" class="mw-redirect" title="Marine (military)">marine</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A soldier trained for service afloat in a (primarily) infantry force that specializes in naval campaigns and subordinated to a navy or a separate naval branch of service rather than to an army. Often capitalized (e.g. a <i>Marine</i> or the <i>Marines</i>). Notable examples are the United Kingdom's <a href="/wiki/Royal_Marines" title="Royal Marines">Royal Marines</a>, formed as the Duke of York and Albany's Maritime Regiment of Foot in 1664 with many and varied duties including providing guard to ship's officers should there be a <a href="/wiki/Mutiny" title="Mutiny">mutiny</a> aboard, and the <a href="/wiki/US_Marine_Corps" class="mw-redirect" title="US Marine Corps">US Marine Corps</a>, formed in 1775 as a separate naval service alongside the US Navy. It is incorrect, and often viewed by marines as offensive, to refer to a marine as a "soldier" or "infantryman", as these terms refer to personnel of an army rather than those of a marine force. It also is incorrect, and sometimes considered offensive by both merchant mariners and marines, to refer to <a href="#merchant_mariner"><span title="See entry on this page at § merchant mariner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">merchant mariners</span></a> as "merchant marines", because merchant mariners are civilian sailors responsible for operating <a href="/wiki/Merchant_ship" title="Merchant ship">merchant ships</a> and are not marines. Marines sometimes are thought by seamen to be rather gullible, hence the phrase "tell it to the marines", meaning that one does not believe what is being said.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;An alternative term for a <a href="#navy"><span title="See entry on this page at § navy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">navy</span></a>, uncommon in English but common in other languages.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;Of or pertaining to the sea (e.g. marine biology, marine insurance, marine salvage).</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;A painting representing a subject related to the sea.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="marine_sandglass_(or_glass)" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Marine_sandglass" title="Marine sandglass">marine sandglass</a> (or glass)</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An <a href="/wiki/Hourglass" title="Hourglass">hourglass</a>-like timekeeping instrument used aboard ships from at least the 14th century until reliable mechanical timepieces replaced it in the early 19th century. Marine sandglasses measured the passage of time in 30-minute increments to regulate time on watch, to measure a boat's speed, and to assist in determining a ship's position by measuring the time elapsed while she was on a given course.  </dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mariner" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mariner</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#sailor"><span title="See entry on this page at § sailor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sailor</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="maritime" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">maritime</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Of or related to the sea (e.g., maritime <i>activities</i>, maritime <i>law</i>, maritime <i>strategy</i>).</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Bordering on the sea (e.g., maritime <i>provinces</i>, maritime <i>states</i>).</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;Living in or near the sea (e.g., maritime <i>animals</i>).</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;Of or relating to a mariner or sailor.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="marlinspike" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Marlinspike" title="Marlinspike">marlinspike</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A tool used in <a href="/wiki/Ropework" title="Ropework">ropework</a> for tasks such as unlaying rope for splicing, untying knots, or forming a makeshift handle.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mast" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Mast_(sailing)" title="Mast (sailing)">mast</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vertical pole on a ship that supports <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sails</span></a> or <a href="#rigging"><span title="See entry on this page at § rigging" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rigging</span></a>. If a wooden multi-part mast, this term applies specifically to the lowest portion.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mast_case" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mast case</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A yachtsman's tabernacle. The iron fitting in which the heel of the <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> is mounted.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mast_step" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mast step</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The place in the hull where the lowest point of a mast rests, taking the weight of the mast and the thrust imposed by the tension of the rigging, and preventing lateral and fore and aft movement of the bottom of the mast. With a wooden hull and mast, this is usually achieved by having a socket cut in the top of the <span title="See entry on this page at § keelson" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#keelson" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">keelson</a></span>, a <span title="See entry on this page at § floor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#floor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">floor</a></span> or some other major structural component. A tenon cut into the bottom of the mast sits snugly in the socket.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESteffy2013_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESteffy2013-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> With a deck-stepped aluminium mast, the step may consist of a metal fitting bolted to the deck, to which bolts a matching fitting at the bottom of the mast.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mast_stepping" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mast stepping</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The process of raising a <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="masthead" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">masthead</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A small platform partway up the mast, just above the height of the mast's main <a href="#yard"><span title="See entry on this page at § yard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yard</span></a>. A <span title="See entry on this page at § lookout" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lookout" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lookout</a></span> is stationed here, and men who are working on the main yard will embark from here. See also <i><span title="See entry on this page at § crow&#39;s nest" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#crow&#39;s_nest" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">crow's nest</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="master" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">master</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The <span title="See entry on this page at § captain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#captain" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">captain</a></span> of a commercial vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A senior officer of a naval sailing ship in charge of routine seamanship and navigation but not in command during combat.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Master_(naval)" title="Master (naval)">master</a>) A former naval rank.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="master-at-arms" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Master-at-arms" title="Master-at-arms">master-at-arms</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="/wiki/Non-commissioned_officer" title="Non-commissioned officer">non-commissioned officer</a> responsible for discipline on a naval ship. Standing between the officers and the crew, commonly known in the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> as "the Buffer".<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="matelot" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">matelot</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A traditional Royal Navy term for an ordinary <a href="#sailor"><span title="See entry on this page at § sailor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sailor</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="material" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">material</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Military equipages of all descriptions for the naval services. The bombs, blankets, beans, and bulletins of the Navy and Marine Corps. Taken from Nelson's British navy as the US services became professional. See also <a href="/wiki/Materiel" title="Materiel">materiel</a> – military supplies, equipment and weapons.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mediterranean_mooring" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Mooring#Mediterranean_mooring" title="Mooring">Mediterranean mooring</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>Med moor</b> and <b>Tahitian mooring</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A method of mooring stern-to.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="merchant_marine" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Merchant_marine" class="mw-redirect" title="Merchant marine">merchant marine</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A collective term for all merchant ships registered in a given country and the civilians (especially those of that nationality) who man them; the ships and personnel in combination are said to constitute that country's <i>merchant marine</i>. Called the <a href="#merchant_navy"><span title="See entry on this page at § merchant navy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">merchant navy</span></a> in the United Kingdom and some other countries.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="merchant_mariner" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">merchant mariner</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A civilian officer or sailor who serves in the <a href="/wiki/Merchant_marine" class="mw-redirect" title="Merchant marine">merchant marine</a>. Sometimes such personnel are incorrectly called "merchant marines", but both merchant mariners and <a href="#marine"><span title="See entry on this page at § marine" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">marines</span></a> frown on this term; although merchant mariners are part of the merchant marine, they are civilians and are not in any way marines, which are a specialized type of military personnel.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="merchant_navy" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Merchant_navy" title="Merchant navy">merchant navy</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A name bestowed upon the <a href="/wiki/Merchant_marine" class="mw-redirect" title="Merchant marine">merchant marine</a> of the United Kingdom by King <a href="/wiki/George_V" title="George V">George V</a>, and since adopted by some other countries as well. The merchant navy's personnel are civilians, and the term "merchant navy" does not imply that they or their ships are a part of the navy. Synonymous with the term <i>merchant marine</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="merchantman" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">merchantman</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="/wiki/Merchant_ship" title="Merchant ship">merchant ship</a> - any non-naval passenger- or cargo-carrying vessel, including <span title="See entry on this page at § cargo ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cargo_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cargo ships</a></span>, <a href="#tanker"><span title="See entry on this page at § tanker" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tankers</span></a>, and <a href="/wiki/Passenger_ship" title="Passenger ship">passenger ships</a> but excluding <a href="/wiki/Troopship" title="Troopship">troopships</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mess" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Mess" title="Mess">mess</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>messdeck</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;An eating place aboard a ship.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A group of <span title="See entry on this page at § crew" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#crew" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">crew</a></span> who live and eat together.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mess_deck_catering" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mess deck catering</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A system of catering in which a standard ration is issued to a <a href="#mess"><span title="See entry on this page at § mess" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mess</span></a> supplemented by a money allowance, which the mess may use to buy additional victuals from the <a href="#ship&#39;s_pusser"><span title="See entry on this page at § ship&#39;s pusser" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">pusser</span></a>'s stores or elsewhere. Each mess was autonomous and self-regulating. Seaman cooks, often members of the mess, prepared the meals and took them, in a tin canteen, to the <span title="See entry on this page at § galley" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#galley" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">galley</a></span> to be cooked by the ship's cooks. As distinct from "<a href="/wiki/Cafeteria" title="Cafeteria">cafeteria</a> messing" where food is issued to an individual hand, which is now the general practice.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="metacenter" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Metacenter" class="mw-redirect" title="Metacenter">metacenter</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The midway point between a vessel<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s <span title="See entry on this page at § center of buoyancy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#center_of_buoyancy" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">center of buoyancy</a></span> when upright and her center of buoyancy when tilted.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="metacentric_height_(gm)" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Metacentric_height" title="Metacentric height">metacentric height</a> (GM)</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="GM"></span>
<dd class="glossary">A measurement of the initial static stability of a vessel afloat, calculated as the distance between her <a href="/wiki/Center_of_gravity" class="mw-redirect" title="Center of gravity">center of gravity</a> and her <a href="/wiki/Metacenter" class="mw-redirect" title="Metacenter">metacenter</a>. A vessel with a large metacentric height <a href="#roll"><span title="See entry on this page at § roll" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rolls</span></a> more quickly and therefore more uncomfortably for people on board; a vessel with a small metacentric height will roll sluggishly and may face a greater danger of <span title="See entry on this page at § capsize" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#capsize" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">capsizing</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="middle_passage" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Middle_Passage" title="Middle Passage">Middle Passage</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The portion of the <a href="/wiki/Triangular_trade" title="Triangular trade">triangular trade</a> pattern of the late 16th through the early 19th centuries in the Atlantic Ocean in which slaves were transported from Africa to the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>. In the terminology of the <a href="/wiki/Slave_trade" class="mw-redirect" title="Slave trade">slave trade</a> itself, the <i>Middle Passage</i> linked the <i>First Passage</i> (the transportation of captives from the interior of Africa to African ports for sale as slaves) with the <i>Final Passage</i> (the transportation of slaves from their port of disembarkation in the Americas to the location where they were to work).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="middles" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">middles</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The middle <span title="See entry on this page at § brail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#brail" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">brails</a></span> on the <a href="#mainsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainsail</span></a>, higher than the lowers, and lower than the mains.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="midship_house" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">midship house</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#superstructure"><span title="See entry on this page at § superstructure" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">superstructure</span></a> built over the <a href="#midships"><span title="See entry on this page at § midships" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">midships</span></a> section of the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span>, often housing the <span title="See entry on this page at § bridge" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bridge" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bridge</a></span> and officers quarters, as well as passenger quarters aboard <span title="See entry on this page at § cargo liner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cargo_liner" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cargo liner</a></span>s. A common feature of <a href="#tanker"><span title="See entry on this page at § tanker" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tanker</span></a>s, <span title="See entry on this page at § cargo liner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cargo_liner" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cargo liner</a></span>s, and <span title="See entry on this page at § cargo ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cargo_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cargo ship</a></span>s up until the mid-20th century, when ship design moved away from the use of midship houses.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="midshipman" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Midshipman" title="Midshipman">midshipman</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;During the 17th century, a naval rating for an experienced seaman.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;From the 18th century, a naval commissioned officer candidate.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;From the 1790s, an apprentice naval officer.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;From the 19th century, an officer cadet at a naval academy.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">5.&#160;&#160;In contemporary British usage, a <a href="/wiki/Non-commissioned_officer" title="Non-commissioned officer">non-commissioned officer</a> below the rank of <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant" title="Lieutenant">lieutenant</a>. Usually regarded as being "in training" to some degree. Also known as "Snotty". It is "the lowest form of rank in the Royal Navy" where he has authority over and responsibility for more junior ranks, yet, at the same time, relying on their experience and learning his trade from them.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">6.&#160;&#160;In contemporary American usage, a cadet of either sex at the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Merchant_Marine_Academy" title="United States Merchant Marine Academy">United States Merchant Marine Academy</a> or the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Naval_Academy" title="United States Naval Academy">United States Naval Academy</a>. When plural (<i>midshipmen</i>), the term refers to the student body of either academy, and more formally as "the Regiment of Midshipmen" for the Merchant Marine Academy and "the Brigade of Midshipmen" for the Naval Academy.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="midshipman&#39;s_hitch" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">midshipman's hitch</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An alternative to the <a href="/wiki/Blackwall_hitch" title="Blackwall hitch">Blackwall hitch</a>, preferred if the rope is greasy. Made by first forming a Blackwall hitch and then taking the underneath part and placing it over the bill of the hook.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="midshipman&#39;s_nuts" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">midshipman's nuts</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Broken pieces of biscuit as dessert.<sup id="cite_ref-smyth_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-smyth-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="midshipman&#39;s_roll" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">midshipman's roll</dfn></dt>
