<dd class="glossary">A slovenly method of rolling up a hammock transversely and lashing it endways by one clue.<sup id="cite_ref-smyth_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-smyth-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="midships" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Midships" class="mw-redirect" title="Midships">midships</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also midship</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A shortened form of <span title="See entry on this page at § amidships" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#amidships" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">amidships</a></span>, with both alternative meanings.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer19757_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer19757-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mile" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mile</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#nautical_mile"><span title="See entry on this page at § nautical mile" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">nautical mile</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="military_mast" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">military mast</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A hollow, tubular <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> used in <a href="#warship"><span title="See entry on this page at § warship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">warships</span></a> in the last third of the 19th century, often equipped with a <span title="See entry on this page at § fighting top" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#fighting_top" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">fighting top</a></span> armed with light-caliber guns.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="millers" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">Millers</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Shipboard rats</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mine" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Naval_mine" title="Naval mine">mine</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A self-contained explosive device intended to damage or sink surface ships or submarines, designed to be placed in water and left to wait until they are triggered by the approach of, proximity of, or contact with, a surface ship or submarines.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="minehunter" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Minehunter" title="Minehunter">minehunter</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel designed or equipped to detect and destroy individual mines. It differs from a <a href="#minesweeper"><span title="See entry on this page at § minesweeper" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">minesweeper</span></a>, which is designed or equipped to clear areas of water of mines without necessarily detecting them first.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="minelayer" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Minelayer#Naval_minelayers" title="Minelayer">minelayer</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel designed or equipped to deploy (or "lay") mines.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="minesweeper" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Minesweeper_(ship)" class="mw-redirect" title="Minesweeper (ship)">minesweeper</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel designed or equipped to clear areas of water of mines without necessarily detecting them first. It differs from a <a href="#minehunter"><span title="See entry on this page at § minehunter" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">minehunter</span></a>, which is designed or equipped to detect and destroy individual mines.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="misstay" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">misstay</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To be "<span title="See entry on this page at § in irons" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#in_irons" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">in irons</a></span>" (i.e. to lose forward momentum) when changing <a href="#tack"><span title="See entry on this page at § tack" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tack</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mizzen" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mizzen</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A <i>mizzen sail</i> is a small <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> (triangular or <span title="See entry on this page at § gaff" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gaff" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gaff</a></span>) on a <span title="See entry on this page at § ketch" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#ketch" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">ketch</a></span> or <a href="#yawl"><span title="See entry on this page at § yawl" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yawl</span></a> set <span title="See entry on this page at § abaft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#abaft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">abaft</a></span> the <a href="#mizzenmast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mizzenmast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mizzenmast</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A <i>mizzen staysail</i> is an occasional lightweight <a href="#staysail"><span title="See entry on this page at § staysail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">staysail</span></a> on a ketch or yawl, set forward of the mizzenmast while reaching in light to moderate airs.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;A <i>mizzenmast</i> is a <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> on a ketch or yawl, or <a href="/wiki/Thames_barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Thames barge">spritsail barge</a>. Its positioning afore of abaft the <a href="#rudder_post"><span title="See entry on this page at § rudder post" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rudder post</span></a> distinguishes between a ketch or a yawl. On a barge its rig determines if she is a <a href="#muffie"><span title="See entry on this page at § muffie" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">muffie</span></a> or a <a href="#mulie"><span title="See entry on this page at § mulie" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mulie</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mizzenmast" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Mast_(sailing)" title="Mast (sailing)">mizzenmast</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>mizzen</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The third <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a>, or the mast <span title="See entry on this page at § aft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aft</a></span> of the <a href="#mainmast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainmast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainmast</span></a>, on a ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mole" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Mole_(architecture)" title="Mole (architecture)">mole</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A massive structure, usually of stone or concrete, used as a <a href="#pier"><span title="See entry on this page at § pier" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">pier</span></a>, breakwater, or causeway between places separated by water. May have a wooden structure built upon it and resemble a wooden pier or <a href="#wharf"><span title="See entry on this page at § wharf" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">wharf</span></a>, but a mole differs from a pier, quay, or wharf in that water cannot flow freely underneath it.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="monitor" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Monitor_(ship)" class="mw-redirect" title="Monitor (ship)">monitor</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A turreted <span title="See entry on this page at § ironclad" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#ironclad" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">ironclad</a></span> <a href="#warship"><span title="See entry on this page at § warship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">warship</span></a> of the second half of the 19th century characterized by low <span title="See entry on this page at § freeboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#freeboard" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">freeboard</a></span>, shallow <span title="See entry on this page at § draft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#draft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">draft</a></span>, poor <a href="#seaworthy"><span title="See entry on this page at § seaworthy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">seaworthiness</span></a>, and heavy guns, intended for riverine and coastal operations.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;In occasional 19th-century usage, any turreted warship.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;A shallow-draft armored shore bombardment vessel of the first half of the 20th century, designed to provide fire support to ground troops, often mounting heavy guns.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Breastwork_monitor" title="Breastwork monitor">breastwork monitor</a>) A 19th-century monitor designed with a <a href="/wiki/Breastwork_(fortification)" title="Breastwork (fortification)">breastwork</a> to improve seaworthiness.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">5.&#160;&#160;(<a href="/wiki/River_monitor" title="River monitor">river monitor</a>) A monitor specifically designed for riverine operations, used during the 19th and 20th centuries and more recently than other types of monitor. River monitors generally are smaller and lighter than other monitors.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="monkey_bridge" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">monkey bridge</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A high platform above the <a href="#wheelhouse"><span title="See entry on this page at § wheelhouse" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">wheelhouse</span></a> offering better visibility to the operator while maneuvering.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="monkey&#39;s_fist" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Monkey%27s_fist" title="Monkey&#39;s fist">monkey's fist</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A ball woven out of <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">line</a></span> used to provide heft to heave the line to another location. The monkey fist and other heaving-line knots were sometimes weighted with lead (easily available in the form of foil used e.g. to seal tea chests from dampness) although <a href="/wiki/The_Ashley_Book_of_Knots" title="The Ashley Book of Knots">Clifford W. Ashley</a> notes that there was a "definite sporting limit" to the weight thus added.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="moor" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Mooring_(watercraft)" class="mw-redirect" title="Mooring (watercraft)">moor</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;To attach a boat to a <a href="#mooring"><span title="See entry on this page at § mooring" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mooring</span></a> <span title="See entry on this page at § buoy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#buoy" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">buoy</a></span> or post.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;To <span title="See entry on this page at § dock" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#dock" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">dock</a></span> a ship.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;To secure a vessel with a <span title="See entry on this page at § cable" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cable" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cable</a></span> or <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mooring" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Mooring_(watercraft)" class="mw-redirect" title="Mooring (watercraft)">mooring</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>moorings</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A place to <a href="#moor"><span title="See entry on this page at § moor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">moor</span></a> a vessel.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mother_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Mother_ship" title="Mother ship">mother ship</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>mothership</b> and <b>mother-ship</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel that leads, serves, or carries smaller vessels, in the latter case either releasing them and then proceeding independently or also recovering them after they have completed a mission or operation. A mother ship sometimes contrasts with a <a href="#tender"><span title="See entry on this page at § tender" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tender</span></a>, which often (but not necessarily) is a vessel that supports or cares for larger vessels.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mould" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mould</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A template of the shape of the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> in transverse section. Several moulds are used to form a temporary framework around which a hull is built.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mould_loft" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mould loft</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Where the <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lines</a></span> of the ship are drawn out full-size and the templates for the timbers are made.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mousing" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mousing</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Several turns of light <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">line</a></span> around the mouth of a hook, to prevent unhooking accidents.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="mulie" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">mulie</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <span title="See entry on this page at § barge" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#barge" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">barge</a></span> rigged with a <a href="#spritsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § spritsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spritsail</span></a> main, and a large <span title="See entry on this page at § gaff rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gaff_rig" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gaff rigged</a></span> <a href="#mizzen"><span title="See entry on this page at § mizzen" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mizzen</span></a> <span title="See entry on this page at § afore" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#afore" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">afore</a></span> the steering wheel. It is sheeted to the saddle <span title="See entry on this page at § chock" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#chock" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">chock</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="multipurpose_vessel" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">multipurpose vessel</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <span title="See entry on this page at § cargo ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cargo_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cargo ship</a></span> that has fittings to carry standard shipping containers and retractable <a href="#tweendecks"><span title="See entry on this page at § tweendecks" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tweendecks</span></a> that can be moved out of the way so that the ship can carry bulk cargo.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="multiservice_tactical_brevity_code" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Multiservice_tactical_brevity_code" title="Multiservice tactical brevity code">multiservice tactical brevity code</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Codes used by various military forces to convey complex information in a few words.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="muster_drill" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Muster_drill" title="Muster drill">muster drill</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An exercise conducted by the <span title="See entry on this page at § crew" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#crew" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">crew</a></span> of a ship prior to embarking on a voyage. Passengers are required to participate in the drill so that they can be instructed how to evacuate safely in the event of an emergency on board the ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="muster_station" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">muster station</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A specific location on a vessel planned as a gathering place during an emergency or a muster drill. If a person is believed missing, all passengers must report to their muster station for a head count.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="muzzle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">muzzle</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Iron ban around the <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> to hold the <span title="See entry on this page at § heel" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#heel" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">heel</a></span> of the <a href="#sprit"><span title="See entry on this page at § sprit" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sprit</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="m.v._(or_mv)" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">M.V. (or MV)</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="MV"></span>
<dd class="glossary">An abbreviation for <i><a href="/wiki/Motor_Ship" class="mw-redirect" title="Motor Ship">Motor Vessel</a></i>, used before a ship<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s name.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="m.y._(or_my)" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">M.Y. (or MY)</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="MY"></span>
<dd class="glossary">An abbreviation for <i><a href="/wiki/Motor_Yacht" class="mw-redirect" title="Motor Yacht">Motor Yacht</a></i>, used before a yacht's name.</dd>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1098327943"/>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="N">N</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: N">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<dt class="glossary" id="natural_harbour" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Harbor#Natural_harbors" title="Harbor">natural harbour</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A body of water protected from the weather by virtue of its being mostly surrounded by land, and deep enough to provide <span title="See entry on this page at § anchorage" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchorage" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchorage</a></span> for the vessels using it.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="narrowboat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Narrowboat" title="Narrowboat">narrowboat</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of boat designed specifically to fit the narrow canal locks of the United Kingdom.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="narrows" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Narrows" title="Narrows">narrows</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A narrow part of a navigable <a href="#waterway"><span title="See entry on this page at § waterway" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">waterway</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="nautical" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Nautical" class="mw-redirect" title="Nautical">nautical</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Of or pertaining to sailors, seamanship, or navigation; maritime.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="nautical_chart" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Nautical_chart" title="Nautical chart">nautical chart</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A map of a sea or ocean area and adjacent coastal regions, intended specifically for navigation at sea. Nautical charts use <a href="/wiki/Map_projection" title="Map projection">map projections</a> designed for easy use with hand instruments, such as the <a href="/wiki/Mercator_projection" title="Mercator projection">Mercator projection</a>, and indicate depths, hazards, <span title="See entry on this page at § landmark" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#landmark" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">landmarks</a></span>, <span title="See entry on this page at § aid to navigation" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aid_to_navigation" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aids to navigation</a></span> such as <span title="See entry on this page at § buoy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#buoy" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">buoys</a></span>, and <span title="See entry on this page at § ashore" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#ashore" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">ashore</a></span> facilities of interest to <a href="#mariner"><span title="See entry on this page at § mariner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mariners</span></a>. Nautical charts are generally originally published by government agencies such as the U.S. <a href="/wiki/National_Oceanic_and_Atmospheric_Administration" title="National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration">National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration</a>, and are now provided in both print form and digital for use in chartplotters.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="nautical_mile" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Nautical_mile" title="Nautical mile">nautical mile</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A unit of length corresponding to approximately one <a href="/wiki/Minute_of_arc" class="mw-redirect" title="Minute of arc">minute of arc</a> of <a href="/wiki/Latitude" title="Latitude">latitude</a> along any <a href="/wiki/Meridian_arc" title="Meridian arc">meridian arc</a>. By international agreement, it is equivalent to exactly 1,852 metres (6,076&#160;ft; 1.151&#160;mi).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="naval_programme" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">naval programme</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The British system of authorizing naval construction by an annual <a href="/wiki/Bill_(proposed_law)" class="mw-redirect" title="Bill (proposed law)">bill</a> in <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">Parliament</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="naval_infantry" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">naval infantry</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;<a href="#sailor"><span title="See entry on this page at § sailor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">Sailors</span></a> subordinated to a <a href="#navy"><span title="See entry on this page at § navy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">navy</span></a> trained and equipped to operate <span title="See entry on this page at § ashore" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#ashore" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">ashore</a></span> temporarily as an organized infantry force, but at other times responsible for the normal duties of sailors aboard ship.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A specialized, permanent force of troops subordinated to a navy and responsible for infantry operations ashore. Although more specialized than sailors trained to operate temporarily as naval infantry and bearing similarities to a <a href="#marine"><span title="See entry on this page at § marine" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">marine</span></a> force or <i>marine corps</i>, such permanent naval infantry forces often lack the full capabilities of a marine force. Naval infantry forces also usually differ from marine forces in being subordinated directly to a navy rather than to a separate branch of naval service such as a marine corps.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="navigation" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Navigation" title="Navigation">navigation</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">All activities related to determining, plotting, and tracking the position and <span title="See entry on this page at § course" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#course" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">course</a></span> of a ship in order to keep track of its position relative to land while at sea. Navigation charts have been used since ancient times, and remain in use as back-ups to modern satellite-based <a href="/wiki/Positioning_system" title="Positioning system">positioning systems</a>. Numerous map projections including the common Mercator projection were developed specifically to make navigation at sea simple to perform with straight-edges and compasses.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="navigation_rules" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/International_Regulations_for_Preventing_Collisions_at_Sea" title="International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea">navigation rules</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Traffic#Rules_of_the_road" title="Traffic">Rules of the road</a> that provide guidance on how to avoid collision and also used to assign blame when a collision does occur.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="nay" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">nay</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">"No"; a reply in the negative. The opposite of "<span title="See entry on this page at § aye" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aye" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aye</a></span>."</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="net_laying_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Net_laying_ship" title="Net laying ship">net laying ship</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>net layer</b>, <b>net tender</b>, <b>gate ship</b>, or <b>boom defence vessel</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A type of naval <span title="See entry on this page at § auxiliary ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#auxiliary_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">auxiliary ship</a></span> equipped for and primarily tasked with laying <a href="#torpedo_net"><span title="See entry on this page at § torpedo net" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">torpedo net</span></a>s or <span title="See entry on this page at § anti-submarine net" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anti-submarine_net" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anti-submarine net</a></span>s to protect individual ships at anchor, harbors, or other anchorages from <a href="#torpedo"><span title="See entry on this page at § torpedo" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">torpedo</span></a> attack and intrusions by <a href="#submarine"><span title="See entry on this page at § submarine" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">submarines</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="net_tender" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">net tender</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An alternative term for a <a href="#net_laying_ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § net laying ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">net laying ship</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="new_company_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">New Company ship</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A term used for a ship trading between England and ports east of the <a href="/wiki/Cape_of_Good_Hope" title="Cape of Good Hope">Cape of Good Hope</a> for the English Company Trading to the East Indies, a new company chartered in 1697 to compete with the "old" <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">East India Company</a>. The term fell into disuse when the two companies merged in 1707.<sup id="cite_ref-threedecksshiproles_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-threedecksshiproles-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="night_boat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">night boat</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">(United States) A type of <a href="#steamboat"><span title="See entry on this page at § steamboat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">steamboat</span></a> that provided sleeping quarters for passengers on overnight voyages, as opposed to a <span title="See entry on this page at § day boat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#day_boat" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">day boat</a></span> that had no need of such facilities.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="nipper" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">nipper</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A short rope used to bind a <span title="See entry on this page at § cable" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cable" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cable</a></span> to the "messenger" (a moving <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">line</a></span> propelled by the <span title="See entry on this page at § capstan" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#capstan" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">capstan</a></span>) so that the cable is dragged along, too (used where the cable is too large to be wrapped around the capstan itself). During the raising of an <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor</a></span>, the nippers were attached and detached from the (endless) messenger by the ship's boys. Hence the term for small boys: "nippers".</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="nock" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">nock</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The throat of the <a href="#mainsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainsail</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="no_room_to_swing_a_cat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">no room to swing a cat</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The entire <a href="#ship&#39;s_company"><span title="See entry on this page at § ship&#39;s company" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ship's company</span></a> was expected to witness floggings, assembled on deck. If it was very crowded, the <span title="See entry on this page at § boatswain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#boatswain" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bosun</a></span> might not have room to swing the <span title="See entry on this page at § cat o&#39; nine tails" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cat_o&#39;_nine_tails" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cat o' nine tails</a></span> (the whip).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="non-self-sustaining" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">non-self-sustaining</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#self-sustaining"><span title="See entry on this page at § self-sustaining" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">self-sustaining</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="nun" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">nun</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of navigational <span title="See entry on this page at § buoy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#buoy" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">buoy</a></span>, often cone-shaped, but if not, always triangular in silhouette, colored green in <a href="/wiki/Lateral_mark#Region_A" title="Lateral mark">IALA region A</a> or red in <a href="/wiki/Lateral_mark#Region_B" title="Lateral mark">IALA region B</a> (the Americas, Japan, Korea, and the Philippines). In channel marking its use is opposite that of a "can buoy".</dd>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1098327943"/>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="O">O</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: O">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<dt class="glossary" id="oakum" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Oakum" title="Oakum">oakum</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Any material, often tarred <a href="/wiki/Hemp" title="Hemp">hemp</a> fibres picked from old untwisted ropes, used for <span title="See entry on this page at § caulking" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#caulking" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">caulking</a></span> gaps or seams between the planks of <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hulls</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="oar" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">oar</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A pole, usually of wood, with a blade at one end and a handle at the other, which is pivoted on a fulcrum on the side of a boat to provide propulsion by moving the blade through the water.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975164_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975164-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="oar_crutch" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">oar crutch</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A metal (or sometimes plastic) fitting that acts as the fulcrum point of an <a href="#oar"><span title="See entry on this page at § oar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">oar</span></a>. Usually takes the form of a U-shape, with a pin underneath the bottom of the "U". The pin rotates in a socket in the <span title="See entry on this page at § gunwale" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gunwale" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gunwale</a></span> of the boat; the oar rests in the "U".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer197554_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer197554-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> Often referred to as a <a href="#rowlock"><span title="See entry on this page at § rowlock" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rowlock</span></a><sup id="cite_ref-PBO_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PBO-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ocean_liner" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ocean liner</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><span title="See entry on this page at § liner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#liner" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">liner</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="offing" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/offing" class="extiw" title="wikt:offing">offing</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The more distant part of the sea as seen from the shore and generally beyond anchoring ground.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="offshore" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">offshore</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Moving away from the shore.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;(of a wind) Blowing from the land to the sea.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;At some distance from the shore; located in the sea away from the coast.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="oiler" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">oiler</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Oiler_(ship)" class="mw-redirect" title="Oiler (ship)">ship</a>) A naval auxiliary ship with fuel tanks, which refuels other ships.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Oiler_(occupation)" title="Oiler (occupation)">occupation</a>) The job title of a seaman holding a junior position in a ship's engineering crew, senior only to the engine room <a href="#wiper"><span title="See entry on this page at § wiper" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">wiper</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="oilskins" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Oilskin" title="Oilskin">oilskins</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="oilies"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>oilies</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">Foul-weather clothing worn by sailors.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="old_man" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">old man</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary"><span title="See entry on this page at § crew" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#crew" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">Crew</a></span><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s slang for the <span title="See entry on this page at § captain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#captain" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">captain</a></span>, <a href="#master"><span title="See entry on this page at § master" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">master</span></a>, or commanding officer of a vessel.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="old_salt" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">old salt</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Slang for an experienced <a href="#mariner"><span title="See entry on this page at § mariner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mariner</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="on_board" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">on board</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>onboard</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><span title="See entry on this page at § aboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aboard" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aboard</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="on_her_own_bottom" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">on her own bottom</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Plural <b>on their own bottoms</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">Said of a vessel making a voyage without being carried aboard another vessel, e.g., "The <a href="#yacht"><span title="See entry on this page at § yacht" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yacht</span></a> crossed the ocean <i>on her own <span title="See entry on this page at § bottom" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bottom" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bottom</a></span></i>," or in the plural, "Yachts rarely cross the ocean <i>on their own bottoms</i>."</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="on_station" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">on station</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A ship's destination, typically an area to be patrolled or guarded.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="on_the_beach" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">on the beach</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> term that means "retired from the Service."<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="on_the_hard" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">on the hard</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A boat that has been <span title="See entry on this page at § hauling" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hauling" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hauled</a></span> and is now sitting on dry land.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="open_registry" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Open_registry" class="mw-redirect" title="Open registry">open registry</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An organization that will register <a href="#merchant_ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § merchant ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">merchant ships</span></a> owned by foreign entities, generally to provide a <span title="See entry on this page at § flag of convenience" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#flag_of_convenience" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">flag of convenience</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ordinary" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ordinary</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><span title="See entry on this page at § in ordinary" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#in_ordinary" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">in ordinary</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ordinary_seaman" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Ordinary_seaman" title="Ordinary seaman">ordinary seaman</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A seaman in the British Royal Navy in the 18th century who had between one and two years of experience at sea. Later, a formal rank in the Royal Navy for the lowest grade of seaman, now obsolete.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The second-lowest rank in the United States Navy from 1797 to 1917, between <span title="See entry on this page at § landsman" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#landsman" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">landsman</a></span> and <a href="#seaman"><span title="See entry on this page at § seaman" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">seaman</span></a>. Renamed "<a href="#seaman_second_class"><span title="See entry on this page at § seaman second class" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">seaman second class</span></a>" in 1917.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;The <a href="#rating"><span title="See entry on this page at § rating" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rating</span></a> for entry-level personnel in the <span title="See entry on this page at § deck department" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck_department" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck department</a></span> of a ship in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Merchant_Marine" title="United States Merchant Marine">United States Merchant Marine</a>. An ordinary seaman (abbreviated "OS") is considered to be serving an apprenticeship to become an <span title="See entry on this page at § able seaman" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#able_seaman" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">able seaman</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ore_carrier" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ore carrier</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of <span title="See entry on this page at § bulk carrier" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bulk_carrier" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bulk carrier</a></span> specially designed to carry <a href="/wiki/Ore" title="Ore">ore</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="oreboat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">oreboat</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a> term for a vessel primarily used in the transport of iron ore.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="orlop_deck" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Orlop_deck" title="Orlop deck">orlop deck</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The lowest <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> of a <a href="#ship-of-the-line"><span title="See entry on this page at § ship-of-the-line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ship-of-the-line</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The deck covering in the <span title="See entry on this page at § hold" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hold" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hold</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="oscar" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/International_maritime_signal_flags" title="International maritime signal flags">oscar</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;International signal for a <a href="#man_overboard"><span title="See entry on this page at § man overboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">man overboard</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Nickname for a water rescue training dummy. Also see <a href="/wiki/Paradummy" title="Paradummy">paradummy</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="outboard" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">outboard</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Situated outside the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> of a vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Situated within a vessel but positioned away (or farther away, when contrasted with another item) from her <span title="See entry on this page at § centerline" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#centerline" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">centerline</a></span>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;Farther from the hull, e.g. "The larger boat was tied up alongside the ship outboard of the smaller boat."</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;Farther from the pier or shore, e.g. "The tanker and cargo ship were tied up at the pier alongside one another with the tanker outboard of the cargo ship."</dd>
<dd class="glossary">5.&#160;&#160;An <a href="#outboard_motor"><span title="See entry on this page at § outboard motor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">outboard motor</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">6.&#160;&#160;A vessel fitted with an outboard motor.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="outboard_motor" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Outboard_motor" title="Outboard motor">outboard motor</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A motor mounted externally on the <a href="#transom"><span title="See entry on this page at § transom" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">transom</span></a> of a small boat. The boat may be steered by twisting the whole motor, instead of or in addition to using a <a href="#rudder"><span title="See entry on this page at § rudder" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rudder</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="outdrive" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">outdrive</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The lower part of a <a href="#sterndrive"><span title="See entry on this page at § sterndrive" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sterndrive</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="outhaul" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Outhaul" title="Outhaul">outhaul</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">line</a></span> used to control the shape of a <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="outrigger" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Outrigger" title="Outrigger">outrigger</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Generally, a structure projecting from the side of a vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Any contraposing float rigging beyond the side of a vessel to improve the vessel's stability.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;A thin, long, solid, hull used to stabilize the inherently unstable main hull of an <a href="#outrigger_canoe"><span title="See entry on this page at § outrigger canoe" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">outrigger canoe</span></a> or a <a href="#sailboat"><span title="See entry on this page at § sailboat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sailboat</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;A variety of structures projecting from a <span title="See entry on this page at § keelboat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#keelboat" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">keelboat</a></span> by which the <a href="#running_rigging"><span title="See entry on this page at § running rigging" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">running rigging</span></a> may be attached outboard of the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">5.&#160;&#160;A pole or series of poles projecting from a <span title="See entry on this page at § fishing vessel" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#fishing_vessel" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">fishing vessel</a></span> that allow the vessel to trawl with more fishing lines in the water without the lines tangling and allowing lures and bait to simulate a school of fish.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">6.&#160;&#160;A triangular frame on a <a href="#rowboat"><span title="See entry on this page at § rowboat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rowboat</span></a> or <span title="See entry on this page at § galley" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#galley" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">galley</a></span> that holds the <a href="#rowlock"><span title="See entry on this page at § rowlock" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rowlock</span></a> away from the <a href="#saxboard"><span title="See entry on this page at § saxboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">saxboard</span></a> or <span title="See entry on this page at § gunwale" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gunwale" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gunwale</a></span> to optimize leverage for the rowers. Also called a <i>rigger</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="outward_bound" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">outward bound</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To leave the safety of <a href="#port"><span title="See entry on this page at § port" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">port</span></a>, heading for the open ocean.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="over-canvassed" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Over-canvassed" class="mw-redirect" title="Over-canvassed">over-canvassed</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To have too great a sail area up to safely maneuver in the current wind conditions.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="over-reaching" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">over-reaching</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Holding a course too long while <a href="#tacking"><span title="See entry on this page at § tacking" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tacking</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="over_the_barrel" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Barrel" title="Barrel">over the barrel</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Adult sailors were flogged on the back or shoulders while tied to a grating, but boys were beaten instead on the posterior (often bared), with a cane or <span title="See entry on this page at § cat o&#39; nine tails" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cat_o&#39;_nine_tails" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cat o' nine tails</a></span>, while bending, often tied down, over the barrel of a gun, known as <span title="See entry on this page at § kissing the gunner&#39;s daughter" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#kissing_the_gunner&#39;s_daughter" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">kissing the gunner's daughter</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="overbear" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">overbear</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To sail downwind directly at another ship, stealing the wind from its sails.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="overboard" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">overboard</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Off or outside a vessel. If something or someone falls, jumps, or is thrown off of a vessel into the water, the object or person is said to have gone overboard. See "Man overboard!"</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="overfalls" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">overfalls</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Dangerously steep and breaking seas due to opposing currents and wind in a shallow area, or strong currents over a shallow rocky bottom.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="overhead" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">overhead</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The ceiling of any enclosed space below decks in a vessel, essentially the bottom of the deck above.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="overhaul" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">overhaul</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Hauling the <span title="See entry on this page at § buntline" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#buntline" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">buntline</a></span> ropes over the sails to prevent them from <span title="See entry on this page at § chafing" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#chafing" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">chafing</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="overtaking_sea" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Overtaking_sea" class="mw-redirect" title="Overtaking sea">overtaking sea</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Seas approaching a vessel from between 15° to port or starboard of astern at a speed greater than that of the vessel.<sup id="cite_ref-Saunders_V3_1965_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Saunders_V3_1965-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> </dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="overwhelmed" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">overwhelmed</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary"><span title="See entry on this page at § capsize" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#capsize" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">Capsized</a></span> or <span title="See entry on this page at § founder" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#founder" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">foundered</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="owner" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">owner</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Traditional Royal Navy term for the <span title="See entry on this page at § captain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#captain" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">captain</a></span>, a survival from the days when privately owned ships were often hired for naval service.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ox-eye" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ox-eye</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A cloud or other weather phenomenon that may be indicative of an upcoming storm.</dd>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1098327943"/>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="P">P</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: P">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<dt class="glossary" id="packet" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">packet</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="Packet_boat"></span><span class="anchor" id="Packet_ship"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>packet boat</b> or <b>packet ship</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Originally, a vessel employed to carry post office mail packets to and from British embassies, colonies, and outposts.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Later, any regularly scheduled ship, carrying passengers, as in <a href="#packet_trade"><span title="See entry on this page at § packet trade" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">packet trade</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="packet_trade" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Packet_trade" title="Packet trade">packet trade</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Any regularly scheduled cargo, passenger, and mail trade conducted by ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="packetman" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">packetman</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A seaman aboard a ship engaged in <a href="#packet_trade"><span title="See entry on this page at § packet trade" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">packet trade</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="paddle_box" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">paddle box</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A covering, usually made of wood, for the upper part of a <a href="/wiki/Paddle_wheel" title="Paddle wheel">paddle wheel</a> on a <a href="/wiki/Paddle_steamer" title="Paddle steamer">paddle steamer</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="paddle_guards" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">paddle guards</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><span title="See entry on this page at § guards" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#guards" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">guards</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="paddy_wester" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Paddy_wester" title="Paddy wester">paddy wester</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Traditional Royal Navy term for a young or inexperienced seaman. </dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pagoda_mast" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Pagoda_mast" title="Pagoda mast">pagoda mast</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A large and distinctive type of <span title="See entry on this page at § foremast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#foremast" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">foremast</a></span> installed aboard <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Navy" title="Imperial Japanese Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a> <a href="/wiki/Battleship" title="Battleship">battleships</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battlecruiser" title="Battlecruiser">battlecruisers</a> during modernization and reconstruction of the ships in the 1930s. A pagoda mast was created by strengthening a ship's existing <a href="/wiki/Tripod_mast" title="Tripod mast">tripod foremast</a> and adding platforms to it for <a href="/wiki/Searchlights" class="mw-redirect" title="Searchlights">searchlights</a>, <span title="See entry on this page at § lookout" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lookout" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lookout</a></span>s, shelters, and other structures, giving the mast the appearance of a <a href="/wiki/Pagoda" title="Pagoda">pagoda</a> temple. </dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="painter" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">painter</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A rope attached to the <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> of a vessel, used to make the vessel <span title="See entry on this page at § fast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#fast" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">fast</a></span> to a <span title="See entry on this page at § dock" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#dock" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">dock</a></span> or a larger vessel, including when towed <span title="See entry on this page at § astern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#astern" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">astern</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="palm" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">palm</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A protective device, usually leather, worn on the hand when working with a sail needle to repair sails.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="panting" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Panting_(ship_construction)" title="Panting (ship construction)">panting</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The pulsation in and out of the <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> and <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a> plating as the ship alternately rises and plunges deep into the water.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="paravane" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">paravane</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Paravane_(weapon)" title="Paravane (weapon)">Paravane (weapon)</a>) A device stabilized by vanes that functions as an underwater glider and is usually streamed from the bow of a vessel and towed alongside. A submerged mine's mooring would  be cut by the paravane or the explosive head on the paravane would destroy the mine <sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> </dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Paravane_(water_kite)" title="Paravane (water kite)">water kite</a>) A towed underwater object with hydrofoils, of use in commercial and sport fishing, water sports, marine exploration, the marine industry, and military operations, sometimes equipped with sensors and also of use in exerting a sideward holding force on a vessel. Also called a <i>water kite</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="parbuckle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">parbuckle</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A method of lifting a roughly cylindrical object such as a <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spar</span></a>. One end of a rope is made fast above the object, a loop of rope is lowered and passed around the object, which can be raised by hauling on the free end of rope.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="parley" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Parley" title="Parley">parley</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A discussion or conference, especially between enemies, over terms of a truce or other matters.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="parrel" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Parrel_beads" title="Parrel beads">parrel</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A movable loop or collar, used to fasten a <a href="#yard"><span title="See entry on this page at § yard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yard</span></a> or <span title="See entry on this page at § gaff" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gaff" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gaff</a></span> to its respective <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a>. A parrel still allows the spar to be raised or lowered and swivel around the mast. It is sometimes with made of wire or rope and fitted with beads to reduce friction.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="part_brass_rags" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">part brass rags</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Fall out with a friend. From the days when cleaning materials were shared between sailors.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="passageway" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">passageway</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An interior corridor or hallway on a ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="passenger-cargoman" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">passenger-cargoman</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><span title="See entry on this page at § cargo liner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cargo_liner" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cargo liner</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="passenger-cargo_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">passenger-cargo ship</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><span title="See entry on this page at § cargo liner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cargo_liner" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cargo liner</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pawls" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pawls</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Small bars used to stop the barrel of a <a href="#winch"><span title="See entry on this page at § winch" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">winch</span></a> or <span title="See entry on this page at § capstan" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#capstan" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">capstan</a></span> moving backward under an increased load or if the turning power was reduced. In early capstans, the pawls had to be manually moved in and out of the notches in which they worked. Later capstans had automatic pawls that dropped into notches as the barrel turned.
