In breaking out an <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor</a></span>, a crew would "heave and pawl" if the bow was rising and falling with the waves, so giving a varying load on the <span title="See entry on this page at § cable" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cable" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cable</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarland1984260–261,_276_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarland1984260–261,_276-15">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pay_off" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pay off</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;To let a vessel's head fall off from the wind (to <span title="See entry on this page at § leeward" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#leeward" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">leeward</a></span>.)<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;During the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Sail" title="Age of Sail">Age of Sail</a>, the practice of paying a crew its wages for the voyage when a vessel completed her voyage, at which point the crew was <i>paid off</i>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;In British and Commonwealth usage, to <span title="See entry on this page at § decommission" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#decommission" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">decommission</a></span> a warship, e.g., "The old destroyer <i>paid off</i> after returning to port at the end of her final cruise."</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="paying" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">paying</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Filling a seam (with <span title="See entry on this page at § caulking" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#caulking" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">caulking</a></span> or pitch), lubricating the running <a href="#rigging"><span title="See entry on this page at § rigging" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rigging</span></a>; paying with <a href="#slush"><span title="See entry on this page at § slush" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">slush</span></a>, protecting from the weather by covering with slush. See also <i><a href="#the_devil_to_pay"><span title="See entry on this page at § the devil to pay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">the devil to pay</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="paymaster" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">paymaster</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The officer responsible for all money matters in Royal Navy ships including the paying and provisioning of the crew, all stores, tools, and spare parts. See also <i><a href="#purser"><span title="See entry on this page at § purser" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">purser</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pea_coat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pea coat</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Heavy topcoat originally made from pilot cloth.<sup id="cite_ref-NHHC_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NHHC-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> Officers and chief petty officers wear a variation with gold buttons called a <i>reefer</i> or a longer model called a <i>bridge coat</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="peak" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">peak</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The upper <span title="See entry on this page at § aftermost" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aftermost" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aftermost</a></span> corner of a <span title="See entry on this page at § fore-and-aft rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#fore-and-aft_rig" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">fore-and-aft</a></span> <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a>; used in many combinations, such as <i>peak-halyards</i>, <i>peak-brails</i>, etc.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The narrow part of a vessel's bow, or the <span title="See entry on this page at § hold" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hold" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hold</a></span> within it.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;The extremity of an <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor</a></span> fluke; the bill.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="peaks" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">peaks</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The uppermost <span title="See entry on this page at § brail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#brail" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">brails</a></span> on the <a href="#mainsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainsail</span></a>. Upper and lower peaks are normal, but a barge may carry a third set, too.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pelagic" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pelagic</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Living in the open ocean rather than coastal or inland waters (e.g. a pelagic shark).</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Taking place in the open ocean (e.g. pelagic fishing, pelagic sealing).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pelican_hook" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Pelican_hook" title="Pelican hook">pelican hook</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A hook with a hinge in the curve of the hook, normally held closed by a metal ring that keeps the two hinged parts together. Can be instantly released by knocking the ring along the hook so that it frees one of the hinged parts which swings open and releases whatever the hook is holding. Often seen on opening sections of guard rails and life-raft lashings, but also used on more heavily loaded components. May also be called a slip-hook or a Davey hook.<sup id="cite_ref-PBO_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PBO-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975111_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975111-17">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pendant" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pendant</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A length of wire or rope secured at one end to a <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> or <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spar</span></a> and having a <span title="See entry on this page at § block" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#block" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">block</a></span> or other fitting at the lower end.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A length of wire or rope hooked to a <a href="#tackle"><span title="See entry on this page at § tackle" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tackle</span></a> on <span title="See entry on this page at § leeboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#leeboard" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">leeboards</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;An alternate spelling of <a href="#pennant"><span title="See entry on this page at § pennant" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">pennant</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pennant" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Pennant_(commissioning)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pennant (commissioning)">pennant</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A long, thin triangular flag flown from the <a href="#masthead"><span title="See entry on this page at § masthead" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">masthead</span></a> of a military ship (as opposed to a <span title="See entry on this page at § burgee" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#burgee" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">burgee</a></span>, the flags thus flown on yachts).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="picaroon" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/picaroon" class="extiw" title="wikt:picaroon">picaroon</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An obsolete (circa 17th century) term for a pirate: From Spanish</dd>.

<dt class="glossary" id="picket_boat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Picket_(military)" title="Picket (military)">picket boat</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A boat on sentry duty, or one placed on a line forward of a position to warn against an enemy advance.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pier" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Pier" title="Pier">pier</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A raised structure, typically supported by widely spread piles or pillars, used industrially for loading and unloading commercial ships, recreationally for walking and housing attractions at a seaside resort, or as a structure for use by boatless fishermen. The lighter structure of a pier contrasts with the more solid foundations of a <a href="#quay"><span title="See entry on this page at § quay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">quay</span></a> or the closely spaced piles of a <a href="#wharf"><span title="See entry on this page at § wharf" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">wharf</span></a>. In North America, the term "pier" used alone connotes either a pier used (or formerly used) by commercial shipping or one used for fishing, while in Europe the term used alone connotes a recreational pier at a seaside resort.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pier-head_jump" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pier-head jump</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">When a sailor is drafted to a <a href="#warship"><span title="See entry on this page at § warship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">warship</span></a> at the last minute, just before she sails.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pilot" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Maritime_pilot" title="Maritime pilot">pilot</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A specially knowledgeable person qualified to navigate a vessel through difficult waters, e.g. harbour pilot, etc.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pilot_boat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Pilot_boat" title="Pilot boat">pilot boat</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of boat used to transport maritime <a href="#pilot"><span title="See entry on this page at § pilot" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">pilots</span></a> between land and the inbound or outbound ships that they are piloting.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pilot_ladder" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Pilot_ladder" title="Pilot ladder">pilot ladder</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A highly specialized form of <a href="/wiki/Rope_ladder" class="mw-redirect" title="Rope ladder">rope ladder</a>, typically used to embark and disembark <a href="#pilot"><span title="See entry on this page at § pilot" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">pilots</span></a> over the side of a ship. Sometimes confused with <span title="See entry on this page at § Jacob&#39;s ladder" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#Jacob&#39;s_ladder" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">Jacob's ladders</a></span>, but the design and construction of pilot ladders is governed tightly by international regulation and includes spreaders – elongated versions of the standard machined step – rather than the type of steps generally found on Jacob′s ladders.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pim" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">PIM</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Points (or plan) of intended movement. The charted course for a naval unit's movements.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pinnace" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pinnace</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Pinnace_(ship%27s_boat)" title="Pinnace (ship&#39;s boat)">ship's boat</a>) A small, light boat propelled by <a href="#oar"><span title="See entry on this page at § oar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">oars</span></a> or a <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a>, used as a <a href="#tender"><span title="See entry on this page at § tender" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tender</span></a> to larger vessels during the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Sail" title="Age of Sail">Age of Sail</a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Full-rigged_pinnace" title="Full-rigged pinnace">full-rigged pinnace</a>) A small "race built" <span title="See entry on this page at § galleon" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#galleon" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">galleon</a></span>, <a href="#square_rig"><span title="See entry on this page at § square rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square-rigged</span></a> with either two or three <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">masts</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;In modern usage, any small boat other than a <span title="See entry on this page at § launch" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#launch" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">launch</a></span> or <span title="See entry on this page at § lifeboat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lifeboat" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lifeboat</a></span> associated with a larger vessel.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pintle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Pintle" title="Pintle">pintle</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The pin or bolt on which a ship's <a href="#rudder"><span title="See entry on this page at § rudder" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rudder</span></a> pivots. The pintle rests in the <span title="See entry on this page at § gudgeon" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gudgeon" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gudgeon</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pipe_(bos&#39;n&#39;s)" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pipe (bos'n's)</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="bosun&#39;s_pipe"></span><span class="anchor" id="bos&#39;n&#39;s_pipe"></span><span class="anchor" id="bosun&#39;s_call"></span><span class="anchor" id="bos&#39;n&#39;s_call"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>bosun's call</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A whistle used by <span title="See entry on this page at § boatswain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#boatswain" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">boatswains</a></span> (bosuns or bos'ns) to issue commands. Consisting of a metal tube that directs the breath over an aperture on the top of a hollow ball to produce high-pitched notes. The pitch of the notes can be changed by partly covering the aperture with the finger of the hand in which the pipe is held. The shape of the instrument is similar to that of a smoking pipe.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pipe_down" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pipe down</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A signal on the <span title="See entry on this page at § bosun&#39;s pipe" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bosun&#39;s_pipe" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bosun's pipe</a></span> to signal the end of the day, requiring lights (and smoking pipes) to be extinguished and silence from the crew.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="piping_the_side" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">piping the side</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="/wiki/Salute" title="Salute">salute</a> on the <span title="See entry on this page at § bosun&#39;s pipe" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bosun&#39;s_pipe" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bosun's pipe(s)</a></span> performed in the company of the deck watch on the <a href="#starboard"><span title="See entry on this page at § starboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">starboard</span></a> side of the <a href="#quarterdeck"><span title="See entry on this page at § quarterdeck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">quarterdeck</span></a> or at the head of the <span title="See entry on this page at § gangway" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gangway" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gangway</a></span>, to welcome or bid farewell to the ship's <span title="See entry on this page at § captain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#captain" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">captain</a></span>, senior officers, and honoured visitors.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="piracy" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Piracy" title="Piracy">piracy</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An act of robbery or criminal violence at sea by the occupants of one vessel against the occupants of another vessel (and therefore excluding such acts committed by the crew or passengers of a vessel against others aboard the same vessel). Piracy is also distinguished from <a href="#privateering"><span title="See entry on this page at § privateering" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">privateering</span></a>, which is authorized by national authorities and therefore a legitimate form of war-like activity by non-state actors.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pirate" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pirate</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">One who engages in an act of <a href="#piracy"><span title="See entry on this page at § piracy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">piracy</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pitch" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Ship_motions" title="Ship motions">pitch</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel's motion, rotating about the <span title="See entry on this page at § beam" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#beam" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">beam</a></span>/transverse axis, causing the <span title="See entry on this page at § fore" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#fore" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">fore</a></span> and <span title="See entry on this page at § aft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aft</a></span> ends to rise and fall repetitively.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pitchpole" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pitchpole</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To capsize a boat stern over bow, rather than by rolling over.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pivotting" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pivotting</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To turn a sailing <span title="See entry on this page at § barge" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#barge" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">barge</a></span> in shallow water by dropping the <span title="See entry on this page at § leeboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#leeboard" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">leeboard</a></span> so it drags in the mud, then putting the <span title="See entry on this page at § helm" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#helm" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">helm</a></span> <span title="See entry on this page at § hard over" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hard_over" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hard over</a></span>. The maneuver is often used to enter congested harbours.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="plane" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Planing_(sailing)" class="mw-redirect" title="Planing (sailing)">plane</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To skim over the water at high speed rather than push through it.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="plimsoll_line" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Plimsoll_line" class="mw-redirect" title="Plimsoll line">Plimsoll line</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="National_Load_Line"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>National Load Line</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A special marking, positioned <span title="See entry on this page at § amidships" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#amidships" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">amidships</a></span>, that indicates the <span title="See entry on this page at § draft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#draft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">draft</a></span> of the vessel and the legal limit to which the vessel may be loaded for specific water types and temperatures.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="plotting_room" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">plotting room</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#transmitting_station"><span title="See entry on this page at § transmitting station" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">transmitting station</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="point" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">point</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A unit of <a href="/wiki/Bearing_(navigation)" class="mw-redirect" title="Bearing (navigation)">bearing</a> equal to <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020198016">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style><span class="frac" role="math"><span class="num">1</span>&#8260;<span class="den">32</span></span> of a circle, i.e. 11.25 degrees. A turn of 32 points is a complete turn through 360 degrees.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="point_up" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">point up</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b><span title="See entry on this page at § heading up" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#heading_up" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">heading up</a></span></b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">To change the direction of a sailboat so that it is more upwind. To bring the <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> <a href="#windward"><span title="See entry on this page at § windward" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">windward</span></a>. This is the opposite of <span title="See entry on this page at § falling off" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#falling_off" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">falling off</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="points_of_sail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Points_of_sail" class="mw-redirect" title="Points of sail">points of sail</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The course of a sailing vessel in relation to the direction of the wind, divided into six points: <i><span title="See entry on this page at § in irons" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#in_irons" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">in irons</a></span></i> (pointed directly into the wind), <i><span title="See entry on this page at § close hauled" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#close_hauled" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">close hauled</a></span></i> (sailing as close into the direction of the wind as possible), <i><span title="See entry on this page at § close reach" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#close_reach" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">close reach</a></span></i> (between close hauled and beam reach), <i><span title="See entry on this page at § beam reach" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#beam_reach" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">beam reach</a></span></i> (perpendicular to the wind), <i><span title="See entry on this page at § broad reach" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#broad_reach" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">broad reach</a></span></i> (wind behind the vessel at an angle), and <i><a href="#running_downwind"><span title="See entry on this page at § running downwind" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">running downwind</span></a></i> or <i>running before the wind</i> (wind directly behind the vessel).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="polacca" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Polacca" title="Polacca">polacca</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="polacre"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>polacre</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A 17th-century sailing vessel commonly seen in the Mediterranean, similar to a <a href="#xebec"><span title="See entry on this page at § xebec" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">xebec</span></a> with two or three <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">masts</span></a>; two-masted polaccas were known as <i>brig-polaccas</i> and three-masted polaccas as <i>ship-polaccas</i> or <i><a href="#polacca-settee"><span title="See entry on this page at § polacca-settee" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">polacca-settees</span></a></i>. Polacca-settees had a <span title="See entry on this page at § lateen" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lateen" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lateen</a></span> sail on the <span title="See entry on this page at § foremast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#foremast" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">foremast</a></span>, a European-style <a href="#square_rig"><span title="See entry on this page at § square rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square rig</span></a> on the <a href="#mainmast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainmast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainmast</span></a>, and a <span title="See entry on this page at § gaff" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gaff" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gaff</a></span> or lateen on the <a href="#mizzenmast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mizzenmast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mizzenmast</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="polacca-settee" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">polacca-settee</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A three-masted <a href="#polacca"><span title="See entry on this page at § polacca" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">polacca</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="polacre" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">polacre</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Another name for a <a href="#polacca"><span title="See entry on this page at § polacca" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">polacca</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="polacre-xebec" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">polacre-xebec</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of <a href="#xebec"><span title="See entry on this page at § xebec" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">xebec</span></a> with a <a href="#square_rig"><span title="See entry on this page at § square rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square rig</span></a> on her <span title="See entry on this page at § foremast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#foremast" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">foremast</a></span>, <span title="See entry on this page at § lateen" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lateen" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lateen</a></span> sails on her other masts, a <span title="See entry on this page at § bowsprit" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bowsprit" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bowsprit</a></span>, and two <span title="See entry on this page at § headsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#headsail" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">headsails</a></span>. A polacre-xebec differed from a <span title="See entry on this page at § felucca" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#felucca" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">felucca</a></span> in that a felucca had only lateen sails.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pontoon" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Pontoon_(boat)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pontoon (boat)">pontoon</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A flat-bottomed vessel used as a <span title="See entry on this page at § ferry" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#ferry" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">ferry</a></span>, <span title="See entry on this page at § barge" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#barge" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">barge</a></span>, or <span title="See entry on this page at § car float" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#car_float" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">car float</a></span>, or a <span title="See entry on this page at § float" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#float" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">float</a></span> moored alongside a <span title="See entry on this page at § jetty" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#jetty" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">jetty</a></span> or a ship to facilitate boarding.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="poop_deck" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Poop_deck" title="Poop deck">poop deck</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A high <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> on the <span title="See entry on this page at § aft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aft</a></span> superstructure of a ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pooped" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pooped</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;(of a ship or boat) to have a wave break over the stern when travelling with a following sea.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMayne2000_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMayne2000-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;(colloquially) Exhausted.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMayne2000_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMayne2000-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="port" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Port_(nautical)" class="mw-redirect" title="Port (nautical)">port</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The left side of a ship or vessel. Towards the left-hand side of the ship facing forward (formerly <span title="See entry on this page at § larboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#larboard" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">larboard</a></span>). Denoted with a red light at night.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="port_of_registry" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Port_of_registry" class="mw-redirect" title="Port of registry">port of registry</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The port listed in a vessel<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s registration documents and lettered on her <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a>. Often used incorrectly as a synonym for <span title="See entry on this page at § home port" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#home_port" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">home port</a></span>, meaning the port at which the vessel is based, but it may differ from the port of registry.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="port_tack" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">port tack</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">When sailing with the wind coming from the <a href="#port"><span title="See entry on this page at § port" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">port</span></a> side of the vessel. Vessels on port tack must give way to those on <a href="#starboard_tack"><span title="See entry on this page at § starboard tack" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">starboard tack</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="porthole" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">porthole</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also simply <b>port</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">An opening in a ship's side, especially a round one for admitting light and air, fitted with thick glass and, often, a hinged metal cover, used as a window.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="portolan" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">portolan</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An obsolete form of nautical chart used prior to the development of lines of latitude and longitude that indicated distances and bearing lines between ports.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="post-captain" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">post-captain</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An obsolete alternative form of the rank of <span title="See entry on this page at § captain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#captain" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">captain</a></span> in the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a>; once achieved, promotion thereafter was entirely due to seniority.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="post_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Post_ship" title="Post ship">post ship</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The British term used from the second half of the 18th century until 1817 for a <a href="/wiki/Sixth_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Sixth rate">sixth rate</a> <span title="See entry on this page at § full-rigged ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#full-rigged_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">ship-rigged</a></span> sailing warship armed with 20 to 26 guns, smaller than a <span title="See entry on this page at § frigate" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#frigate" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">frigate</a></span> but large enough to require a <a href="#post-captain"><span title="See entry on this page at § post-captain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">post-captain</span></a> as her commanding officer.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="powder_hulk" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">powder hulk</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <span title="See entry on this page at § hulk" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hulk" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hulk</a></span> used to store <a href="/wiki/Gunpowder" title="Gunpowder">gunpowder</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="powder_magazine" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">powder magazine</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A small room/closet area in the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> of the ship used for storing <a href="/wiki/Gunpowder" title="Gunpowder">gunpowder</a> in barrels, or "kegs", usually located centrally so as to have easy access to the grated loading area. Sometimes may be an enclosed closet with a door, so it can be locked and only the captain would have the key, similar to how rum is stored.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pratique" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Pratique" title="Pratique">pratique</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The license given to a ship to enter port on assurance from her captain that she is free from contagious disease. A ship can signal a request for pratique by flying a square solid-yellow flag. The clearance granted is commonly referred to as <i>free pratique</i>. </dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="predreadnought" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Pre-dreadnought_battleship" title="Pre-dreadnought battleship">predreadnought</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A term used retrospectively after 1906 for a wide variety of steam <span title="See entry on this page at § battleship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#battleship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">battleships</a></span> built between the 1880s and c. 1905 designed with only a few large guns for long-range fire, relying on an intermediate secondary battery used at shorter ranges for most of their offensive power, and having <a href="/wiki/Triple-expansion_steam_engine" class="mw-redirect" title="Triple-expansion steam engine">triple-expansion steam engines</a>. They were rendered obsolete by the revolutionary <span title="See entry on this page at § dreadnought" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#dreadnought" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">dreadnought</a></span> battleships, which began to appear in 1906 and differed from predreadnoughts in having <a href="/wiki/Steam_turbine" title="Steam turbine">steam turbine</a> propulsion and an "all-big-gun" armament layout in which the ship<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s primary gun power resided in a primary battery of its largest guns intended for use at long range, with other gun armament limited to small weapons intended for close-range defense against <a href="/wiki/Torpedo_boat" title="Torpedo boat">torpedo boats</a> and other small warships.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="press_gang" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Impressment" title="Impressment">press gang</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Formed body of personnel from a ship of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> (either a ship seeking personnel for its own crew or from a "press tender" seeking men for a number of ships) that would identify and force ("press") men, usually merchant sailors, into service on naval ships, usually against their will.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="preventer" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">preventer</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>gybe preventer</b> and <b>jibe preventer</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A sail control <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">line</a></span> originating at some point on the <span title="See entry on this page at § boom" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#boom" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">boom</a></span> leading to a fixed point on the boat's <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> or <a href="#rail"><span title="See entry on this page at § rail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rail</span></a> (usually a <span title="See entry on this page at § cleat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cleat" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cleat</a></span> or <a href="#pad_eye"><span title="See entry on this page at § pad eye" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">pad eye</span></a>) used to prevent or moderate the effects of an accidental <span title="See entry on this page at § jibe" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#jibe" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">jibe</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="principal_naval_transport_officer" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Principal_Naval_Transport_Officer" class="mw-redirect" title="Principal Naval Transport Officer">Principal Naval Transport Officer</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">In British usage, a Principal Naval Transport Officer is a shore-based <span title="See entry on this page at § flag officer" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#flag_officer" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">flag officer</a></span> or <span title="See entry on this page at § captain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#captain" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">captain</a></span> responsible for sea transport duties, and for assisting the Senior Naval Officer in the preparation of naval orders and conducting <span title="See entry on this page at § disembarkation" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#disembarkation" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">disembarkations</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="principal_warfare_officer_(pwo)" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Principal_Warfare_Officer" class="mw-redirect" title="Principal Warfare Officer">Principal Warfare Officer</a> (PWO)</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">One of a number of Warfare branch specialist officers.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="prison_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Prison_ship" title="Prison ship">prison ship</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="prison_hulk"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>prison hulk</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel used as a prison, often to hold convicts awaiting transportation to penal colonies; particularly common in the British Empire in the 18th and 19th centuries.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="private_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Private_ship" title="Private ship">private ship</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">In British usage, a commissioned <a href="#warship"><span title="See entry on this page at § warship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">warship</span></a> in active service that is not being used as the <span title="See entry on this page at § flagship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#flagship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">flagship</a></span> of a <span title="See entry on this page at § flag officer" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#flag_officer" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">flag officer</a></span>. The term does not imply in any way that the ship is privately owned.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="privateer" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Privateer" title="Privateer">privateer</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>private man of war</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A privately owned ship authorised by a national power (by means of a <span title="See entry on this page at § letter of marque" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#letter_of_marque" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">letter of marque</a></span>) to conduct hostilities against an enemy.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="prize" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">prize</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A property captured at sea in virtue of the rights of war, as a vessel.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="prize_crew" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">prize crew</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Members of a warship<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s crew assigned to man a vessel taken as a prize.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="propeller" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">propeller</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;(fixed) A propeller mounted on a rigid shaft protruding from the hull of a vessel, usually driven by an inboard motor.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;(folding) A propeller with folding blades, furling to reduce drag on a sailing vessel when not in use.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="propeller_walk" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Propeller_walk" title="Propeller walk">propeller walk</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="prop_walk"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>prop walk</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The tendency for a <a href="#propeller"><span title="See entry on this page at § propeller" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">propeller</span></a> to push the <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a> sideways. In theory, a right-hand propeller in reverse will walk the stern to <a href="#port"><span title="See entry on this page at § port" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">port</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="prow" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Prow" class="mw-redirect" title="Prow">prow</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The forwardmost part of a vessel′s <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> above her <a href="#waterline"><span title="See entry on this page at § waterline" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">waterline</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;An alternative term for the <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> of a vessel, sometimes used poetically.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="puddening" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">puddening</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Fibres of old rope packed between <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spars</span></a> or used as a fender.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955112_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955112-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pulling" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">pulling</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">(of an oar, as used at sea) using an oar for propulsion of a boat where each person (of several) uses one oar. This contrasts with <a href="#row"><span title="See entry on this page at § row" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">row</span></a>ing (at sea), where each person uses two oars, one each side of the boat. See <a href="#row"><span title="See entry on this page at § row" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">row</span></a> for a full explanation of the complexities of the strict definitions.<sup id="cite_ref-McKee_1983_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McKee_1983-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 135">&#58;&#8202;135&#8202;</span></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="pump_boat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Pump_boat" title="Pump boat">pump boat</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An <a href="#outrigger_canoe"><span title="See entry on this page at § outrigger canoe" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">outrigger canoe</span></a> powered by a small <a href="/wiki/Gasoline_engine" class="mw-redirect" title="Gasoline engine">gasoline engine</a> or <a href="/wiki/Diesel_engine" title="Diesel engine">diesel engine</a>, used in the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> and by <a href="/wiki/Sama-Bajau" title="Sama-Bajau">Sama-Bajau</a> migrants and refugees in <a href="/wiki/Sabah" title="Sabah">Sabah</a> and eastern <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="punt" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Punt_(boat)" title="Punt (boat)">punt</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A flat-bottomed boat with a square-cut bow designed for use in small rivers or other shallow water and typically propelled by pushing against the riverbed with a pole. In this way it differs from a <span title="See entry on this page at § gondola" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gondola" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gondola</a></span>, which is propelled by an <a href="#oar"><span title="See entry on this page at § oar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">oar</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="punting" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">punting</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Boating in a <a href="#punt"><span title="See entry on this page at § punt" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">punt</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="purchase" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">purchase</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A mechanical method of increasing force, such as a <a href="#tackle"><span title="See entry on this page at § tackle" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tackle</span></a> or lever.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="purser" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Purser" title="Purser">purser</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The person who buys, stores, and sells all stores on board ships, including victuals, rum, and tobacco. Originally a private merchant, latterly a warrant officer.</dd>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1098327943"/>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Q">Q</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Q">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<dt class="glossary" id="quarter" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">quarter</dfn></dt> 
<dd class="glossary">Designation for the aft part of the ship between 120° and 180° to starboard, or 180° and 240° to port.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="quarterdeck" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Quarterdeck" title="Quarterdeck">quarterdeck</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The aftermost <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> of a <a href="#warship"><span title="See entry on this page at § warship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">warship</span></a>. During the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Sail" title="Age of Sail">Age of Sail</a>, the quarterdeck was the preserve of the ship's officers.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="quartering_sea" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Quartering_sea" class="mw-redirect" title="Quartering sea">quartering sea</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Seas approaching a vessel from between 105° and 165° to port or starboard. Aft of a <a href="/wiki/Beam_sea" class="mw-redirect" title="Beam sea">beam sea</a> and abeam of a <a href="/wiki/Following_sea" title="Following sea">following sea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Saunders_V3_1965_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Saunders_V3_1965-12">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> </dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="quartermaster" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Quartermaster" title="Quartermaster">quartermaster</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;In merchant marine usage, the seaman responsible for steering a ship. In naval usage, additional duties in running the ship's routine are included.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;US Navy enlisted rating (QM) who, in addition to the above duties, assists with the navigation of the ship.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="queen&#39;s_regulations" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Monarch" title="Monarch">Queen's</a> Regulations</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="King&#39;s_Regulations"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>King's Regulations</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The standing orders governing the British <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> issued in the name of the current <a href="/wiki/Monarch" title="Monarch">Monarch</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="quay" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">quay</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A stone or concrete structure on navigable water used for loading and unloading vessels, generally synonymous with a <a href="#wharf"><span title="See entry on this page at § wharf" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">wharf</span></a>, although the solid foundations of a quay contrast with the closely spaced piles of a wharf. When "quay" and "wharf" are used as synonyms, the term "quay" is more common in everyday speech in the United Kingdom, many <a href="/wiki/British_Commonwealth" class="mw-redirect" title="British Commonwealth">Commonwealth</a> countries, and the Republic of Ireland, while "wharf" is more commonly used in the United States.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;To land or tie up at a quay.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="quayside" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">quayside</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;An area alongside a <a href="#quay"><span title="See entry on this page at § quay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">quay</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Being alongside a quay, e.g. "The ship is moored quayside."</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="quickwork" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">quickwork</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="lining"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>lining</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The ceiling inside the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> above the turn of the <span title="See entry on this page at § bilge" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bilge" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bilge</a></span>, usually being of lighter dimensions than the ceiling lower down (spirketting).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESteffy2013_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESteffy2013-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="quoin" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Quoin_(gunnery)" class="mw-redirect" title="Quoin (gunnery)">quoin</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A wedge used to assist in the aiming of a cannon</dd>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1098327943"/>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="R">R</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: R">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<dt class="glossary" id="rabbet" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Rabbet" title="Rabbet">rabbet</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="rebate"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>rebate</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A groove cut in wood to form part of a joint.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="radar" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Radar" title="Radar">radar</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An electronic system designed to transmit radio signals and receive reflected images of those signals from a "target" in order to determine the bearing and distance to the target. The term is an acronym for <b>RA</b>dio <b>D</b>etection <b>A</b>nd <b>R</b>anging.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="radar_reflector" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">radar reflector</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A special fixture fitted to a vessel or incorporated into the design of certain <span title="See entry on this page at § aid to navigation" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aid_to_navigation" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aids to navigation</a></span> to enhance their ability to reflect <a href="#radar"><span title="See entry on this page at § radar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">radar</span></a> energy. In general, these fixtures materially improve the visibility for use by vessels with radar.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="raft" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Raft" title="Raft">raft</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A flat structure used for support or transportation over water, lacking a <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> and kept afloat by buoyant materials or structures such as wood, balsa, barrels, drums, inflated air chambers such as pontoons, or extruded polystyrene blocks.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="raft_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">raft ship</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Another name for a <span title="See entry on this page at § disposable ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#disposable_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">disposable ship</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rail_meat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rail meat</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A term used to describe the members of a sailboat crew that are using their body weight to control the angle of <span title="See entry on this page at § heel" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#heel" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">heel</a></span> of the boat.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rake" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rake</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To incline from the perpendicular; something so inclined is said to be <i>raked</i> or <i>raking</i> (e.g. a <a href="#stem"><span title="See entry on this page at § stem" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stem</span></a>, <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a>, <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a>, funnel, etc.).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ram" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Naval_ram" title="Naval ram">ram</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A weapon consisting of an underwater prolongation of the <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> of a vessel to form an armored beak, intended to be driven into the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> of an enemy vessel in order to puncture the hull and disable or sink that vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;An armored <a href="#warship"><span title="See entry on this page at § warship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">warship</span></a> of the second half of the 19th century designed to use such a weapon as her primary means of attack.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;To intentionally collide with another vessel with the intention of damaging or sinking her.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;To accidentally collide bow-first with another vessel.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="range" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">range</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;To lay out a rope or chain on deck in a zig-zag or (for rope) a figure‐eight pattern (as opposed to in a <span title="See entry on this page at § coil" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#coil" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">coil</a></span>) so that it can run freely. The zig-zag pattern may be described as <span title="See entry on this page at § flake" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#flake" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">flakes</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-PBO_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PBO-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_22-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The difference between the heights of the high and low <a href="/wiki/Tides" class="mw-redirect" title="Tides">tides</a> – a figure that will vary from place to place and day to day.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_22-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;The distance from an observer to a target, such as in gunnery.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_22-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="range_clock" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Range_clock" class="mw-redirect" title="Range clock">range clock</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A clockwork device used aboard a <a href="#warship"><span title="See entry on this page at § warship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">warship</span></a> to continuously calculate the distance or <a href="#range"><span title="See entry on this page at § range" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">range</span></a> to an enemy ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="range_lights" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Range_lights" class="mw-redirect" title="Range lights">range lights</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><span title="See entry on this page at § leading lights" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#leading_lights" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">leading lights</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rating" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Naval_rating" title="Naval rating">rating</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>rate</b> or <b>bluejacket</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;In British usage, a junior enlisted member of a country's <a href="#navy"><span title="See entry on this page at § navy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">navy</span></a>; i.e., any member of the navy who is not an officer or <a href="#warrant_officer"><span title="See entry on this page at § warrant officer" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">warrant officer</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;In contemporary <a href="/wiki/U.S._Navy" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Navy">U.S. Navy</a> and <a href="/wiki/U.S._Coast_Guard" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Coast Guard">U.S. Coast Guard</a> usage, rating is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_Navy_ratings" title="List of United States Navy ratings">occupational specialty</a> of an enlisted member of the service, <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_Navy_enlisted_rates" title="List of United States Navy enlisted rates">rate</a> denotes enlisted pay grade, and <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy_officer_rank_insignia" title="United States Navy officer rank insignia">rank</a> generally applies to commissioned officer pay grades.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;A <a href="/wiki/Rating_system_of_the_Royal_Navy" title="Rating system of the Royal Navy">classification system</a> of Royal Navy sailing warships.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ratlines" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Ratlines" title="Ratlines">ratlines</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>rattlins</b> or <b>ratlins</b>.</span></p>
