<dd class="glossary">The rungs fastened between the <a href="#shroud"><span title="See entry on this page at § shroud" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">shrouds</span></a> permanently rigged from <span title="See entry on this page at § bulwark" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bulwark" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bulwarks</a></span> and <a href="#top"><span title="See entry on this page at § top" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tops</span></a> to the <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> to form rope ladders enabling access to the <a href="#topmast"><span title="See entry on this page at § topmast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">topmasts</span></a> and <a href="#yard"><span title="See entry on this page at § yard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yards</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="razee" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Razee" title="Razee">razee</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A sailing ship that has been cut down to reduce the number of <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">decks</a></span>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;To cut down a sailing ship to reduce the number of decks.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="reach" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Reach_(geography)" title="Reach (geography)">reach</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A section of a stream or river along which similar hydrologic conditions exist, such as discharge, depth, area, and slope.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;In sailing usage, a straight section of water that can be traversed in a single <a href="#reaching"><span title="See entry on this page at § reaching" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">reaching</span></a> maneuver, without <a href="#tacking"><span title="See entry on this page at § tacking" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tacking</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="reaching" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Points_of_sail#reaching" class="mw-redirect" title="Points of sail">reaching</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Sailing across the wind; i.e. bearing anywhere between about 60° and 160° relative to the direction from which the wind is blowing. Reaching can be further subdivided into "close reaching" (about 60° to 80°), "beam reaching" (about 90°), and "broad reaching" (about 120° to 160°). Compare <i><span title="See entry on this page at § beating" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#beating" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">beating</a></span></i> and <i><a href="#running"><span title="See entry on this page at § running" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">running</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="reaching_sail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">reaching sail</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> specifically designed for tighter reaching legs. Reaching sails are often used in racing with a true wind angle of 35 to 95 degrees. They are generally used before the wind angle moves <span title="See entry on this page at § aft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aft</a></span> enough to permit <a href="#spinnaker"><span title="See entry on this page at § spinnaker" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spinnakers</span></a> to be flown.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ready_about" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ready about</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A call to indicate imminent <a href="#tacking"><span title="See entry on this page at § tacking" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tacking</span></a>. See also <i><span title="See entry on this page at § going about" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#going_about" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">going about</a></span></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="receiver_of_wreck" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Receiver_of_Wreck" title="Receiver of Wreck">Receiver of Wreck</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A government official whose duty is to give owners of <a href="#shipwreck"><span title="See entry on this page at § shipwreck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">shipwrecks</span></a> the opportunity to retrieve their property and ensure that law-abiding finders of wrecks receive an appropriate reward.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="receiving_hulk" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">receiving hulk</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="receiving_ship"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>receiving ship</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A <span title="See entry on this page at § hulk" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hulk" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hulk</a></span> used in harbor to house newly recruited sailors before they are assigned to a crew.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="red_duster" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">Red Duster</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A traditional nickname for the <a href="#red_Ensign"><span title="See entry on this page at § Red Ensign" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">Red Ensign</span></a>, the <span title="See entry on this page at § civil ensign" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#civil_ensign" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">civil ensign</a></span> flown by civilian vessels of the United Kingdom.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="red_ensign" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Red_Ensign" title="Red Ensign">Red Ensign</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>Red Duster</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A British flag flown as an <span title="See entry on this page at § ensign" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#ensign" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">ensign</a></span> by certain British ships. Since 1854, it has been flown by British <a href="#merchant_ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § merchant ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">merchant ships</span></a> (except for those authorized to fly the <span title="See entry on this page at § Blue Ensign" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#Blue_Ensign" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">Blue Ensign</a></span>) as the United Kingdom′s <span title="See entry on this page at § civil ensign" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#civil_ensign" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">civil ensign</a></span>. Prior to 1864, ships of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a>′s Red Squadron also flew it, but its naval use ended with the reorganisation of the Royal Navy in 1864.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="red_right_return" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Red_Right_Return" class="mw-redirect" title="Red Right Return">Red Right Return</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A phrase used as a mnemonic to remember that the navigational standard for a vessel entering ("returning to") a port in the Americas (excluding <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a>), Japan, South Korea, and the Philippines is for her to steer so that red-marked <span title="See entry on this page at § aids to navigation" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aids_to_navigation" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">navigational aids</a></span> lie to <a href="#starboard"><span title="See entry on this page at § starboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">starboard</span></a> (to the "right") of an observer facing <span title="See entry on this page at § forward" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#forward" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">forward</a></span> on the vessel, while green-marked aids must lie to <a href="#port"><span title="See entry on this page at § port" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">port</span></a> (i.e. to the "left"). This contrasts with the rest of the world, where the standard is the opposite, i.e. green markers must lie to starboard and red ones to port.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="red-to-red" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">red-to-red</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A passage of two vessels moving in the opposite direction on their <a href="#port"><span title="See entry on this page at § port" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">port</span></a> sides, so called because the red navigation light on one of the vessels faces the red light on the other vessel.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="reduced_cat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">reduced cat</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>boys' pussy</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A light version of the <span title="See entry on this page at § cat o&#39;nine tails" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cat_o&#39;nine_tails" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cat o'nine tails</a></span> for use on young sailors.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="reef" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">reef</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Reef" title="Reef">noun</a>) Rock or coral that is either partially submerged or fully submerged but shallow enough that a vessel with a sufficient <span title="See entry on this page at § draft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#draft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">draft</a></span> may touch or run <span title="See entry on this page at § aground" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aground" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aground</a></span>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Reefing" title="Reefing">verb</a>) To temporarily reduce the area of a <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> exposed to the wind, usually to guard against adverse effects of strong wind or to slow the vessel.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="reef-points" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">reef-points</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Lengths of rope attached to a <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> and used to tie up the part of a sail that is taken out of use when <a href="#reef"><span title="See entry on this page at § reef" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">reefed</span></a>. In older systems, such as <a href="#square_rig"><span title="See entry on this page at § square rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square</span></a> or <span title="See entry on this page at § gaff rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gaff_rig" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gaff rigs</a></span>, the reef points take some of the load on the sail and distribute it to the <span title="See entry on this page at § boltrope" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#boltrope" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">boltrope</a></span>; with slab reefing, the reef-points just keep the sail fabric controlled in a tidy manner. Reef points may either be sewn to each side of the sail or passed through eyelets.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMayne2000_19-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMayne2000-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PBO_10-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PBO-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECunliffe2016125_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECunliffe2016125-25">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="reef-bands" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">reef-bands</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Long pieces of rough canvas sewn across the sails to give them additional strength.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="reef-tackles" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">reef-tackles</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Ropes employed in the operation of reefing.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199024_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199024-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="reefer_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Reefer_ship" title="Reefer ship">reefer ship</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also simply <b>reefer</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A refrigerated cargo ship used to carry perishable goods that require refrigeration.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A shipboard refrigerator.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="reeve" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">reeve</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To thread a <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">line</a></span> through <span title="See entry on this page at § block" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#block" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">blocks</a></span> in order to gain a mechanical advantage, such as in a <span title="See entry on this page at § block and tackle" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#block_and_tackle" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">block and tackle</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199024_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199024-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="regatta" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Regatta" class="mw-redirect" title="Regatta">regatta</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A series of boat races, usually of sailboats or rowboats but occasionally of powered boats.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="regular_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">regular ship</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A term used by the British <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">East India Company</a> from the 17th to the 19th centuries for merchant ships that made "regular voyages" for the company between England (later the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">United Kingdom</a>) and ports east of the <a href="/wiki/Cape_of_Good_Hope" title="Cape of Good Hope">Cape of Good Hope</a>, a trade over which the company held a strict monopoly. The company <span title="See entry on this page at § charter" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#charter" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">chartered</a></span> most of its ships; "regular ships" were those under long-term charter, and the company kept their operations under tight control. A set of "regular ships" set off for Asian ports during each sailing season (September through April), and returned up to two years later. The status and role of "regular ships" differed from that of ships the company referred to as <span title="See entry on this page at § chartered ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#chartered_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">chartered ships</a></span>, <span title="See entry on this page at § country ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#country_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">country ships</a></span>, <span title="See entry on this page at § extra ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#extra_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">extra ships</a></span>, and <span title="See entry on this page at § licensed ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#licensed_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">licensed ships</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-threedecksshiproles_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-threedecksshiproles-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="relative_bearing" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Relative_bearing" class="mw-redirect" title="Relative bearing">relative bearing</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <span title="See entry on this page at § bearing" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bearing" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bearing</a></span> relative to the direction in which the vessel is pointing or traveling; the angle between the vessel's forward direction and an object, as measured clockwise from the <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span>. See also <i><span title="See entry on this page at § absolute bearing" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#absolute_bearing" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">absolute bearing</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="repair_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Repair_ship" title="Repair ship">repair ship</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A naval <span title="See entry on this page at § auxiliary ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#auxiliary_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">auxiliary ship</a></span> designed to provide maintenance support to other ships.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="replenishment_oiler" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Replenishment_oiler" title="Replenishment oiler">replenishment oiler</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A naval <span title="See entry on this page at § auxiliary ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#auxiliary_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">auxiliary ship</a></span> which provides fuel and dry stores to other ships.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="research_vessel" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Research_vessel" title="Research vessel">research vessel</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A ship designed and equipped to carry out research at sea, especially <a href="/wiki/Hydrographic_survey" title="Hydrographic survey">hydrographic surveys</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oceanography" title="Oceanography">oceanographic</a> research, <a href="/wiki/Fisheries_science" title="Fisheries science">fisheries research</a>, <a href="/wiki/Navy" title="Navy">naval</a> research, <a href="/wiki/Polar_region" class="mw-redirect" title="Polar region">polar</a> research, and <a href="/wiki/Oil_exploration" class="mw-redirect" title="Oil exploration">oil exploration</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="reserve_fleet" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Reserve_fleet" title="Reserve fleet">reserve fleet</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A collection of naval vessels fully equipped for service but partially or fully decommissioned because they are not currently needed. In the modern United States, a reserve fleet is sometimes informally called a <i>ghost fleet</i>. During the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Sail" title="Age of Sail">Age of Sail</a> and well into the 19th century, ships in a reserve fleet were said to be <i><span title="See entry on this page at § in ordinary" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#in_ordinary" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">in ordinary</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rib_tickler" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rib tickler</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A bargeman's name for the <a href="#tiller"><span title="See entry on this page at § tiller" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tiller</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="riding_light" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">riding light</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A light hung from the <span title="See entry on this page at § forestay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#forestay" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">forestay</a></span> when at <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rigging" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Rigging" title="Rigging">rigging</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The system of <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">masts</span></a> and <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lines</a></span> on ships and other sailing vessels.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199024_26-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199024-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rigging_chocks" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rigging chocks</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Thick blocks of wood fixed outside the <a href="#rail"><span title="See entry on this page at § rail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rails</span></a> to take the chain plates for the <a href="#shroud"><span title="See entry on this page at § shroud" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">shrouds</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rigging_screw" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rigging screw</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A bottle screw used to keep wires taut.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="righting_couple" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">righting couple</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The force that tends to restore a ship to equilibrium once a <span title="See entry on this page at § heel" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#heel" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">heel</a></span> has altered the relationship between her <span title="See entry on this page at § center of buoyancy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#center_of_buoyancy" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">center of buoyancy</a></span> and her <a href="/wiki/Center_of_gravity" class="mw-redirect" title="Center of gravity">center of gravity</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rigol" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rigol</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The rim or "eyebrow" above a <a href="#porthole"><span title="See entry on this page at § porthole" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">porthole</span></a> or <a href="#scuttle"><span title="See entry on this page at § scuttle" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">scuttle</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rip_rap" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rip rap</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A man-made pile of rocks and rubble used as a base to support an <span title="See entry on this page at § aid to navigation" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aid_to_navigation" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aid to navigation</a></span>, often an offshore <span title="See entry on this page at § lighthouse" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lighthouse" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lighthouse</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ro-ro" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ro-ro</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#roll-on/roll-off_ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § roll-on/roll-off ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">roll-on/roll-off ship</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="roads" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">roads</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#roadstead"><span title="See entry on this page at § roadstead" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">roadstead</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="roadstead" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Roadstead" title="Roadstead">roadstead</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>roads</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A sheltered area outside a harbour where a ship can lie safe at anchor.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="roaring_forties" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Roaring_Forties" title="Roaring Forties">Roaring Forties</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An area of persistent strong westerly winds found in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a>, generally between the latitudes of <a href="/wiki/40th_parallel_south" title="40th parallel south">40</a> and <a href="/wiki/50th_parallel_south" title="50th parallel south">50</a> degrees south. During the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Sail" title="Age of Sail">Age of Sail</a>, ships took advantage of the Roaring Forties to speed their trips, and <a href="/wiki/Yacht" title="Yacht">yacht</a> sailors still do today.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rode" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rode</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>anchor rode</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The anchor <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">line</a></span>, rope, or <span title="See entry on this page at § cable" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cable" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cable</a></span> connecting the <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor chain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor_chain" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor chain</a></span> to the vessel.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rogue_wave" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Rogue_wave" title="Rogue wave">rogue wave</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Any unusually large wave for a given <a href="#sea_state"><span title="See entry on this page at § sea state" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sea state</span></a>; formally, a wave whose height is more than twice the <a href="/wiki/Significant_wave_height" title="Significant wave height">significant wave height</a> of that sea state (i.e. the mean of the largest third of waves in a wave record).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="roll" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Ship_motions" title="Ship motions">roll</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The side-to-side motion of a vessel as it rotates about the <span title="See entry on this page at § fore" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#fore" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">fore</a></span>-<span title="See entry on this page at § aft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aft</a></span> (longitudinal) axis. <span title="See entry on this page at § list" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#list" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">Listing</a></span> is a lasting, stable tilt, or <span title="See entry on this page at § heel" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#heel" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">heel</a></span>, along this longitudinal axis.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Another name for the longitudinal axis itself (e.g. the "roll axis").</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="roll-on/roll-off_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Roll-on/roll-off" title="Roll-on/roll-off">roll-on/roll-off ship</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="RORO"></span><span class="anchor" id="ro-ro"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>RORO</b> or <b>ro-ro</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel designed to carry wheeled cargo that can drive on and off the ship on its own wheels.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rolling-tackle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rolling-tackle</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A number of pulleys, engaged to confine the <a href="#yard"><span title="See entry on this page at § yard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yard</span></a> to the <a href="#weather_side"><span title="See entry on this page at § weather side" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">weather side</span></a> of a <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a>; this tackle is much used in a rough sea.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199025_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199025-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rolling_vang" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rolling vang</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A second set of sprit-head <a href="#vang"><span title="See entry on this page at § vang" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">vangs</span></a> played out forward to rail near the <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bows</a></span>, used to give additional control and support when needed in a <a href="#seaway"><span title="See entry on this page at § seaway" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">seaway</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="romper" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">romper</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">In a <span title="See entry on this page at § convoy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#convoy" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">convoy</a></span>, a ship that breaks ranks and "romps" ahead out of formation with the other ships.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ropes,_the" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ropes, the</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;All <span title="See entry on this page at § cordage" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cordage" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cordage</a></span>; the <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lines</a></span> in the <a href="#rigging"><span title="See entry on this page at § rigging" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rigging</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Any cordage of over 1 inch (2.5&#160;cm) in diameter.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199025_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199025-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rope&#39;s_end" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Rope%27s_end" class="mw-redirect" title="Rope&#39;s end">rope's end</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A summary punishment device used as a <a href="/wiki/Flogging" class="mw-redirect" title="Flogging">flog</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rope_yarn" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rope yarn</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A period, traditionally on Wednesday afternoons, when a tailor boarded a sailing warship while the vessel was in port; the <span title="See entry on this page at § crew" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#crew" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">crew</a></span> was excused from most duties and had light duty mending uniforms and hammocks and darning socks. When the ship was at sea, the crew similarly was excused from most duties on Wednesday afternoons to engage in mending chores. Wednesday afternoons, like Sundays, thus were a more social time when crewmen rested from normal duties, similar to a Sunday, and, because the crew used rope yarn for mending, Wednesday afternoon became known as <i>rope yarn Sunday</i>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;After uniforms began to require less care, and through the mid-20th century, a period on Wednesday afternoons when naval crew members were excused from their regular duties to run personal errands.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;Since the mid-20th century, any period of free time when a naval crew is given early <span title="See entry on this page at § liberty" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#liberty" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">liberty</a></span> or otherwise excused from its normally scheduled duties.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;One of the threads in a rope.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199025_27-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199025-27">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="round_to" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">round to</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To turn the <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> of a vessel into the wind.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rove" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rove</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Past tense of <a href="#reeve"><span title="See entry on this page at § reeve" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">reeve</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199024_26-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199024-26">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="row" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">row</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;(in general speech) to propel a boat with <a href="#oar"><span title="See entry on this page at § oar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">oar</span></a>s</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;(more precisely, as used at sea) to propel a boat with oars, where each rower handles two oars, one on each side of the boat. This contrasts with the inland waters definition. When, at sea, a person is working just one oar, this is termed <a href="#pulling"><span title="See entry on this page at § pulling" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">pulling</span></a><sup id="cite_ref-McKee_1983_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McKee_1983-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 135">&#58;&#8202;135&#8202;</span></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;(more precisely, as used at in inland waters) to propel a boat with oars, where each rower uses just one oar. On inland waters, one person using two oars, one on each side of the boat, is termed <a href="#sculling"><span title="See entry on this page at § sculling" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sculling</span></a><sup id="cite_ref-McKee_1983_21-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McKee_1983-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 135">&#58;&#8202;135&#8202;</span></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rowlock" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Rowlock" title="Rowlock">rowlock</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The cutout in the <a href="#washstrake"><span title="See entry on this page at § washstrake" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">washstrake</span></a> of a boat into which an oar is placed, so providing a fulcrum when the oar is in use.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975205_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975205-28">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A common term for an <a href="#oar_crutch"><span title="See entry on this page at § oar crutch" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">oar crutch</span></a>, the u-shaped metal fitting, with a pin underneath that fits in a socket in the <span title="See entry on this page at § gunwale" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gunwale" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gunwale</a></span> of a boat to provide the fulcrum for an <a href="#oar"><span title="See entry on this page at § oar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">oar</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-PBO_10-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PBO-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> See also <i><a href="#thole_pin"><span title="See entry on this page at § thole pin" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">thole pin</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="royal" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">royal</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;On large sailing ships, a <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> right above the <a href="#topgallant"><span title="See entry on this page at § topgallant" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">topgallant</span></a> mast.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> of such a mast.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rubbing_strake" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rubbing strake</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An extra plank fitted to the outside of the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span>, usually at deck level, to protect the <a href="#topsides"><span title="See entry on this page at § topsides" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">topsides</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rudder" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Rudder" title="Rudder">rudder</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A steering device that is placed <span title="See entry on this page at § aft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aft</a></span> and pivoted about a (usually vertical) axis to generate a <a href="#yaw"><span title="See entry on this page at § yaw" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yawing</span></a> moment from the hydrodynamic forces that act on the rudder blade when it is angled to the flow of water over it. There are several types of rudder, which generally divide into outboard or inboard. An outboard rudder is hung (hinged) on the <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a> of the vessel. An inboard rudder has a <a href="#rudderstock"><span title="See entry on this page at § rudderstock" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stock</span></a> which passes through a gland in the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span>, with the structure of the hull continuing towards the stern above the rudder. A spade rudder is hinged solely on the stock and has no lower bearing to help take the loads. Other rudder types may be hinged on an extension of the <span title="See entry on this page at § keel" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#keel" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">keel</a></span> or on a <a href="#skeg"><span title="See entry on this page at § skeg" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">skeg</span></a>. Rudders may be balanced, by having some of the blade extend in front of the stock. On simple watercraft, the rudder may be controlled by a <a href="#tiller"><span title="See entry on this page at § tiller" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tiller</span></a>—essentially, a stick or pole attached to the top of the rudder to allow it to be turned by a helmsman. In larger vessels, the rudder is often linked to a <a href="#wheel"><span title="See entry on this page at § wheel" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">steering wheel</span></a> via cables, pushrods, or hydraulics.</dd>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Adler_von_L%C3%BCbeck._Model_ship_05.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Adler_von_L%C3%BCbeck._Model_ship_05.jpg/220px-Adler_von_L%C3%BCbeck._Model_ship_05.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="238" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Adler_von_L%C3%BCbeck._Model_ship_05.jpg/330px-Adler_von_L%C3%BCbeck._Model_ship_05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Adler_von_L%C3%BCbeck._Model_ship_05.jpg/440px-Adler_von_L%C3%BCbeck._Model_ship_05.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1947" data-file-height="2108" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Adler_von_L%C3%BCbeck._Model_ship_05.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Model of a <a href="#sternpost"><span title="See entry on this page at § sternpost" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sternpost</span></a>-mounted pintle-and-gudgeon <b><a href="#rudder"><span title="See entry on this page at § rudder" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rudder</span></a></b></div></div></div>
<dt class="glossary" id="rudder_stop" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rudder stop</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A fitting that limits the swing of the rudder.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rudderstock" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rudderstock</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The structural part of a <a href="#rudder"><span title="See entry on this page at § rudder" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rudder</span></a> that transmits the torque created by the <a href="#tiller"><span title="See entry on this page at § tiller" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tiller</span></a> or steering gear to the rudder blade. It may consist of a steel tube which passes through bearings in the hull above the rudder, or with a stern-hung rudder, is the structure carrying all or some of the pintles or gudgeons on which the rudder pivots.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ruffle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ruffle</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A serrated iron ring attached to the barrel of the <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor</a></span> <a href="#winch"><span title="See entry on this page at § winch" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">winch</span></a> and to which the <a href="#pawl"><span title="See entry on this page at § pawl" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">pawl</span></a> is applied to prevent backruns of the <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor chain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor_chain" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor chain</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rum-runner" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rum-runner</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><span title="See entry on this page at § go-fast boat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#go-fast_boat" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">go-fast boat</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rummage" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rummage</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>romage</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A place or room for the <a href="#stowage"><span title="See entry on this page at § stowage" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stowage</span></a> of cargo in a vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The act of stowing cargo aboard a vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;To arrange (cargo, goods, etc.) in the <span title="See entry on this page at § hold" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hold" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hold</a></span> of a vessel; to move or rearrange such goods; the pulling and moving about of packages incident to close stowage aboard a vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;To search a vessel for smuggled goods, e.g. "The customs officers rummaged the ship."</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="rummage_sale" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">rummage sale</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A sale of damaged cargo (from French <i>arrimage</i>).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="run" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">run</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a> of the underwater body of a ship from where it begins to curve upward and inward.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A voyage, particularly a brief or routine one.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="running_before_the_wind" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Points_of_sail" class="mw-redirect" title="Points of sail">running before the wind</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="running"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also simply <b>running</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">Sailing more than about 160° away from the direction from which the wind is blowing (i.e. moving in the same or nearly the same direction as the wind). If moving directly away from the wind, it is called a <span title="See entry on this page at § dead run" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#dead_run" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">dead run</a></span>. Compare <i><a href="#reaching"><span title="See entry on this page at § reaching" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">reaching</span></a></i> and <i><span title="See entry on this page at § beating" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#beating" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">beating</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="running_backstays" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">running backstays</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <span title="See entry on this page at § backstay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#backstay" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">backstay</a></span> that can be released and moved out of the way so that it does not interfere with <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sails</span></a> or <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spars</span></a> on the <span title="See entry on this page at § lee side" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lee_side" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">leeward side</a></span>. On <a href="#tacking"><span title="See entry on this page at § tacking" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tacking</span></a>, the new windward running backstay must be set up promptly to support the mast.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="running_gear" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">running gear</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The propellers, shafts, struts, and related parts of a <a href="/wiki/Motorboat" title="Motorboat">motorboat</a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The <a href="#running_rigging"><span title="See entry on this page at § running rigging" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">running rigging</span></a> of a sailing vessel.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="running_rigging" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Running_rigging" title="Running rigging">running rigging</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary"><p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>running gear</b>.</span></p><a href="#rigging"><span title="See entry on this page at § rigging" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">Rigging</span></a> used to manipulate <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sails</span></a>, <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spars</span></a>, etc. in order to control the movement of a sailing vessel. Contrast <i><a href="#standing_rigging"><span title="See entry on this page at § standing rigging" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">standing rigging</span></a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199026_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199026-29">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1098327943"/>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="S">S</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: S">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<dt class="glossary" id="safe_harbour" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">safe harbour</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#harbour" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § harbour" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">harbour</span></a></dfn> that provides safety from bad weather or attack.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="safe_haven" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">safe haven</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#safe_harbour"><span title="See entry on this page at § safe harbour" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">safe harbour</span></a>, including natural harbours, which provide safety from bad weather or attack.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="safety_briefing" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">safety briefing</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#muster_drill" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § muster drill" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">muster drill</span></a></dfn></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="saddle_chock" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">saddle chock</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A transverse beam placed over the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#transom" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § transom" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">transom</span></a></dfn> with <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#fairlead" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § fairlead" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">fairleads</span></a></dfn> for mooring warps.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sagging" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Hogging_and_sagging" title="Hogging and sagging">sagging</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A condition in which the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hull</span></a></dfn> of a vessel deflects downward so the ends of the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#keel" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § keel" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">keel</span></a></dfn> are higher than the middle. The opposite of <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hogging" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hogging" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hogging</span></a></dfn>. Sagging can occur when the trough of a wave is <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#amidships" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § amidships" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">amidships</span></a></dfn> or during loading or unloading of a vessel and can damage her or even break her in half.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sail" title="Sail">sail</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A piece of fabric attached to a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#vessel" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § vessel" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">vessel</span></a></dfn> and arranged such that it causes the wind to drive the vessel along. Sails are typically attached to the vessel via a combination of <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn>, <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spars</span></a>, and <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rope" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rope" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">ropes</span></a></dfn>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The power harnessed by a sail or sails to propel a vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;To use sail power to propel a vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;A trip in a boat or ship, especially a sailboat or sailing ship.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">5.&#160;&#160;In American usage, a <a href="/wiki/Sail_(submarine)" title="Sail (submarine)">sail</a> is a tower-like structure on the dorsal (topside) surface of submarines constructed since the mid-20th century—similar in appearance to a fabric sail or fin, and originally containing instruments and controls for the periscopes to direct the submarine and launch <a href="/wiki/Torpedo" title="Torpedo">torpedo</a> attacks. Modern sails or fins do not perform these functions.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sail_drive" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sail drive</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Non-steerable drive leg fitted through the bottom of a sailboat carrying a propeller. Compare with <span title="See entry on this page at § azimuth thruster" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#azimuth_thruster" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">azimuth thruster</a></span> and <a href="#sterndrive"><span title="See entry on this page at § sterndrive" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sterndrive</span></a></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sail_loft" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sail_loft" class="mw-redirect" title="Sail loft">sail loft</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A large open space used by <a href="#sailmaker"><span title="See entry on this page at § sailmaker" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sailmakers</span></a> to spread out <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sails</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sail-plan" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sail-plan" class="mw-redirect" title="Sail-plan">sail-plan</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A set of drawings showing various sail combinations recommended for use in various situations.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sailing_skiff" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sailing skiff</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#skiff"><span title="See entry on this page at § skiff" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">skiff</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sailmaker" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sailmaker" title="Sailmaker">sailmaker</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A craftsman who makes and repairs <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sails</span></a>, working either on shore in a <a href="#sail_loft"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail loft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail loft</span></a> or aboard a large, oceangoing sailing ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sailorman" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sailorman</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">London term for a sailing <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barge</span></a></dfn>, or a bargeman.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sally_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sally ship</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A method of freeing a vessel <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#grounded" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § grounded" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">grounded</span></a></dfn> on mud, in which the crew forms a line and runs back and forth <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#athwartships" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § athwartships" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">athwartships</span></a></dfn> to cause her to rock back and forth, breaking the mud<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s suction and freeing her with little or no damage to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hull</span></a></dfn>. When this is required, the crew is given the order "Sally ship!"</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="saloon" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">saloon</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A social lounge on a passenger ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="saltie" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">saltie</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Great Lakes term for a vessel that sails the oceans.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="salty_dog" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">salty dog</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Slang for a <a href="#sailor"><span title="See entry on this page at § sailor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sailor</span></a>, especially for a <a href="#seaman"><span title="See entry on this page at § seaman" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">seaman</span></a> in the navy.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="salvage_tug" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Salvage_tug" title="Salvage tug">salvage tug</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Sometimes called a <b>wrecking tug</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A specialized <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#tugboat" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § tugboat" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">tugboat</span></a></dfn> used to assist ships in distress or in danger of sinking, or to salvage ships which have already sunk or run aground.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="salvor" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">salvor</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A person engaged in the salvage of a ship or items lost at sea.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sampan" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sampan" title="Sampan">sampan</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A relatively flat-bottomed Chinese wooden boat from 3.5 to 4.5 metres (11 to 15&#160;ft) long, generally used in coastal areas or rivers and as traditional fishing boats. Some have a small shelter, and they may be used as a permanent habitation on inland waters. It is unusual for sampans to sail far from land as they are not designed to survive rough weather.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sampson_post" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sampson post</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A strong vertical post used to fasten the anchor cable or mooring warps, for towing another vessel, or to support a ship's <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#windlass" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § windlass" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">windlass</span></a></dfn>, the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#heel" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § heel" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">heel</span></a></dfn> of a ship's <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bowsprit" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bowsprit" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bowsprit</span></a></dfn>, the base of a cargo derrick or any other heavy load. In a smaller vessel, is usually fastened to the keel at its lower end.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMayne2000_19-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMayne2000-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PBO_10-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PBO-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sandsucker" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sandsucker</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barge</span></a></dfn> that collects sand from the bottom of lakes.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="s.b._(or_sb)" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">S.B. (or SB)</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="SB"></span>
<dd class="glossary">Prefix for "<a href="/wiki/Thames_sailing_barge" title="Thames sailing barge">Sailing Barge</a>", used before a ship<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s name.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="scandalize" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">scandalize</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To reduce the area and efficiency of a <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> by expedient means (slacking the peak and tricing up the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#tack" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § tack" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">tack</span></a></dfn>) without properly <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#reefing" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § reefing" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">reefing</span></a></dfn>, thus slowing boat speed. Also used in the past as a sign of mourning.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="scantlings" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Scantling" title="Scantling">scantlings</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Dimensions of a ship's structural members, e.g. <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#frame" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § frame" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">frame</span></a></dfn>, <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#beam" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § beam" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">beam</span></a></dfn>, <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#girder" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § girder" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">girder</span></a></dfn>, etc.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="schooner" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Schooner" title="Schooner">schooner</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of sailing vessel characterized by the use of <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#fore-and-aft_rig" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § fore-and-aft rig" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">fore-and-aft</span></a></dfn> sails on two or more <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">masts</span></a></dfn> with the forward mast being no taller than the rear masts. First used by the Dutch in the 16th or 17th century. A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#topsail_schooner" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § topsail schooner" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">topsail schooner</span></a></dfn> has a square topsail (and may also have a topgallant) on the foremast.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="schooner_barge" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Schooner_barge" title="Schooner barge">schooner barge</a></dfn></dt>
