<dd class="glossary">A type of <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barge</span></a></dfn> either converted from a <a href="#schooner"><span title="See entry on this page at § schooner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">schooner</span></a> or purpose-built as a barge with a schooner <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rigging" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rigging" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rig</span></a></dfn>, primarily in use from the 1860s to the 1940s, initially on the <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a> and later in salt-water environments as well. A schooner barge required a smaller crew than a schooner and needed to be towed, but under favorable conditions could hoist <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a>s to reduce fuel consumption by the vessel towing her.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKaramanski200035–41_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKaramanski200035–41-31">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="schuyt" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">schuyt</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Another name for a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#dutch_barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § Dutch barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">Dutch barge</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="scope" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">scope</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The length of cable extended when a ship rides at anchor.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="scow" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Scow" title="Scow">scow</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A method of preparing an <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#anchor" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § anchor" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">anchor</span></a></dfn> for tripping by attaching an <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#anchor_cable" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § anchor cable" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">anchor cable</span></a></dfn> to the crown and fixing to the ring by a light <a href="#seizing"><span title="See entry on this page at § seizing" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">seizing</span></a> (also known as <i>becue</i>). The seizing can be broken if the anchor becomes fouled.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A type of clinker <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#dinghy" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § dinghy" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">dinghy</span></a></dfn>, characteristically beamy and slow.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;An inland racing boat with no <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#keel" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § keel" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">keel</span></a></dfn>, a large sail plan, and a planing hull.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="scow_schooner" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">scow schooner</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel with a <a href="#scow"><span title="See entry on this page at § scow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">scow</span></a>-like (def. 2) <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hull</span></a></dfn> and a <a href="#schooner"><span title="See entry on this page at § schooner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">schooner</span></a> rig. Scow schooners appeared on the <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a> during the 1820s and served there into the 20th century, and also were common on <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay" title="San Francisco Bay">San Francisco Bay</a> and in <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-scowschooner_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scowschooner-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="scow_sloop" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">scow sloop</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel with a <a href="#scow"><span title="See entry on this page at § scow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">scow</span></a>-like (def. 2) <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hull</span></a></dfn> and a <a href="#sloop"><span title="See entry on this page at § sloop" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sloop</span></a> rig. Scow sloops were common in <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a> by 1725.<sup id="cite_ref-scowschooner_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scowschooner-32">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="screaming_sixties" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Screaming_Sixties" class="mw-redirect" title="Screaming Sixties">Screaming Sixties</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also called the <b>Shrieking Sixties</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">Strong westerly winds found in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a>, south of <a href="/wiki/60th_parallel_south" title="60th parallel south">60 degrees</a>. They are stronger than the similar "<a href="/wiki/Roaring_Forties" title="Roaring Forties">Roaring Forties</a>" to their north.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="screecher" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Screecher" title="Screecher">screecher</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A specialty sail which can be used as an upwind <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#genoa" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § genoa" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">genoa sail</span></a></dfn>, <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#reaching" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § reaching" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">reaching</span></a></dfn> sail, or downwind sail. The name comes from combining "<a href="#spinnaker"><span title="See entry on this page at § spinnaker" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spinnaker</span></a>" and "reaching".</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="screw" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">screw</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#propeller" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § propeller" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">propeller</span></a></dfn>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Propeller-driven (e.g. a <a href="/wiki/Screw_frigate" class="mw-redirect" title="Screw frigate">screw frigate</a> or <a href="/wiki/Screw_sloop" title="Screw sloop">screw sloop</a>).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="scud" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">scud</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A name given by sailors to the lowest clouds, which are mostly observed in squally weather.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="scudding" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">scudding</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A term applied to a vessel when carried furiously along by a tempest.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="scull" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Scull" class="mw-redirect" title="Scull">scull</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;(verb) In sport or recreational rowing, especially on inland water, to propel a boat by oars, where each of one or several persons uses two oars, one on each side of the boat. This contrasts with the maritime traditional working boat or naval usage, where this activity is called <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#row" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § row" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">row</span></a></dfn>ing<sup id="cite_ref-McKee_1983_21-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McKee_1983-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 135">&#58;&#8202;135&#8202;</span></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;(verb) To propel a boat with a single oar resting in a notch at the stern, using a figure of eight motion of the blade of the oar, which is continuously immersed in the water</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;(noun) An <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#oar" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § oar" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">oar</span></a></dfn> used for sculling</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;(noun) A boat propelled by sculling, generally for recreation or racing</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="scuppers" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">scuppers</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Originally a series of pipes fitted through a ship's side from inside the thicker deck waterway to the topside planking in order to drain water overboard, with larger quantities drained through freeing ports, which were openings in the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bulwark" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bulwark" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bulwarks</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="scuttle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">scuttle</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A small opening, or lid thereof, in a ship's <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#deck" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § deck" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">deck</span></a></dfn> or <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hull</span></a></dfn>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;To sink a vessel deliberately.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="scuttlebutt" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">scuttlebutt</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A barrel with a hole in it, used to hold water that sailors would drink from. By extension (in modern naval usage), a shipboard drinking fountain or water cooler.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Slang for <a href="/wiki/Gossip" title="Gossip">gossip</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="scuttling" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Scuttling" title="Scuttling">scuttling</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Making a hole in the hull of a vessel or opening <a href="#seacock"><span title="See entry on this page at § seacock" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">seacocks</span></a>, especially in order to sink a vessel deliberately.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sea_anchor" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sea_anchor" title="Sea anchor">sea anchor</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A stabilizer deployed in the water for <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#heaving_to" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § heaving to" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">heaving to</span></a></dfn> in heavy weather. It acts as a brake and keeps the hull in line with the wind and perpendicular to the waves. Often in the form of a large bag made of heavy canvas. See also <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#drogue" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § drogue" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">drogue</span></a></dfn></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sea_chest" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sea chest</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A watertight box built against the hull of the ship communicating with the sea through a grillage, to which valves and piping are attached to allow water in for ballast, engine cooling, and firefighting purposes. Also, a wooden box used to store a sailor's effects.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sea_shanty/chanty/chantey" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sea_shanty" title="Sea shanty">sea shanty</a>/chanty/chantey</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Work song to accompany rhythmical labor.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sea_state" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sea_state" title="Sea state">sea state</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The general condition of the free surface on a large body of water with respect to wind waves and swell at a certain location and moment, characterized by statistics, including the <a href="/wiki/Wave_height" title="Wave height">wave height</a>, <a href="/wiki/Period_(physics)" class="mw-redirect" title="Period (physics)">period</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Power_spectrum" class="mw-redirect" title="Power spectrum">power spectrum</a>. The sea state varies with time, as the wind conditions or swell conditions change.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sea_trial" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sea_trial" title="Sea trial">sea trial</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The testing phase of a boat, ship, or submarine, usually the final step in her construction, conducted to measure a vessel's performance and general seaworthiness before her owners take delivery of her.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="seaboat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">seaboat</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A <a href="#ship&#39;s_boat"><span title="See entry on this page at § ship&#39;s boat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ship's boat</span></a> kept ready for immediate use at sea, and used, for example, for retrieving a man overboard, or taking a boarding party to another vessel. Usually rigged with patent disengaging gear that allows both falls to be released simultaneously and quickly, so enabling the boat to be launched from a ship with way on.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEManual_of_Seamanship:_Volume_11937244–252_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEManual_of_Seamanship:_Volume_11937244–252-33">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A term used for any vessel when assessing her physical behavior at sea. A vessel that performs well in challenging weather or sea conditions such as heavy seas is <i>a good seaboat</i>, while one which does not is <i>a bad seaboat</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="seaboots" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Seaboot" title="Seaboot">seaboots</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">High waterproof boots for use at sea. In leisure sailing, known as <i>sailing wellies</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="seacock" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Seacock" title="Seacock">seacock</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="/wiki/Valve" title="Valve">valve</a> in the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hull</span></a></dfn> of a vessel used to allow seawater into or out of the vessel. Seacocks are used to admit seawater for purposes such as cooling an engine, feeding a saltwater faucet, or <a href="#scuttling"><span title="See entry on this page at § scuttling" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">scuttling</span></a> a vessel, or to drain a sink or toilet into the sea. On <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#warship" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § warship" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">warships</span></a></dfn>, seacocks may be used to flood <a href="/wiki/Magazine_(firearm)" class="mw-redirect" title="Magazine (firearm)">ammunition magazines</a> with seawater to prevent them from exploding during a fire.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="seakeeping" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Seakeeping" title="Seakeeping">seakeeping</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The ability of a watercraft to remain <a href="#seaworthy"><span title="See entry on this page at § seaworthy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">seaworthy</span></a> in the conditions she encounters while underway. A vessel with a good seakeeping ability is very seaworthy even in rough weather.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sea-kindly" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sea-kindly</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="sea-kindly"></span>
<dd class="glossary">(of a boat or ship) Having a comfortable motion in rough seas<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMayne2000253_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMayne2000253-34">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sealer" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sealer</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel designed for or engaged in seal hunting.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sealing" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sealing</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The hunting of <a href="/wiki/Pinniped" title="Pinniped">seals</a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The caulked floor of the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hold" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hold" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hold</span></a></dfn>. Also <i>ceiling</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="seaman" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Seaman_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Seaman (disambiguation)">seaman</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A generic term for a <a href="#sailor"><span title="See entry on this page at § sailor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sailor</span></a>, or (part of) a low naval rank.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="seamount" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Seamount" title="Seamount">seamount</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A large geologic landform rising from the ocean floor that does not reach the surface; an underwater mountain.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="seaworthy" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">seaworthy</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Certified for and capable of safely sailing at sea.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="second_mate" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Second_mate" title="Second mate">second mate</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="second_officer"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also called a <b>second officer</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A licensed member of the deck department of a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#merchant_ship" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § merchant ship" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">merchant ship</span></a></dfn>, third – or, on some <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#ocean_liner" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § ocean liner" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">ocean liners</span></a></dfn>, fourth – in command; a watchkeeping officer, customarily the ship<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#navigator" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § navigator" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">navigator</span></a></dfn>. Other duties vary, but the second mate is often the medical officer and in charge of maintaining distress-signaling equipment. On oil tankers, the second mate usually assists the chief mate with tank-cleaning operations.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="see_you_on_the_one_-_cuoto" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">see you on the one - CUOTO</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Used principally by Pilot's and River Tug and Barge deck and Officer crew as (a) a friendly farewell (similar to the phrase "catch you later") or (b) more properly used in vessel to vessel VHF (or when needed ship's whistle) communication, along with its companion phrase "see you on the two" to indicate which side a head-to-head vessel crossing is going to occur. The correct response to the challenge is to repeat it back to the apposing vessel in agreement, and if not in agreement to ask for an alternative arrangement. The "on the one" indicates a single whistle sound signal, or port to port crossing, whilst "on the two" is a dual (two) whistle sound signal, or starboard to starboard crossing. In the USA, a "one whistle" or port to port crossing is the normal and preferred crossing side.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="seekers" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">seekers</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">London term for sailing <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barges</span></a></dfn> that sought cargo, carrying cargo for other merchants at a fee, rather than for the owner.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="seiner" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Seiner" class="mw-redirect" title="Seiner">seiner</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A fishing vessel rigged to fish by <a href="/wiki/Seining" class="mw-redirect" title="Seining">seining</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="seize" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Seizing" title="Seizing">seize</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To bind two <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rope" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rope" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">ropes</span></a></dfn> together with small line.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="self-sustaining" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">self-sustaining</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#merchant_ship" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § merchant ship" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">merchant ship</span></a></dfn> that can unload herself with no assistance from harbor facilities is <i>self-sustaining</i>, while a ship that needs harbor facilities to unload is <i>non-self-sustaining</i>. Self-sustaining ships are more expensive to build, maintain, and operate than non-self-sustaining ships, but have the advantage of being able to operate in less-developed ports that lack infrastructure.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="self-unloader" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">self-unloader</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Great Lakes slang term for a vessel with a conveyor or some other method of unloading the cargo without shoreside equipment.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sennet" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sennet</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Cord formed by plaiting rope-yarn by hand. There are many types of plait, which may be flat, round, or square in section, and many uses.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955114_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955114-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_22-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> </dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sennet_whip" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sennet whip</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A summary punitive implement.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="serve" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">serve</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Cover a rope or splice by wrapping with thin line to protect it.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> Compare with <a href="#whipping"><span title="See entry on this page at § whipping" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">whipping</span></a> </dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="set" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">set</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The direction toward which the current flows.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="settle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">settle</dfn></dt> 
<dd class="glossary">(of a ship or boat): sink lower in the water, often prior to sinking altogether.</dd> 

<dt class="glossary" id="sextant" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sextant" title="Sextant">sextant</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A navigational instrument used to measure a ship's <a href="/wiki/Latitude" title="Latitude">latitude</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shackle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shackle</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">U-shaped iron, with a screw pin at the open end used for securing <a href="#stay"><span title="See entry on this page at § stay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stays</span></a> to <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sails</span></a>, allowing easy removal.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shaft" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shaft</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A <a href="/wiki/Drive_shaft" title="Drive shaft">propeller shaft</a>. The term <i>shaft</i> can be used instead of "<dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#propeller" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § propeller" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">propeller</span></a></dfn>" to describe the number of propellers a ship has, e.g., <i>The ship has two shafts</i> or <i>The ship's engines drive three shafts</i>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;To push or propel (a boat) with a pole.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shaft_alley" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shaft alley</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The section of a ship that houses the propulsion shaft, running from the engine room to the <a href="/wiki/Stuffing_box" title="Stuffing box">stuffing box</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shaft_log" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shaft log</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A shaped piece of timber or metal fitted to a vessel's <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#deadwood" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § deadwood" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">deadwood</span></a></dfn>, <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#keel" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § keel" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">keel</span></a></dfn>, or <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#keelson" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § keelson" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">keelson</span></a></dfn> at the point where the <a href="#stern_tube"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern tube" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern tube</span></a> passes through the hull.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shakedown_cruise" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Shakedown_cruise" title="Shakedown cruise">shakedown cruise</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also simply called a <b>shakedown</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A cruise performed before a ship enters service or after major changes such as a crew change, repair, or overhaul during which the performance of the ship and her crew are tested under working conditions.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shakes" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shakes</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Pieces of barrels or casks broken down to save space. They are worth very little, leading to the phrase "no great shakes".</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shallop" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Shallop" title="Shallop">shallop</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A term used for a variety of boats and small ships used for coastal navigation beginning in the 17th century.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A large boat armed with cannon used by the Danes as <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#gunboat" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § gunboat" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">gunboats</span></a></dfn> during the <a href="/wiki/Gunboat_War" title="Gunboat War">Gunboat War</a> (1807–1814).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shanghaied" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shanghaied</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The condition of a crewman involuntarily impressed into service on a ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sheave" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sheave</dfn></dt>(traditionally pronounced "shiv")
<dd class="glossary">The wheel in a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#block" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § block" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">block</span></a></dfn>, which rotates as the rope runs.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sheave-hole" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sheave-hole</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A hole or slot in a <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spar</span></a>, fitted with a <a href="#sheave"><span title="See entry on this page at § sheave" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sheave</span></a> to allow a rope to run.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sheer" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sheer</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The upward curve of a vessel's longitudinal lines as viewed from the side.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sheer_line" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sheer line</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The intersection of the external <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hull</span></a></dfn> surface and the main <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#deck" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § deck" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">deck</span></a></dfn> surface, shown by a line on the <a href="#sheer_plan"><span title="See entry on this page at § sheer plan" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sheer plan</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sheer_plan" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sheer plan</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">In <a href="/wiki/Shipbuilding" title="Shipbuilding">shipbuilding</a>, a diagram showing an <a href="/wiki/Elevation_(view)" class="mw-redirect" title="Elevation (view)">elevation</a> of the ship's <a href="#sheer"><span title="See entry on this page at § sheer" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sheer</span></a> viewed from the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#broadside" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § broadside" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">broadside</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sheet" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sheet_(sailing)" title="Sheet (sailing)">sheet</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A rope attached to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#clew" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § clew" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">clew</span></a></dfn> and used to control the setting of a <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> in relation to the direction of the wind. The sheet is often passed through a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#tackle" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § tackle" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">tackle</span></a></dfn> before being attach to fixed points on the deck, or in the case of a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barge</span></a></dfn>, to a traveller on the main horse.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sheet_anchor" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sheet anchor</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Historically, the heaviest <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#anchor" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § anchor" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">anchor</span></a></dfn> aboard a sailing ship, to be used only in case of emergency, and located <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#amidships" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § amidships" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">amidships</span></a></dfn>. In more general usage, the term has come to mean a person or thing that is very reliable in times of emergency.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> For example, during the <a href="/wiki/First_inauguration_of_Thomas_Jefferson" title="First inauguration of Thomas Jefferson">first inauguration of Thomas Jefferson</a>, he advocated, "the preservation of the General [Federal] Government in its whole constitutional vigor, as the sheet anchor of our peace at home and safety abroad."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKammen2017&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksid_x4uDwAAQBAJpgPP43_43&#93;_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKammen2017[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid_x4uDwAAQBAJpgPP43_43]-40">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sheet_bend" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sheet_bend" title="Sheet bend">sheet bend</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bend" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bend" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bend</span></a></dfn> to attach a rope to a small <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#eye" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § eye" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">eye</span></a></dfn> or <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#clew" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § clew" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">clew</span></a></dfn>, e.g. to attach a hammock to a clew or a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#painter" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § painter" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">painter</span></a></dfn> to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#jacobs_ladder" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § Jacobs Ladder" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">Jacobs Ladder</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAdmiralty_manual_of_seamanship1972159_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAdmiralty_manual_of_seamanship1972159-41">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shell" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Racing_shell" title="Racing shell">shell</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also called a <b>fine boat</b> in the United Kingdom.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">An extremely narrow, and often disproportionately long, rowing boat outfitted with long <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#oar" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § oar" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">oars</span></a></dfn>, <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#outrigger" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § outrigger" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">outriggers</span></a></dfn> to hold the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#oarlock" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § oarlock" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">oarlocks</span></a></dfn> away from the boat, and sliding seats, specifically designed for racing or exercise.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shelter_deck" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shelter deck</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An upper <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#deck" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § deck" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">deck</span></a></dfn> having no overhead protection from the weather itself, but sheltering the deck below it.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shift_colors" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shift colors</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Changing the flag and pennant display when a moored vessel becomes underway, and vice versa. A highly coordinated display that ships take pride in; the desired effect is that of one set of flags vanishing while another set flashes out at precisely the same time.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Slang for changing out of one's Navy uniform into civilian clothes to go ashore. (The US Navy's newsletter for retired personnel is nicknamed <i>Shift Colors</i> for this reason.)<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shift_tides" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Shift_tides" class="mw-redirect" title="Shift tides">shift tides</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Sighting the positions of the Sun and Moon using a <a href="#sextant"><span title="See entry on this page at § sextant" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sextant</span></a>, using a <a href="/wiki/Nautical_almanac" title="Nautical almanac">nautical almanac</a> to determine the location and phase of the Moon, and calculating the relative effect of the <a href="/wiki/Tide" title="Tide">tides</a> on the navigation of the ship.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ship</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;(n.) Strictly, a sailing vessel of three-masts or more and <a href="#square_rig"><span title="See entry on this page at § square rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square-rigged</span></a> on all <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">masts</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBennett20058_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBennett20058-45">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975222_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975222-46">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;(n.) More generally, any medium or larger seagoing vessel. Smaller vessels or those used in sheltered waters are generally called boats.  Exceptions include submarines which are always referred to as boats.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975222_46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975222-46">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;(v.) To send (an item or cargo) via waterborne transport, or in the derived meaning, by any means of transport (such as rail).<sup id="cite_ref-OED_ship_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OED_ship-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;(v.) To bring something aboard a vessel.<sup id="cite_ref-OED_ship_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OED_ship-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">5.&#160;&#160;(v.) To put something in its place aboard a vessel, ready for use.<sup id="cite_ref-OED_ship_47-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OED_ship-47">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">6.&#160;&#160;(v.) To take employment to serve aboard a vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">7.&#160;&#160;(v.) To embark or travel on a vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">8.&#160;&#160;(v.) To take water over the bow or sides of a vessel, e.g., "The freighter <i>shipped</i> a great deal of water during the storm."</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship_a_sea" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ship a sea</dfn></dt> 
<dd class="glossary">(Of a ship or boat): be flooded by a wave.</dd> 

<dt class="glossary" id="ship_breaking" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Ship_breaking" title="Ship breaking">ship breaking</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also called <b>ship cracking</b>, <b>ship demolition</b>, <b>ship dismantling</b>, or <b>ship recycling</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The demolition of ships for spare parts and scrap metal. A ship on her way to be scrapped is said to be going to <i>the breakers</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship_cemetery" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ship cemetery</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Another name for a <a href="#ship_graveyard"><span title="See entry on this page at § ship graveyard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ship graveyard</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship-of-the-line" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Ship_of_the_line" title="Ship of the line">ship-of-the-line</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of sailing <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#warship" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § warship" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">warship</span></a></dfn> constructed from the 1600s through the mid-1800s to serve as part of the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#line_of_battle" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § line of battle" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">line of battle</span></a></dfn>; one of the largest and most powerful warships of the era.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship_graveyard" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Ship_graveyard" title="Ship graveyard">ship graveyard</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also called a <b>ship cemetery</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A location where the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hulls</span></a></dfn> of discarded ships are left to decay and disintegrate.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;An area where <a href="#shipwreck"><span title="See entry on this page at § shipwreck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">shipwrecks</span></a> accumulate due to hazardous navigation conditions, deliberate <a href="#scuttling"><span title="See entry on this page at § scuttling" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">scuttling</span></a>, or losses in combat.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;An <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#anchorage" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § anchorage" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">anchorage</span></a></dfn> for ships of a <a href="/wiki/Reserve_fleet" title="Reserve fleet">reserve fleet</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship_over" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ship over</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To reenlist. When a sailor extends his or her service another term.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship-polacca" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ship-polacca</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A three-masted <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#polacca" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § polacca" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">polacca</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship_rig" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ship rig</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="ship_rigged_ship"></span><span class="anchor" id="ship_rigged"></span><span class="anchor" id="ship-rigged"></span>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#full_rig" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § full rig" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">full-rigged ship</span></a></dfn></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship_sloop" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Ship_sloop" class="mw-redirect" title="Ship sloop">ship sloop</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of <a href="#sloop-of-war"><span title="See entry on this page at § sloop-of-war" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sloop-of-war</span></a> introduced in the 1740s that had three <a href="#square_rig"><span title="See entry on this page at § square rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square-rigged</span></a> <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">masts</span></a></dfn> (in contrast to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#brig_sloop" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § brig sloop" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">brig sloop</span></a></dfn> introduced in the 1770s, which had two masts).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship_stores" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ship stores</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The materials, supplies and equipment required for the navigation, maintenance, operation and upkeep of a ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship_taken_up_from_trade" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">Ship Taken Up From Trade</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#sTUFT"><span title="See entry on this page at § STUFT" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">STUFT</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship&#39;s_bell" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Ship%27s_bell" title="Ship&#39;s bell">ship's bell</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Striking the ship's bell is the traditional method of marking time and regulating the crew's watches. Each bell (from one to eight) represents a 30-minute period since the beginning of a four-hour <a href="/wiki/Watch_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Watch system">watch</a>. For example, in the classical system, "Three bells in the morning watch" represents 90 minutes since the beginning of the morning watch, or 5:30 AM. "Eight bells" indicates the end of a watch.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship&#39;s_biscuit" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ship's biscuit</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hard_tack" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hard tack" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hard tack</span></a></dfn></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship&#39;s_company" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ship's company</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#crew" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § crew" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">crew</span></a></dfn> of a ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship&#39;s_complement" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ship's complement</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The number of persons in a ship<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#crew" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § crew" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">crew</span></a></dfn>, including officers.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ship&#39;s_husband" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ship's husband</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A legal term for an agent based on land, who has authority to make repairs and attend to the management, equipment, and general management of a ship in the home port.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ships_husbandry" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Ships_husbandry" title="Ships husbandry">ships husbandry</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">All aspects of maintenance, cleaning, and general upkeep of the hull, rigging, and equipment of a ship. It may also be used to refer to aspects of maintenance which are not specifically covered by the technical departments.<sup id="cite_ref-Nelson_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nelson-50">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shipbreach" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shipbreach</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Another name for a <a href="#shipwreck"><span title="See entry on this page at § shipwreck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">shipwreck</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shipping" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shipping</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Passage or transport on a ship; <a href="/wiki/Maritime_transport" title="Maritime transport">maritime transport</a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The body of ships belonging to one country, port, or industry.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shipwreck" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Shipwreck" title="Shipwreck">shipwreck</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The remains of a ship that has sunk.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The remains of a ship that has run <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#aground" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § aground" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">aground</span></a></dfn> such that she is no longer <a href="#seaworthy"><span title="See entry on this page at § seaworthy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">seaworthy</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;An event in which a ship sinks or otherwise becomes a wreck.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shipwrecking" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Shipwrecking" title="Shipwrecking">shipwrecking</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To wreck a ship through a mishap.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shipwrecked" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shipwrecked</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A person marooned due to the loss of a ship he or she was aboard is said to be <i>shipwrecked</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shipwright" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shipwright</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A person who designs, builds, and repairs ships, especially wooden ones.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shipyard" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Shipyard" title="Shipyard">shipyard</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A facility where <a href="#ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ships</span></a> or boats are built and repaired. Routinely used as a synonym for <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#dockyard" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § dockyard" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">dockyard</span></a></dfn>, although dockyard is sometimes associated more closely with a facility used for maintenance and basing activities, while shipyard sometimes is associated more closely with a facility used in construction.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shoal" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Shoal" title="Shoal">shoal</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Shallow water that is a hazard to navigation.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shoal_draught" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shoal draught</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An especially shallow <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#draught" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § draught" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">draught</span></a></dfn> on a vessel, making the vessel capable of sailing in unusually shallow water.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shore_leave" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shore leave</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Free time given to officers and crew of a naval vessel when they are off duty and allowed to disembark and spend time on land. See also <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#liberty" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § liberty" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">liberty</span></a></dfn></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="short_stay" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">short stay</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The relative slackness of an <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#anchor_chain" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § anchor chain" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">anchor chain</span></a></dfn>; "short stay" means the chain is somewhat slack, and neither vertical nor fully extended.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shorten" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shorten</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;To take in the slack of (a rope).</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;To reduce (sail) by taking it in, e.g. "shorten sail".</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shot_across_the_bow" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shot across the bow</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A shot fired close to and in front of a moving vessel to warn her to stop, often for boarding.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shrieking_sixties" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">Shrieking Sixties</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#screaming_Sixties"><span title="See entry on this page at § screaming Sixties" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">screaming Sixties</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shrimper" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">shrimper</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A fishing vessel rigged for <a href="/wiki/Shrimp_fishing" class="mw-redirect" title="Shrimp fishing">shrimp fishing</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shroud" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Shroud_(sailing)" title="Shroud (sailing)">shroud</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A rope or cable serving to support a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn> from either side.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="shrouds" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Shroud_(sailing)" title="Shroud (sailing)">shrouds</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Standing <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rigging" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rigging" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rigging</span></a></dfn> running from a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn> to the sides of a ship to support the mast sideways. The shrouds work with the <a href="#stay"><span title="See entry on this page at § stay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stays</span></a>, which run forward and aft, to support the mast's weight.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sick_bay" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sick_bay" title="Sick bay">sick bay</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A compartment reserved for medical purposes.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sideboy" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sideboy" title="Sideboy">sideboy</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">One of an even-numbered group of seamen posted in two rows on the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#quarterdeck" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § quarterdeck" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">quarterdeck</span></a></dfn> when a visiting dignitary boards or leaves the ship, historically to help (or even hoist) him aboard.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sidewheel" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sidewheel</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A side-mounted <a href="/wiki/Paddle_wheel" title="Paddle wheel">paddle wheel</a> used for propulsion by a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#paddle_steamer" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § paddle steamer" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">paddle steamer</span></a></dfn>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Propelled by sidewheels (e.g. "sidewheel <a href="/wiki/Steamboat" title="Steamboat">steamer</a>").</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sidewheeler" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sidewheeler</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#paddle_steamer" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § paddle steamer" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">paddle steamer</span></a></dfn> propelled by a pair of <a href="/wiki/Paddle_wheel" title="Paddle wheel">paddle wheels</a>, one mounted on each side.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="single-banked" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">single-banked</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="single-banked"></span>
<dd class="glossary">(of the arrangement of oars on a boat) having only one oarsman seated on each <a href="#thwart"><span title="See entry on this page at § thwart" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">thwart</span></a>, operating one oar on one side of the boat, with the oars alternating between port and starboard along the length of the boat. This contrasts with <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#double-banked" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § double-banked" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">double-banked</span></a></dfn>, where two oarsmen are seated on each thwart, each of whom operates one oar on their side of the boat. A third arrangement is to have one rower on each thwart working two oars, one on each side of the boat.<sup id="cite_ref-McKee_1983_21-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McKee_1983-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 135">&#58;&#8202;135&#8202;</span></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="single_up" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">single up</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">to reduce the number of mooring lines to a minimum immediately prior to getting under way. In a small vessel this would usually be a reduction to a mooring line at just the bow and the stern. In a larger vessel this may be a reducton to headrope, sternrope and two springs.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975229_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975229-52">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="siren" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Siren_(noisemaker)" class="mw-redirect" title="Siren (noisemaker)">siren</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A sound signal that uses electricity or compressed air to actuate either a disc or a cup-shaped rotor.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sister_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sister_ship" title="Sister ship">sister ship</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ship</span></a> of the same class as, and therefore virtually identical in design and appearance to, another ship. Sister ships share an identical or nearly identical <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hull</span></a></dfn> and <a href="#superstructure"><span title="See entry on this page at § superstructure" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">superstructure</span></a> layout, similar displacement, and roughly comparable features and equipment. Often, sister ships become more differentiated during their service lives as their equipment (and, in the case of military ships, their armament) are separately altered.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="skaffie" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Skaffie" class="mw-redirect" title="Skaffie">skaffie</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of small sailing vessel used for fishing, primarily during the 19th century and mostly in the <a href="/wiki/Moray_Firth" title="Moray Firth">Moray Firth</a> region of <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="skeg" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Skeg" title="Skeg">skeg</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A downward or sternward projection from the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#keel" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § keel" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">keel</span></a></dfn> in front of the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rudder" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rudder" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rudder</span></a></dfn>. Protects the rudder from damage, and in <i>bilge keelers</i> may provide one "leg" of a tripod on which the boat stands when the tide is out.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="skeleton_crew" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Skeleton_crew" title="Skeleton crew">skeleton crew</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A minimal crew, usually employed during an emergency or when a vessel is inactive, generally consisting of the minimum number of personnel required to maintain or operate the vessel.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="skiff" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Skiff" title="Skiff">skiff</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A small boat, traditionally a coastal or river craft, for leisure or fishing, with a single person or small crew. Sailing skiffs have developed into high-performance competitive classes.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="skipjack" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Skipjack_(boat)" title="Skipjack (boat)">skipjack</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of sailboat used as a traditional fishing boat on the <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay" title="Chesapeake Bay">Chesapeake Bay</a> for oyster dredging. It arose around the end of the 19th century as the successor to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bugeye" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bugeye" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bugeye</span></a></dfn> as the chief oystering boat on the bay.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="skipper" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Skipper_(boating)" class="mw-redirect" title="Skipper (boating)">skipper</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#captain" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § captain" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">captain</span></a></dfn> of a ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="skysail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">skysail</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A square <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> set above the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#royal" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § royal" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">royals</span></a></dfn>, typically only carried by large <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barque" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barque" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barques</span></a></dfn> and ships, such as the <i>Primrose Hill</i> (1885), <i>Oweenee</i> (1819), and <i>Mushkosa</i> (1819).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955112_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955112-20">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1952196_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1952196-53">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="skyscraper" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">skyscraper</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A small triangular sail above the <a href="#skysail"><span title="See entry on this page at § skysail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">skysail</span></a>. Used in light winds on a few ships.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="slack_tide" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Slack_tide" class="mw-redirect" title="Slack tide">slack tide</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The period between rising tide and falling tide, or the period between falling tide and rising tide when there is no tidal-induced current.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="slamming" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Slamming" title="Slamming">slamming</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Slamming occurs when wave or wind action cause part of the vessel to rise out of the water and then slam back down onto the surface of the sea.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="slave_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Slave_ship" title="Slave ship">slave ship</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A large cargo ship specially converted for the transportation of <a href="/wiki/Slave" class="mw-redirect" title="Slave">slaves</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Slave_trade" class="mw-redirect" title="Slave trade">slave trade</a>. Also known as a <i>slaver</i> or <i>Guineaman</i>, the latter term deriving from the <a href="/wiki/Guinea_(region)" title="Guinea (region)">Guinea</a> coast of <a href="/wiki/West_Africa" title="West Africa">West Africa</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="slaver" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">slaver</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Another name for a <a href="#slave_ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § slave ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">slave ship</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="slide" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">slide</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The cabin <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hatch" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hatch" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hatch</span></a></dfn> on a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barge</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBenhamFinchKershaw1986187_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBenhamFinchKershaw1986187-54">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sling" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sling</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;To pass a rope around something in preparation for attaching a hoisting or lowering <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#tackle" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § tackle" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">tackle</span></a></dfn> to it.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A band of rope or iron for securing a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#yard" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § yard" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">yard</span></a></dfn> to a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn>; chiefly used in the plural, <i>slings</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="slip" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">slip</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;To let go a rope at a precise moment, such as when releasing the last attachment to a buoy, when getting under way.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975231_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975231-55">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;To slip an <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor</a></span>: to let go the anchor cable, abandoning the anchor so as to get under way in an emergency, rather than spend time hauling in the cable to raise the anchor in the normal way. The released anchor cable is usually buoyed to aid recovery later.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975231_55-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975231-55">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;The difference between the theoretical distance traveled per revolution of a vessel's propeller and the actual advance of the vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;In marine engineering, the motion of the center of resistance of the float of a paddle wheel or the blade of an <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#oar" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § oar" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">oar</span></a></dfn> through the water horizontally.</dd>
