<dd class="glossary">5.&#160;&#160;In marine engineering, the difference between a vessel's actual speed and the speed it would have if the propelling instrument acted upon a solid.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">6.&#160;&#160;In marine engineering, the velocity of the backward current of water produced by the propeller relative to still water.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">7.&#160;&#160;In marine insurance, a memorandum of the particulars of a risk for which a policy is to be executed, usually bearing the broker's name and initialled by the underwriters.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="slip_rope" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">slip rope</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A mooring rope that is intended to be the last to be released when getting under way and is arranged so that it can be released from on-board. An example of this would be a rope that is led from the ship (or boat), through a ring on a mooring buoy, and then back to the ship.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975232_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975232-56">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="slipway" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Slipway" title="Slipway">slipway</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A ramp on the shore by which ships or boats can be moved to and from the water. Slipways are used for building and repairing ships and boats. They are also used for launching and retrieving small boats on trailers towed by automobiles and flying boats on their undercarriage.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sloop" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sloop" title="Sloop">sloop</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">In modern usage (from <i>circa</i> 1850s), a single-masted fore and aft sailing rig with one headsail set on the forestay, and a mainsail <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#abaft" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § abaft" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">abaft</span></a></dfn> the mast. The sloop rig is very common in modern leisure sailing vessels. In older usage, a sloop may have more than one headsail, but with the jib (the outer headsail) also set on a stay. This differentiates from a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#cutter" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § cutter" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">cutter</span></a></dfn> of the same era, where the jib would be set flying and a running bowsprit was used. Any bowsprit that might be fitted on a sloop was part of the standing rigging and remained in place at all times.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBennett200549–51_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBennett200549–51-57">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup></dd> 

<dt class="glossary" id="sloop-of-war" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sloop-of-war" title="Sloop-of-war">sloop-of-war</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;In the 18th and 19th centuries, a small sailing <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#warship" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § warship" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">warship</span></a></dfn> carrying 18 or fewer guns with a single continuous gundeck.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;In the 18th and 19th centuries, any sailing warship bearing fewer than 20 guns.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;In the 19th-century US Navy, the term used for the type of sailing warship known in other navies as a <a href="/wiki/Corvette" title="Corvette">corvette</a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;In the early and mid-20th century, a small oceangoing warship not intended for fleet deployments, and used instead for convoy escort, gunboat duties, etc.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="slop_chest" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">slop chest</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A ship's store of merchandise, such as clothing, tobacco, etc., maintained aboard merchant ships for sale to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#crew" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § crew" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">crew</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="slush" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">slush</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Greasy substance obtained by boiling or scraping the fat from empty salted meat storage barrels, or the floating fat residue after boiling the crew's meal. In the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a>, it was a perquisite of the ship's cook, who could sell it or exchange it (usually for alcohol) with other members of the crew. Used for greasing parts of the running rigging of the ship and therefore valuable to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#master" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § master" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">master</span></a></dfn> and <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#boatswain" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § boatswain" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bosun</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="slush_fund" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Slush_fund" title="Slush fund">slush fund</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The money obtained by the cook selling <a href="#slush"><span title="See entry on this page at § slush" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">slush</span></a> ashore. Used for the benefit of the crew (or the cook).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="smack" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Smack_(ship)" title="Smack (ship)">smack</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A traditional fishing boat used off the coast of England and the Atlantic coast of America for most of the 19th century and in small numbers up to the mid-20th century. Originally a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#cutter" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § cutter" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">cutter</span></a></dfn>-rigged sailing boat, after about 1865 lengthened and given a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#ketch" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § ketch" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">ketch</span></a></dfn> rig. Some had a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#topsail" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § topsail" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">topsail</span></a></dfn> on the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mizzen_mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mizzen mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mizzen mast</span></a></dfn>, others a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bowsprit" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bowsprit" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bowsprit</span></a></dfn> carrying a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#jib" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § jib" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">jib</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="small_bower" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">small bower</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The smaller of two <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#anchor" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § anchor" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">anchors</span></a></dfn> carried in the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bow" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bow" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bow</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="smoking_lamp" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">smoking lamp</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Restricted flame source lighted only during authorized smoking hours.<sup id="cite_ref-NHHC_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NHHC-16">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="snag" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">snag</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Snag_(ecology)#Maritime_hazard" title="Snag (ecology)">Snag</a>, also <i><b>deadhead</b></i>: A tree or tree branch fixed in the bottom of a navigable body of water and partially submerged or rising nearly to the surface that can pierce and sink vessels. Snags were a particularly severe hazard in the 19th and early 20th centuries; to be <i>snagged</i> is to suffer damage from or to be sunk by such a hazard.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;An underwater obstruction on which equipment trailed from a vessel, such as fishing lines and nets, becomes caught, sometimes resulting in loss of the equipment.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="snagboat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Snagboat" title="Snagboat">snagboat</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A river boat resembling a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barge</span></a></dfn> with a <a href="#superstructure"><span title="See entry on this page at § superstructure" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">superstructure</span></a> for crew accommodations, equipped with <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#deck" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § deck" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">deck</span></a></dfn>-mounted cranes and hoists for removing <a href="#snag"><span title="See entry on this page at § snag" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">snag</span></a>s and other obstructions from rivers and other shallow waterways.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="snatch_block" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">snatch block</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#block" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § block" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">block</span></a></dfn> with one cheek that is hinged, so that the bight of a rope can be inserted in the block (as opposed to threading the end of the rope into an ordinary block).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEManual_of_Seamanship:_Volume_11937115_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEManual_of_Seamanship:_Volume_11937115-58">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="snipe" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">snipe</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Member of a ship's engineering department.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Mythical object of a "<a href="/wiki/Snipe_hunt" title="Snipe hunt">snipe hunt</a>" for inexperienced crewmembers.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="snotter" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">snotter</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A short rope, spliced together at the ends and covered with hide, that is seized to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn> to hold the lower end of a <a href="#sprit"><span title="See entry on this page at § sprit" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sprit</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199030_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199030-59">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="snotty" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">snotty</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> slang for a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#midshipman" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § midshipman" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">midshipman</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="snow" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Snow_(ship)" title="Snow (ship)">snow</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A form of <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#brig" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § brig" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">brig</span></a></dfn> where the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#gaff" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § gaff" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">gaff</span></a></dfn> <a href="#spanker"><span title="See entry on this page at § spanker" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spanker</span></a> or driver is rigged on a "snow mast", a lighter <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spar</span></a> supported in chocks close behind the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mainmast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mainmast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mainmast</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="snub" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">snub</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="Snub"></span>
<dd class="glossary">To quickly stop a line that is running out - usually by taking or tightening a turn on a bollard, cleat or winch drum.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975234_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975234-61">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="snug_loaded" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">snug loaded</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">When all the cargo on a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barge</span></a></dfn> is stowed below in the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hold" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hold" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hold</span></a></dfn> and there is nothing on <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#deck" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § deck" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">deck</span></a></dfn>. In contrast to carrying a stack.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBenhamFinchKershaw1986187_54-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBenhamFinchKershaw1986187-54">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="soft_eye" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">soft eye</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An eye splice without a thimble fitted.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sog" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">SOG</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An abbreviation of "speed over ground", the speed of the vessel relative to the Earth (and as shown by a GPS). Referenced on many fishing forums.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sonar" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sonar" title="Sonar">Sonar</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;An <a href="/wiki/Acronym" title="Acronym">acronym</a> for "SOund Navigation And Ranging", a method of using sound pulses to detect, range, and sometimes image underwater targets and obstacles or the bed of the sea. See also <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#echo_sounding" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § echo sounding" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">echo sounding</span></a></dfn></i> and <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#asdic" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § ASDIC" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">ASDIC</span></a></dfn></i>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The equipment used to conduct such searches, ranging, and imaging.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sos" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/SOS" title="SOS">SOS</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">International distress signal.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sou&#39;wester" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sou%27wester" title="Sou&#39;wester">sou'wester</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A storm originating from the southwest.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A type of waterproof hat with a wide brim over the neck, worn in storms.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="soul,_souls" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">soul, souls</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">With a quantifier, can apply to the number of people on board ship; hence, <a href="#sOS"><span title="See entry on this page at § SOS" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">SOS</span></a>, “Save Our Souls”.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sounding" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sounding</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Measuring the depth of the water. Traditionally done by "<a href="#swinging_the_lead"><span title="See entry on this page at § swinging the lead" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">swinging the lead</span></a>", now more commonly by <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#echo_sounding" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § echo sounding" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">echo sounding</span></a></dfn>.</dd>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Heaving_the_lead.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Heaving_the_lead.jpg/170px-Heaving_the_lead.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="248" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Heaving_the_lead.jpg/255px-Heaving_the_lead.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Heaving_the_lead.jpg/340px-Heaving_the_lead.jpg 2x" data-file-width="454" data-file-height="661" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Heaving_the_lead.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="#sounding"><span title="See entry on this page at § sounding" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">Sounding</span></a></div></div></div>
<dt class="glossary" id="spanker" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Spanker_(sail)" title="Spanker (sail)">spanker</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#fore-and-aft_rig" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § fore-and-aft rig" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">fore-and-aft</span></a></dfn> or <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#gaff_rig" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § gaff rig" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">gaff-rigged</span></a></dfn> <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> on the aftmost mast of a <a href="#square_rig"><span title="See entry on this page at § square rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square-rigged</span></a> vessel and the main fore-and-aft sail (spanker sail) on the aftmost mast of a (partially) fore-and-aft rigged vessel such as a <a href="#schooner"><span title="See entry on this page at § schooner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">schooner</span></a>, <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barque" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barque" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barque</span></a></dfn>, or <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barquentine" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barquentine" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barquentine</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955114_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955114-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spanker-mast" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">spanker-mast</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The aftmost <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn> of a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#fore-and-aft_rig" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § fore-and-aft rig" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">fore-and-aft</span></a></dfn> or <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#gaff_rig" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § gaff rig" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">gaff-rigged</span></a></dfn> five-masted vessel such as a <a href="#schooner"><span title="See entry on this page at § schooner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">schooner</span></a> or <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barquentine" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barquentine" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barquentine</span></a></dfn>. A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#full_rig" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § full rig" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">full-rigged</span></a></dfn> ship has a <a href="#spanker"><span title="See entry on this page at § spanker" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spanker sail</span></a> but not a spanker-mast (see <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#jigger-mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § jigger-mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">jigger-mast</span></a></dfn>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113_35-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spar" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Spar_(sailing)" title="Spar (sailing)">spar</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A wooden (in later years also iron or steel) pole used to support various pieces of <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rigging" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rigging" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rigging</span></a></dfn> and <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sails</span></a>. The big five-masted <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#full_rig" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § full rig" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">full-rigged</span></a></dfn> <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#tall_ship" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § tall ship" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">tall ship</span></a></dfn> <i><a href="/wiki/Preu%C3%9Fen_(ship)" class="mw-redirect" title="Preußen (ship)">Preussen</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German spelling</a>: <i>Preußen</i>) had crossed 30 steel yards, but only one wooden spar – the little <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#gaff" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § gaff" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">gaff</span></a></dfn> of its <a href="#spanker"><span title="See entry on this page at § spanker" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spanker</span></a> sail.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spar_torpedo" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Spar_torpedo" title="Spar torpedo">spar torpedo</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A weapon consisting of a bomb placed at the end of a long <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spar</span></a> and attached to a boat.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="speaking_tube" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">speaking tube</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#communication_tube" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § communication tube" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">communication tube</span></a></dfn></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spencer" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">spencer</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#trysail" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § trysail" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">trysail</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113_35-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spider_band" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">spider band</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>spider hoop</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">An iron band around the base of a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn> that holds a set of iron <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#belaying_pin" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § belaying pin" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">belaying pins</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spindrift" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Spindrift" title="Spindrift">spindrift</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Finely divided water swept from the crests of waves by strong winds. The presence of spindrift may be used to approximately estimate wind speed.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spinnaker" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Spinnaker" title="Spinnaker">spinnaker</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A large <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> flown in front of the vessel while heading downwind.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMayne2000&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidFp63wWByImQCpgPA282_282&#93;_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMayne2000[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidFp63wWByImQCpgPA282_282]-63">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#headsail" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § headsail" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">headsail</span></a></dfn> set <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#windward" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § windward" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">windward</span></a></dfn> when running before the wind. The bargeman's spinnaker is his <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#topmast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § topmast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">topmast</span></a></dfn> <a href="#staysail"><span title="See entry on this page at § staysail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">staysail</span></a>, tacked to the mast, and sheeted round the weather crosstree.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spinnaker_pole" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Spinnaker_pole" title="Spinnaker pole">spinnaker pole</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spar</span></a> used to help control a <a href="#spinnaker"><span title="See entry on this page at § spinnaker" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spinnaker</span></a> or other <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#headsail" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § headsail" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">headsail</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spirketting" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">spirketting</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The thicker planks of the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#ceiling" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § ceiling" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">ceiling</span></a></dfn>, found at the bottom of the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hold" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hold" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hold</span></a></dfn> and continuing up the inside of the hull to the start of the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#quickwork" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § quickwork" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">quickwork</span></a></dfn> (or lining).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESteffy2013_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESteffy2013-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="splice" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Rope_splicing" title="Rope splicing">splice</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To join lines (ropes, cables, etc.) by unravelling their ends and intertwining them to form a continuous line; to form an eye or a knot by splicing.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199030_59-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199030-59">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="splice_the_mainbrace" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Splice_the_mainbrace" title="Splice the mainbrace">splice the mainbrace</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An order given aboard naval vessels to issue the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#crew" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § crew" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">crew</span></a></dfn> with a drink, traditionally <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#grog" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § grog" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">grog</span></a></dfn>. The phrase "splice the mainbrace" is used idiomatically meaning to go ashore on <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#liberty" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § liberty" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">liberty</span></a></dfn>, intending to go out for an evening of drinking.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="split_lugsail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">split lugsail</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Two sails, <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#foresail" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § foresail" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">foresail</span></a></dfn> and <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mainsail" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mainsail" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mainsail</span></a></dfn> on a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#lugsail" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § lugsail" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">lugsail</span></a></dfn> <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#yard" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § yard" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">yard</span></a></dfn>, removing the need to dip the yard around the mast every time the vessel <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#tacking" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § tacking" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">tacked</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarr195163_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarr195163-64">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sponson" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sponson" title="Sponson">sponson</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A projection from the side of a vessel for protection, stability, or the mounting of equipment such as armaments or <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#lifeboat" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § lifeboat" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">lifeboats</span></a></dfn>. A sponson that extends a hull dimension at or below the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#waterline" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § waterline" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">waterline</span></a></dfn> serves to increase flotation or add lift when underway. In salvage of a damaged or disabled vessel, a sponson may be a flotation tank attached to provide stability or buoyancy.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spoke" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">spoke</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Spoke (to) another ship, as in "Spoke a brig from Rio" in <i>Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym of Nantucket</i> by <a href="/wiki/Edgar_Allan_Poe" title="Edgar Allan Poe">Edgar Allan Poe</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sponsor" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sponsor</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The person, traditionally a woman, who christens a ship at its launching ceremony.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spotting_top" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">spotting top</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A platform on a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn> used to aid in <a href="/wiki/Gun_laying" title="Gun laying">gun laying</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spreader" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Spreader_(sailboat)" title="Spreader (sailboat)">spreader</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spar</span></a> on a sailboat used to deflect the <a href="#shrouds"><span title="See entry on this page at § shrouds" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">shrouds</span></a> to allow them to better support the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spring" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">spring</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A mooring warp that goes from the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bow" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bow" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bow</span></a></dfn> to a position on the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#quayside" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § quayside" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">quayside</span></a></dfn> level with the <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a> (<i>backspring</i>) or led forward from the stern to a point level with the bow (<i>forespring</i>). A spring may be used in conjunction with the engine to swing the bow or stern away from a quayside to enable safe departure.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMayne2000&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidFp63wWByImQCpgPA284_284&#93;_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMayne2000[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidFp63wWByImQCpgPA284_284]-65">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="springs" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">springs</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Big tides caused by the alignment of the Moon and Sun.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBenhamFinchKershaw1986187_54-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBenhamFinchKershaw1986187-54">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sprit" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sprit</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spar</span></a> that supports a <a href="#spritsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § spritsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spritsail</span></a>. It is attached to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn> near the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#deck" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § deck" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">deck</span></a></dfn> and extends diagonally up to the peak of the sail. It is steadied by <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#vangs" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § vangs" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">vangs</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spritsail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Spritsail" title="Spritsail">spritsail</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#fore-and-aft" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § fore-and-aft" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">fore-and-aft</span></a></dfn> <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a>, where the peak is supported by a <a href="#sprit"><span title="See entry on this page at § sprit" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sprit</span></a>. It may be free-footed or use a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#boom" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § boom" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">boom</span></a></dfn>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A rig that uses a spritsail.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;A square-sail flown beneath the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bowsprit" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bowsprit" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bowsprit</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sprittie" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sprittie</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#spritsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § spritsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spritsail</span></a>-rigged <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barge</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="spurling_pipe" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">spurling pipe</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A pipe that connects to the chain locker, from which the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#anchor_chain" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § anchor chain" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">anchor chain</span></a></dfn> emerges onto the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#deck" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § deck" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">deck</span></a></dfn> at the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bow" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bow" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bow</span></a></dfn> of a ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="squadron" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Squadron_(naval)" title="Squadron (naval)">squadron</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;In general, any significant group of <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#warship" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § warship" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">warships</span></a></dfn> considered too small to be a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#fleet" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § fleet" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">fleet</span></a></dfn>, but otherwise not strictly defined by size. In some navies, the term <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#flotilla" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § flotilla" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">flotilla</span></a></dfn></i> may be used instead of or in addition to <i>squadron</i>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Such a group of warships assigned to and named after a particular ocean, sea, or geographical region, commanded by an <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#admiral" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § admiral" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">admiral</span></a></dfn> who may be the naval commander-in-chief in that theatre, e.g. the <a href="/wiki/Asiatic_Squadron" title="Asiatic Squadron">Asiatic Squadron</a>, the <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Squadron" title="North Atlantic Squadron">North Atlantic Squadron</a>, etc.; generally synonymous with similar naval formations known as <a href="#stations"><span title="See entry on this page at § stations" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stations</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;During the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Sail" title="Age of Sail">Age of Sail</a>, a temporary subdivision of a fleet.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;A temporary detachment of ships from a fleet.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">5.&#160;&#160;Especially in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, a permanent battle formation of a fleet, equipped and trained to operate as a tactical unit under the overall command of the fleet or when detached from the fleet.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">6.&#160;&#160;Especially in modern usage, an administrative naval command responsible for the manning, training, supply, and maintenance of a group of ships or submarines but not for directing their operations at sea.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="square" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">square</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To place at right angles with the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn> or <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#keel" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § keel" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">keel</span></a></dfn> and parallel to the horizon, e.g. "to square the yards".</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="square_meal" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">square meal</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A sufficient quantity of food. Meals on board ship were served to the crew on a square wooden plate in harbor or at sea in good weather. Food in the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> was invariably better or at least in greater quantity than that available to the average landsman. However, while square wooden plates were indeed used on board ships, there is no established link between them and this particular term. The OED gives the earliest reference from the US in the mid-19th century.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="square_rig" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Square_rig" title="Square rig">square rig</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="square_rigging"></span><span class="anchor" id="square-rigged"></span>
<dd class="glossary">A generic type of <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> and <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rigging" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rigging" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rigging</span></a></dfn> arrangement in which the primary driving sails are carried on <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#yard" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § yard" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">yards</span></a></dfn> that are perpendicular, or "<a href="#square"><span title="See entry on this page at § square" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square</span></a>", to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#keel" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § keel" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">keel</span></a></dfn> of the vessel and to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">masts</span></a></dfn>. A ship mainly so rigged is said to be <i>square-rigged</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113_35-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="square_rigger" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">square rigger</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#square-rigged"><span title="See entry on this page at § square-rigged" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square-rigged</span></a> ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="squared_away" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">squared away</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary"><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#yard" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § yard" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">Yards</span></a></dfn> held rigidly perpendicular to their <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">masts</span></a></dfn> and parallel to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#deck" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § deck" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">deck</span></a></dfn>. This was rarely the best trim of the yards for efficiency but made a pretty sight for inspections and in harbor. The term is applied to situations and to people figuratively to mean that all difficulties have been resolved or that the person is performing well and is mentally and physically prepared.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="squat_effect" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Squat_effect" title="Squat effect">squat effect</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The phenomenon by which a vessel moving quickly through shallow water creates an area of lowered pressure under its <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#keel" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § keel" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">keel</span></a></dfn> that reduces the ship's buoyancy, particularly at the bow. The reduced buoyancy causes the ship to "squat" lower in the water than would ordinarily be expected, and thus its effective <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#draught" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § draught" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">draught</span></a></dfn> is increased.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="squid" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/squid" class="extiw" title="wikt:squid">squid</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A derogatory term for a US Navy sailor.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="s.s._(or_ss)" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">S.S. (or SS)</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="SS"></span>
<dd class="glossary">To the purist, a prefix for Screw Steamer (i.e. with screw propulsion, meaning propellers). It is used before the name of a ship. Compare with "PS", which stands for "Paddle Steamer". Widely used as an abbreviation for "<a href="/wiki/Steamboat" title="Steamboat">Steam Ship</a>".</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stack" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stack</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>funnel</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Another name for a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#funnel" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § funnel" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">funnel</span></a></dfn>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Deck cargo.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stack_marking" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stack marking</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A logo or other type of livery on a ship′s <a href="#stack"><span title="See entry on this page at § stack" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stack</span></a> indicating which private entity, such as a shipping line, or government agency owns or operates her. Generally, all the ships belonging to the fleet of a single company or agency will have the same stack marking.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stackie" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stackie</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barge</span></a></dfn> designed to take a large deck cargo, usually of hay or straw needed to feed working horses.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stanchion" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Stanchion" title="Stanchion">stanchion</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vertical post near the edge of a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#deck" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § deck" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">deck</span></a></dfn> that supports life-lines; a timber fitted in between the frame heads on a wooden hull or a bracket on a steel vessel, approx one meter high, to support the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bulwark" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bulwark" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bulwark</span></a></dfn> plank or plating and the <a href="/wiki/Hand_rail" class="mw-redirect" title="Hand rail">rail</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stand" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stand</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">(of a ship or its captain) To steer, sail, or steam, usually used in conjunction with a specified direction or destination, e.g. "The ship stood out of the harbor" or "The ship stood toward the east" or "The ship stood toward the missing vessel's last known position".</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stand-on_(vessel)" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stand-on (vessel)</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel <a href="/wiki/International_Regulations_for_Preventing_Collisions_at_Sea" title="International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea">directed</a> to keep her course and speed where two vessels are approaching one another so as to involve a risk of collision.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="standing_part" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">standing part</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The section of a rope at a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#cleat" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § cleat" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">cleat</span></a></dfn> or a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#block" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § block" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">block</span></a></dfn> that is under tension, as opposed to the loose end.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="standing_rigging" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Standing_rigging" title="Standing rigging">standing rigging</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary"><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rigging" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rigging" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">Rigging</span></a></dfn> that supports <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">masts</span></a></dfn> and <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spars</span></a> and is not manipulated during normal operations. Contrast <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#running_rigging" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § running rigging" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">running rigging</span></a></dfn></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113_35-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stanliff" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stanliff</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A heavy wire cable attached to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn> at the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hounds" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hounds" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hounds</span></a></dfn> to support the weight of a <a href="#spritsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § spritsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spritsail</span></a> at the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#heel" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § heel" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">heel</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="starboard" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Starboard" class="mw-redirect" title="Starboard">starboard</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The right side of a ship or boat; towards the right-hand side of a vessel facing forward (toward the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bow" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bow" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bow</span></a></dfn>).<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> Denoted with a green light at night. Derived from the old steering oar or "steerboard", which preceded the invention of the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rudder" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rudder" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rudder</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="starboard_tack" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">starboard tack</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">When sailing with the wind coming from the <a href="#starboard"><span title="See entry on this page at § starboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">starboard</span></a> side of the vessel. Vessels on starboard tack generally have right-of-way over vessels on <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#port_tack" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § port tack" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">port tack</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="starter" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">starter</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A rope used as a punitive device. See <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#teazer" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § teazer" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">teazer</span></a></dfn></i> and <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#togey" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § togey" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">togey</span></a></dfn></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stateroom" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stateroom</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A superior cabin for a vessel<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s officer.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;In American usage, a private passenger cabin on a transport or cruise ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="station" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">station</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;In chiefly 19th- and early 20th-century usage, a naval formation under a commander-in-chief who controls all naval operations, and sometimes all naval shore facilities, within a specified geographic area (e.g. the <a href="/wiki/China_Station" class="mw-redirect" title="China Station">China Station</a>, the <a href="/wiki/East_Indies_Station" title="East Indies Station">East Indies Station</a>, etc.); sometimes synonymous with <a href="#squadron"><span title="See entry on this page at § squadron" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">squadron</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;In <a href="/wiki/Newfoundland_(island)" title="Newfoundland (island)">Newfoundland</a>, a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#harbour" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § harbour" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">harbour</span></a></dfn> or cove with a foreshore suitable for a facility to support nearby fishing.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;<i>Naval station</i>: a naval base (a <i>naval air station</i> is a base for naval aircraft).</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;<i>Coaling station</i>: a facility that supplies ships with coal.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="station_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">station ship</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A ship assigned to a particular station, such as a port or a geographic area, usually to support naval vessels and operations. A station ship may patrol the local area, or provide personnel to other ships, or provide fuel or services such as repairs.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stay" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Stays_(nautical)" title="Stays (nautical)">stay</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="stay"></span>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A strong <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rope" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rope" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rope</span></a></dfn> supporting a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn> and leading from the head of one mast down to some other mast or other part of the vessel; any <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rigging" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rigging" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rigging</span></a></dfn> running fore (<dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#forestay" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § forestay" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">forestay</span></a></dfn>) and aft (<dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#backstay" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § backstay" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">backstay</span></a></dfn>) from a mast to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hull</span></a></dfn>. The stays support a mast's weight forward and aft, while the <a href="#shrouds"><span title="See entry on this page at § shrouds" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">shrouds</span></a> support its weight from side to side.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199031_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199031-67">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;To incline forward, aft, or to one side by means of stays, e.g. to "stay a mast".</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;To <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#tack" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § tack" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">tack</span></a></dfn>; put on the other tack, e.g. to "stay ship".</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;To change; tack; go about; be in stays, as a ship.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">5.&#160;&#160;A <a href="#station"><span title="See entry on this page at § station" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">station</span></a> or fixed <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#anchorage" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § anchorage" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">anchorage</span></a></dfn> for vessels.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">6.&#160;&#160;<i>In stays</i> or <i>hove in stays</i>: in the act of going about while tacking.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">7.&#160;&#160;<i>Miss stays</i>: an unsuccessful attempt to tack.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stayfall" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stayfall</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A flexible wire cable rove through <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#block" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § block" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">blocks</span></a></dfn>, one on the <a href="#stemhead"><span title="See entry on this page at § stemhead" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stemhead</span></a> and one on the end of the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#forestay" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § forestay" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">forestay</span></a></dfn>. This is the means by which the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mainmast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mainmast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mainmast</span></a></dfn> is lowered.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="staysail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Staysail" title="Staysail">staysail</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> whose <span title="See entry on this page at § luff" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#luff" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">luff</a></span> is attached to a <a href="#stay"><span title="See entry on this page at § stay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stay</span></a>. If set on the most forward (or only) <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a>, a staysail is a <span title="See entry on this page at § headsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#headsail" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">headsail</a></span>. Where more than one headsail is set, the staysail is generally the one closest to the mast.<sup id="cite_ref-PBO_10-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PBO-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Location: headsail">&#58;&#8202;headsail&#8202;</span></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="steamer" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">steamer</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>steamboat</b> or <b>steamship</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel equipped with <a href="/wiki/Steam_propulsion" class="mw-redirect" title="Steam propulsion">steam propulsion</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="steerage" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Steerage" title="Steerage">steerage</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The effect of the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#helm" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § helm" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">helm</span></a></dfn> on a vessel; the act of steering a vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A 19th- and early 20th-century term for the section of a passenger ship that provided inexpensive accommodation with no individual cabins.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="steerageway" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">steerageway</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The minimum speed at which a vessel answers the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#helm" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § helm" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">helm</span></a></dfn>, below which she cannot be steered. Speed sufficient for the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rudder" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rudder" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rudder</span></a></dfn> to "bite".</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="steering_flat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">steering flat</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The compartment on a vessel that contains the steering gear.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="steering_oar" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Steering_oar" title="Steering oar">steering oar</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="steering_board"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>steering board</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A long, flat board or <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#oar" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § oar" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">oar</span></a></dfn> that went from the <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a> to well underwater, used to steer vessels before the invention of the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rudder" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rudder" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rudder</span></a></dfn>. Traditionally on the <a href="#starboard"><span title="See entry on this page at § starboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">starboard</span></a> side of a ship (the "steering board" side).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="steersman" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">steersman</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Another name for a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#helmsman" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § helmsman" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">helmsman</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="steeve" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">steeve</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spar</span></a> or derrick with a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#block" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § block" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">block</span></a></dfn> at one end, used for stowing cargo.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;To incline upwards at an angle (used especially of a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bowsprit" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bowsprit" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bowsprit</span></a></dfn>) rather than lie horizontally; to set at a particular upwards incline.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955114_36-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955114-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stem" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Stem_(ship)" title="Stem (ship)">stem</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;An extension of the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#keel" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § keel" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">keel</span></a></dfn> at the forward end of a ship.</dd>
