<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;On a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barge</span></a></dfn>, the foremost timber set vertically to the keel, forming the head of the stem; it carries the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#forestay" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § forestay" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">forestay</span></a></dfn> and other <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rigging" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rigging" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rigging</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stern" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Stern" title="Stern">stern</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The rear part of a ship, technically defined as the area built up over the <a href="#sternpost"><span title="See entry on this page at § sternpost" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sternpost</span></a>, extending upwards from the counter rail to the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#taffrail" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § taffrail" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">taffrail</span></a></dfn>. Contrast <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bow" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bow" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bow</span></a></dfn></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stern_chaser" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stern chaser</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#chase_gun" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § chase gun" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">chase gun</span></a></dfn></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stern_tube" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stern tube</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The tube under the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hull</span></a></dfn> bearing the tailshaft for propulsion (usually at the <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a>).</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A <a href="/wiki/Torpedo_tube" title="Torpedo tube">torpedo tube</a> mounted in the stern of a submarine.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sterncastle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sterncastle</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Another name for an <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#aftercastle" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § aftercastle" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">aftercastle</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sterndrive" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sterndrive" title="Sterndrive">sterndrive</a> </dfn></dt>
<dt class="glossary" id="stern_drive" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stern drive</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary"><p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also: Z-drive</span></p>
A propeller drive system similar to the lower part of an <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#outboard_motor" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § outboard motor" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">outboard motor</span></a></dfn> extending below the hull of a larger power boat or yacht, but driven by an engine mounted within the hull. Unlike a fixed propeller (but like an outboard), the boat may be steered by twisting the drive. See also <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#inboard_motor" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § inboard motor" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">inboard motor</span></a></dfn></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sternpicker" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sternpicker</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#gillnetter" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § gillnetter" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">gillnetter</span></a></dfn> that fishes by deploying a <a href="/wiki/Gillnet" class="mw-redirect" title="Gillnet">gillnet</a> from the <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sternpost" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sternpost" title="Sternpost">sternpost</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The upright structural member (or <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#post" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § post" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">post</span></a></dfn>) at the <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a> of a (usually wooden) ship or boat, to which are attached the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#transom" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § transom" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">transoms</span></a></dfn> and the rearmost corner part of the stern. It rests on ("fays to") the ship's <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#keel" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § keel" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">keel</span></a></dfn>, and may be vertical or tilted ("raked") slightly aft.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sternsheets" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sternsheets</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The area at the <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a> of an open boat.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMayne2000_19-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMayne2000-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The benches at the <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a> of an open boat that forms the or seating in the stern.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMayne2000_19-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMayne2000-19">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sternwalk" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sternwalk</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An external walkway or gallery for the use of officers installed on the <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a>, chiefly of British warships until the early 20th century.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sternway" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sternway</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The reverse movement of a boat or watercraft through the water.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sternwheel" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sternwheel</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a>-mounted <a href="/wiki/Paddle_wheel" title="Paddle wheel">paddle wheel</a> used for propulsion by a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#paddle_steamer" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § paddle steamer" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">paddle steamer</span></a></dfn>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Propelled by a sternwheel (e.g. a "sternwheel <a href="#steamer"><span title="See entry on this page at § steamer" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">steamer</span></a>").</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sternwheeler" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sternwheeler</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="/wiki/Paddle_steamer" title="Paddle steamer">paddle steamer</a> propelled by a <a href="#sternwheel"><span title="See entry on this page at § sternwheel" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sternwheel</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="steward" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">steward</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A member of a vessel<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s crew involved in commissary duties or in personal services to passengers or other crew members.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stood" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stood</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#stand"><span title="See entry on this page at § stand" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stand</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stocks" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stocks</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The frame that supports a ship or boat when it is being built.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stoker" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stoker</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#fireman" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § fireman" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">fireman</span></a></dfn></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stopper_knot" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Stopper_knot" title="Stopper knot">stopper knot</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A knot tied in the end of a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rope" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rope" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rope</span></a></dfn>, usually to stop it passing through a hole; most commonly a <a href="/wiki/Figure-eight_knot" title="Figure-eight knot">figure-eight knot</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stoppers" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stoppers</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A short rope to check a cable in a fixed position. <i>Anchor stoppers</i> hold the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#anchor" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § anchor" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">anchor</span></a></dfn> when catted, <i>bitt stoppers</i> and <i>deck stoppers</i> are used to retain the cable when at anchor, <i>shroud stoppers</i> contain a damaged shroud, and <i>foretack</i> and <i>sheet stoppers</i> secure the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#tack" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § tack" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">tacks</span></a></dfn> until they are belayed.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199032_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199032-68">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="storeship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Storeship" class="mw-redirect" title="Storeship">storeship</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>store ship</b> or <b>stores ship</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;During the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Sail" title="Age of Sail">Age of Sail</a> and immediately afterwards, a captured ship used to stow supplies and other goods for naval purposes.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Since the mid-20th century, a type of naval ship that provides supplies, such as frozen, chilled, and dry provisions, and propulsion and aviation fuel to <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#warship" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § warship" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">warships</span></a></dfn> at sea for an extended period. In some navies, synonymous with <i>replenishment oiler</i>, <i>fleet replenisher</i>, or <i>fleet tanker</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stove" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stove</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="stove_in"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>stove in</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">(past tense of <i>stave</i>, often applied as present tense) To smash inward; to force a hole or break in, as in a cask, door, ship's <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hull</span></a></dfn>, or other (wooden) barrier.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stow" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stow</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To store or put away, e.g. personal effects, tackle, or cargo.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stowage" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Stowage" title="Stowage">stowage</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The amount of room for storing materials on board a ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stowaway" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Stowaway" title="Stowaway">stowaway</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A trespasser on a ship; a person aboard a ship without permission and/or without payment, who usually boards undetected, remains hidden aboard, and jumps ship just before making <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#port" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § port" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">port</span></a></dfn> or reaching a port's dock; sometimes found aboard and imprisoned in the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#brig" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § brig" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">brig</span></a></dfn> until the ship makes port and the prisoner can be transferred to the custody of police or military.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="straggler" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">straggler</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">In a convoy, a ship that is unable to maintain speed and falls behind.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="strake" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Strake" title="Strake">strake</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A continuous line of planking on a wooden hull going from bow to stern. Successive strakes, one above the other, form the outer skin of a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hull</span></a></dfn>. In a steel hull the same term can be applied to a continuous line of steel plates all fastened at the same level.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975247_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975247-69">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stretcher" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stretcher</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An inclined foot rest attached to the boat, to which a rower may place and in some instances (usually in competition) attach his feet.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="strike" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">strike</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;To haul down or lower (a flag, mast, etc.).</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;To surrender the vessel to the enemy, from "<a href="#strike_the_colors"><span title="See entry on this page at § strike the colors" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">strike the colors</span></a>".</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;To remove a naval vessel<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s name from a country's naval register (after which the vessel is considered <i>stricken</i>).</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;An attack by a naval combat asset.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">5.&#160;&#160;To undergo training (as a "striker") to qualify for an enlisted <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rating" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rating" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rating</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="strike_the_colors" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">strike the colors</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To surrender the vessel to an enemy, from the custom during the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Sail" title="Age of Sail">Age of Sail</a> of lowering the vessel<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#ensign" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § ensign" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">ensign</span></a></dfn> to indicate that she is surrendering.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="studding_sails" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Studding_sail" title="Studding sail">studding sails</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="studding_sail"></span><span class="anchor" id="studding-sail"></span><span class="anchor" id="studding-sails"></span>
<dd class="glossary">(pronounced <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="&#39;s&#39; in &#39;sigh&#39;">s</span><span title="&#39;t&#39; in &#39;tie&#39;">t</span><span title="/ʌ/: &#39;u&#39; in &#39;cut&#39;">ʌ</span><span title="&#39;n&#39; in &#39;nigh&#39;">n</span><span title="&#39;s&#39; in &#39;sigh&#39;">s</span><span title="/əl/: &#39;le&#39; in &#39;bottle&#39;">əl</span></span>/</a></span></span>) Long and narrow <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sails</span></a>, used in lighter winds, on the outside of the large <a href="#square_sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § square sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square sails.</span></a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113_35-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955113-35">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stuft" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/STUFT" title="STUFT">STUFT</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">British and Commonwealth acronym for <i>Ship Taken Up From Trade</i>, which refers to a civilian ship requisitioned for naval or other government service.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stumpy" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">stumpy</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A <a href="#spritsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § spritsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spritsail</span></a> <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barge</span></a></dfn> without a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#topmast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § topmast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">topmast</span></a></dfn>. Normal form before 1850, the stumpies sprit was longer than those used in <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#topsail" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § topsail" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">topsail</span></a></dfn> barges, as the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mainsail" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mainsail" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mainsail</span></a></dfn> was cut with a higher peak.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarr195171_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarr195171-70">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A tops'l barge underway without her topsails set.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="stw" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">STW</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An abbreviation of "speed through (the) water"; the speed of the vessel relative to the surrounding water (and as shown by a <a href="/wiki/Pitometer_log" title="Pitometer log">Log</a>). Used in navigation.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="submarine" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Submarine" title="Submarine">submarine</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Generally, a watercraft capable of independent operations underwater, able to renew its own power and breathing air. A submarine differs from a <a href="#submersible"><span title="See entry on this page at § submersible" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">submersible</span></a>, which has more limited underwater capabilities. By naval tradition, any submarine is referred to informally as a "boat" regardless of its size.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Most commonly, a large, crewed vessel capable of independent underwater operations.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;Historically and colloquially, a broad category of vessels capable of submerged operations, including large, crewed submarines but also medium-sized and smaller vessels such as <a href="/wiki/Midget_submarine" title="Midget submarine">midget submarines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wet_sub" title="Wet sub">wet subs</a> and vessels technically considered submersibles because they require external support, such as <a href="/wiki/Remotely_operated_vehicle" class="mw-redirect" title="Remotely operated vehicle">remotely operated vehicles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_underwater_vehicle" title="Autonomous underwater vehicle">autonomous underwater vehicles</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="submarine_tender" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Submarine_tender" title="Submarine tender">submarine tender</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A naval auxiliary ship designed to supply <a href="#submarine"><span title="See entry on this page at § submarine" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">submarines</span></a> and support their operations. Known in British English as a <i>submarine depot ship</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="submersible" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Submersible" title="Submersible">submersible</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A small watercraft capable of operating underwater but which requires the support of a surface vessel, a surface platform, a shore team, or a larger undersea vessel such as a <a href="#submarine"><span title="See entry on this page at § submarine" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">submarine</span></a>. A submersible contrasts with a submarine in that a submarine is capable of fully autonomous operations, including generation of its own power and breathing air. However, colloquially, the term "submarine" often indiscriminately refers to any vessel capable of underwater operations, including those that technically are submersibles.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sunfish" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Sunfish_(sailboat)" title="Sunfish (sailboat)">sunfish</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A personal-sized, beach-launched sailing <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#dinghy" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § dinghy" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">dinghy</span></a></dfn> with a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#pontoon" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § pontoon" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">pontoon</span></a></dfn>-type <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#hull" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § hull" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">hull</span></a></dfn>, <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#daggerboard" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § daggerboard" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">daggerboard</span></a></dfn>, and <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#lateen_sail" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § lateen sail" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">lateen sail</span></a></dfn> mounted to an un-<a href="#stay"><span title="See entry on this page at § stay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stayed</span></a> <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">mast</span></a></dfn>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="supercargo" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Supercargo" title="Supercargo">supercargo</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A person aboard a vessel who is employed by the cargo owner. Duties include selling merchandise in ports, as well as buying and receiving goods for the return voyage.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="superfiring" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">superfiring</dfn></dt> 
<dd class="glossary">Superfiring armament is a naval military building technique in which two (or more) turrets are located in a line, one behind the other, with the second turret located above ("super") the one in front so that the second turret can fire over the first.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="superstructure" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Superstructure" title="Superstructure">superstructure</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The parts of a ship or boat, including a sailboat, fishing boat, passenger ship, or submarine, that project above her main <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#deck" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § deck" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">deck</span></a></dfn>. This does not usually include its <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#mast" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § mast" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">masts</span></a></dfn> or any armament turrets.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="surface_warfare_officer/specialist" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Surface_warfare_insignia" title="Surface warfare insignia">surface warfare officer/specialist</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">U.S. Navy qualification and insignia for surface warfare training.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="surfboat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Surfboat" title="Surfboat">surfboat</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>surf boat</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">An <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#oar" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § oar" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">oar</span></a></dfn>-driven boat designed to enter the ocean from a beach in heavy surf or large waves. Surfboats often play a lifesaving or rescue role when rescuers need to reach victims of a mishap directly from a beach.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="surge" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">surge</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A vessel's transient motion in a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#fore" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § fore" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">fore</span></a></dfn> and <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#aft" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § aft" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">aft</span></a></dfn> direction.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;To let a small amount of <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#rope" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § rope" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">rope</span></a></dfn> on a bollard or winch drum pay out – a controlled slackening of a rope under tension.<sup id="cite_ref-PBO_10-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PBO-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="survey_vessel" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">survey vessel</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Any type of ship or boat that is used for mapping a body of water's bottom, <a href="/wiki/Benthic_zone" title="Benthic zone">benthic zone</a>, full water column, and surface for purposes of <a href="/wiki/Hydrography" title="Hydrography">hydrography</a>, general <a href="/wiki/Oceanography" title="Oceanography">oceanography</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marine_salvage" title="Marine salvage">marine salvage</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dredging" title="Dredging">dredging</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marine_archaeology" class="mw-redirect" title="Marine archaeology">marine archaeology</a>, or the study of marine habitats.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="s/v" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">S/V</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An abbreviation of "Sailing Vessel", used before the ship's name.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="swallow" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">swallow</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The gap in the shell of a block through which a line passes over a sheave.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_22-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="swatchway" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">swatchway</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A twisting channel navigable by shallow vessels at high water, generally found between <a href="/wiki/Sandbank" class="mw-redirect" title="Sandbank">sandbanks</a> (e.g. in the <a href="/wiki/Thames_Estuary" title="Thames Estuary">Thames Estuary</a>) or between a sandbank and the shore.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sway" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sway</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A vessel's lateral motion from side to side.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;(v.) To hoist, e.g. "sway up my dunnage".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199033_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199033-71">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sweep" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sweep</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1}.&#160;&#160;A long <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#oar" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § oar" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">oar</span></a></dfn> used to row, steer or maneuver an unpowered <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#lighter" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § lighter" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">lighter</span></a></dfn> or sailing vessel when there is no wind.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_22-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;(v.) To search for an underwater object using a towed submerged line or device which will snag on the target.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_22-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="swig" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">swig</dfn></dt>
<dt class="glossary" id="swigging" style="margin-top: -0.2em;"><dfn class="glossary">swigging</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To take up the last bit of slack on a line such as a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#halyard" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § halyard" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">halyard</span></a></dfn>, anchor line, or dockline by taking a single turn round a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#cleat" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § cleat" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">cleat</span></a></dfn> and alternately heaving on the rope above and below the cleat while keeping the tension on the tail.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="swimhead" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">swimhead</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">swim-head</span></p>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">swim-headed</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">Having a straight overhanging bow and stern.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_22-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="swimmie" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">swimmie</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>muffie</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#barge" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § barge" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">barge</span></a></dfn> with a square overhanging <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#bow" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § bow" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">bow</span></a></dfn>, such as a swimhead <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#lighter" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § lighter" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">lighter</span></a></dfn>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="sweat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">sweat</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A technique to finally tension a <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#halyard" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § halyard" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">halyard</span></a></dfn>, by pulling alternatively on the tail from the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#cleat" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § cleat" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">cleat</span></a></dfn> and at right angles on the taut standing line.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="swinging_the_compass" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">swinging the compass</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Measuring the accuracy in a ship's magnetic <a href="/wiki/Compass" title="Compass">compass</a> so its readings can be adjusted, often accomplished by turning the ship and taking bearings on reference points. Essentially synonymous with <i>swinging the ship</i> (<i>q.v.</i>).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="swinging_the_lamp" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">swinging the lamp</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Telling <a href="/wiki/Nautical_fiction" title="Nautical fiction">sea stories</a>. Refers to lamps slung from the <dfn id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms#deckhead" class="mw-redirect" title="Glossary of nautical terms"><span title="See entry at: Glossary of nautical terms § deckhead" style="color:inherit;" class="glossary-link">deckhead</span></a></dfn> that swing while at sea, and often used to describe a storyteller who is exaggerating.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="swinging_the_lead" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">swinging the lead</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Measuring the depth of water beneath a ship using a <a href="/wiki/Lead" title="Lead">lead</a>-weighted <a href="/wiki/Sounding_line" class="mw-redirect" title="Sounding line">sounding line</a>. Regarded as a relatively easy job.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Feigning illness, etc., in order to avoid a difficult job.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="swinging_the_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">swinging the ship</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Turning the ship and steadying her on various headings while taking bearings on reference points to measure the accuracy of her magnetic compass. Essentially synonymous with <i>swinging the compass</i> (<i>q.v.</i>).</dd>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1098327943"/>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="T">T</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: T">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<dt class="glossary" id="tabernacle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tabernacle</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>mast case</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A large bracket attached firmly to the <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span>, to which the foot of the <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> is fixed. It has two sides or cheeks and a bolt forming the pivot around which the mast is raised and lowered.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tack" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tack_(sailing)" title="Tack (sailing)">tack</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A leg of the route of a sailing vessel, particularly in relation to <a href="#tacking"><span title="See entry on this page at § tacking" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tacking</span></a> and to <a href="#starboard_tack"><span title="See entry on this page at § starboard tack" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">starboard tack</span></a> and <a href="#port_tack"><span title="See entry on this page at § port tack" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">port tack</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Another name for <span title="See entry on this page at § hard tack" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hard_tack" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hard tack</a></span>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;The front bottom corner of a <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;A <a href="#rope"><span title="See entry on this page at § rope" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rope</span></a> or purchase holding down the <span title="See entry on this page at § clew" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#clew" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">clew</a></span> of a course.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tacking" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tacking_(sailing)" title="Tacking (sailing)">tacking</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A sailing manouevre by which a sailing vessel whose desired course is into the wind (i.e. in the opposite direction from which the wind is blowing) turns its <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> toward and through the wind, such that the direction from which the wind fills the sails changes from one side of the boat to the other, thereby allowing progress in the desired direction. A series of tacking moves, effectively "zig-zagging" back and forth across the wind, is called <span title="See entry on this page at § beating" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#beating" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">beating</a></span>, and allows the vessel to sail directly upwind, which would otherwise be impossible.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115_72-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Another name for <span title="See entry on this page at § going about" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#going_about" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">going about</a></span>.</dd>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tacking.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Tacking.svg/220px-Tacking.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="89" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Tacking.svg/330px-Tacking.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Tacking.svg/440px-Tacking.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="360" data-file-height="145" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Tacking.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Overhead diagram of a <b><a href="#tacking"><span title="See entry on this page at § tacking" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tacking</span></a></b> manouevre. The red arrow is the direction of the wind; note how the side of the sail that is filled by the wind changes as the vessel turns its bow.</div></div></div>
<dt class="glossary" id="tacking_duels" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tacking duels</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">In sailboat racing, on an upwind leg of the race course, the complex manoeuvres of lead and overtaking boats to vie for the aerodynamic advantage of clear air. This results from the ongoing strategy of the lead boat's effort to keep the following boat(s) in the blanket of disturbed bad air he is creating.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tackle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tackle</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A pair of <span title="See entry on this page at § block" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#block" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">blocks</a></span> through which is rove a <a href="#rope"><span title="See entry on this page at § rope" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rope</span></a> to provide an advantageous purchase. Used for lifting heavy loads and to raise and <a href="#trim"><span title="See entry on this page at § trim" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">trim</span></a> <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sails</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tactical_diameter" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tactical_diameter" title="Tactical diameter">tactical diameter</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The perpendicular distance between a ship's course when the <span title="See entry on this page at § helm" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#helm" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">helm</a></span> is put <span title="See entry on this page at § hard over" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hard_over" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hard over</a></span> and her course when she has turned through 180 degrees; the ratio of the tactical diameter divided by the ship's <span title="See entry on this page at § length between perpendiculars" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#length_between_perpendiculars" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">length between perpendiculars</a></span> gives a dimensionless parameter that can be used to compare the manoeuvrability of ships.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="taffrail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Taffrail" title="Taffrail">taffrail</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#rail"><span title="See entry on this page at § rail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rail</span></a> at the <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a> of a boat that covers the head of the counter timbers.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tail</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The loose end of a rope that has been secured to a <a href="#winch"><span title="See entry on this page at § winch" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">winch</span></a> or a <span title="See entry on this page at § cleat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cleat" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cleat</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tailshaft" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Drive_shaft" title="Drive shaft">tailshaft</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A kind of metallic shafting (a rod of metal) to hold the propeller and connected to the power engine. When the tailshaft is moved, the propeller may also be moved for propulsion.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="taken_aback" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">taken aback</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An inattentive <span title="See entry on this page at § helmsman" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#helmsman" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">helmsman</a></span> might allow the dangerous situation to arise where the wind is blowing into the sails "backwards", causing a sudden (and possibly dangerous) shift in the position of the sails.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="taking_the_wind_out_of_his_sails" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">taking the wind out of his sails</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To sail in a way that steals the wind from another ship. Compare <i><a href="#overbear"><span title="See entry on this page at § overbear" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">overbear</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="taking_on_water" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">taking on water</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>taking water</b> and <b>taking in water</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">Said of a vessel, to fill with water slowly, either because of a leak or because of waves washing across the deck. The term can be used to describe water entering the vessel by waves washing over her <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> or <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a>, e.g., "The freighter <i>took water</i> over her bow," or "The motorboat <i>took water</i> over her stern." A vessel which continues to <i>take on water</i> eventually will sink.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tall_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tall_ship" title="Tall ship">tall ship</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A large, traditionally-rigged sailing vessel.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tally" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tally</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The operation of hauling <span title="See entry on this page at § aft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aft</a></span> the <a href="#sheets"><span title="See entry on this page at § sheets" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sheets</span></a>, or drawing them in the direction of the ship's <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tanker" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tanker_(ship)" title="Tanker (ship)">tanker</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="tank_ship"></span><span class="anchor" id="tankship"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>tank ship</b> or <b>tankship</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A ship designed to transport liquids in bulk.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="target_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Target_ship" title="Target ship">target ship</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel, typically an obsolete or captured <a href="#warship"><span title="See entry on this page at § warship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">warship</span></a>, used for naval gunnery practice or for weapons testing. The term includes both ships intended to be sunk and ships intended to survive and see repeated use as targets.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tartane" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tartane" title="Tartane">tartane</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>tartan</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A small, <span title="See entry on this page at § lateen rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lateen_rig" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lateen-rigged</a></span>, single-<a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">masted</span></a> sailing ship used in the Mediterranean for fishing and coastal trade from the 16th century to the late 19th century.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="task_force" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Task_Force" class="mw-redirect" title="Task Force">Task Force</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Any temporary naval organisation composed of particular ships, aircraft, submarines, military land forces, or shore service units, assigned to fulfill certain missions. Seemingly drawn originally from <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> heritage, the emphasis is placed on the individual commander of the unit, and references to "CTF" are common for "Commander Task Force".</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tattle_tale" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tattle tale</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Light cord attached to a mooring line at two points a few inches apart with a slack section in between (resembling an inchworm) to indicate when the line is stretching from the ship's rising with the tide. Obviously only used when moored to a fixed dock or pier and only on watches with a flood tide.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tell-tale" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tell-tale_(sailing)" title="Tell-tale (sailing)">tell-tale</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="tell-tail"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>tell-tail</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A light piece of string, yarn, rope, or plastic (often magnetic audio tape) attached to a <a href="#stay"><span title="See entry on this page at § stay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stay</span></a> or a <a href="#shroud"><span title="See entry on this page at § shroud" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">shroud</span></a> to indicate the local wind direction. They may also be attached to the surface and/or the <span title="See entry on this page at § leech" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#leech" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">leech</a></span> of a <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> to indicate the state of the air flow over the surface of the sail. They are referenced when optimizing the <a href="#trim"><span title="See entry on this page at § trim" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">trim</span></a> of the sails to achieve the best boat speed in the prevailing wind conditions. See <i><span title="See entry on this page at § dogvane" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#dogvane" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">dogvane</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tender" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Ship%27s_tender" title="Ship&#39;s tender">tender</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>ship's tender</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A type of naval <span title="See entry on this page at § auxiliary ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#auxiliary_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">auxiliary ship</a></span> designed to provide advanced basing services in undeveloped harbors to seaplanes, flying boats, torpedo boats, destroyers, or submarines.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A vessel used to provide transportation services for people and supplies to and from shore for a larger vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;A vessel used to maintain navigational aids, such as buoys and lighthouses.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="t.e.v._(or_tev)" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">T.E.V. (or TEV)</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="TEV"></span>
<dd class="glossary">A prefix for "<a href="/wiki/Turbo-electric" class="mw-redirect" title="Turbo-electric">turbo-electric</a> vessel", used before a ship<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s name.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="texas" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Texas_(steamboat)" title="Texas (steamboat)">texas</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A structure or section of a <a href="#steamboat"><span title="See entry on this page at § steamboat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">steamboat</span></a> that includes the <a href="#pilothouse"><span title="See entry on this page at § pilothouse" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">pilothouse</span></a> and the crew's quarters, located on the <span title="See entry on this page at § hurricane deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hurricane_deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hurricane deck</a></span>, in this case also called the <a href="#texas_deck"><span title="See entry on this page at § texas deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">texas deck</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="texas_deck" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">texas deck</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>hurricane deck</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> of a <a href="#steamboat"><span title="See entry on this page at § steamboat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">steamboat</span></a> on which its <a href="#texas"><span title="See entry on this page at § texas" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">texas</span></a> is located.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="thimble" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">thimble</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A round or heart-shaped grooved ring of iron inserted into an <span title="See entry on this page at § eye-splice" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#eye-splice" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">eye-splice</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955114_36-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955114-36">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="third_mate" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Third_mate" title="Third mate">third mate</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>third officer</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A licensed member of the deck department of a <a href="#merchant_ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § merchant ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">merchant ship</span></a>, typically fourth, or on some ocean liners fifth, in command; a watchkeeping officer, customarily also the ship's safety officer, responsible for the ship<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s firefighting equipment, <span title="See entry on this page at § lifeboat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lifeboat" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lifeboats</a></span>, and other emergency systems. Other duties of the third mate vary depending on the type of ship, its crewing, and other factors.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="third_officer" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">third officer</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#third_mate"><span title="See entry on this page at § third mate" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">third mate</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="thole_pin" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">thole pin</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="thole_pin"></span>
<dd class="glossary">A vertical wooden peg or pin inserted through the <span title="See entry on this page at § gunwale" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gunwale" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gunwale</a></span> to form a fulcrum for <a href="#oar"><span title="See entry on this page at § oar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">oars</span></a> when rowing. Often used in pairs to create a gap in which the oar is placed, but used singly if the oar has a thickened section pierced with a hole which takes the thole pin. See also <a href="#rowlock"><span title="See entry on this page at § rowlock" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rowlock</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="throat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">throat</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The forward top corner of a square <span title="See entry on this page at § fore-and-aft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#fore-and-aft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">fore-and-aft</a></span> <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The end of the <span title="See entry on this page at § gaff" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gaff" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gaff</a></span>, next to the <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199034_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199034-73">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="three_sheets_to_the_wind" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">three sheets to the wind</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">On a three-masted ship, having the <a href="#sheets"><span title="See entry on this page at § sheets" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sheets</span></a> of the three lower courses loose will result in the ship meandering aimlessly downwind. Also used to describe a sailor who has drunk strong spirits beyond his capacity.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="thunderboat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">thunderboat</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Alternative term for a <span title="See entry on this page at § hydroplane" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hydroplane" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hydroplane</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="thwart" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Thwart" title="Thwart">thwart</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Pronounced <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/θ/: &#39;th&#39; in &#39;thigh&#39;">θ</span><span title="&#39;w&#39; in &#39;wind&#39;">w</span><span title="/ɔːr/: &#39;ar&#39; in &#39;war&#39;">ɔːr</span><span title="&#39;t&#39; in &#39;tie&#39;">t</span></span>/</a></span></span>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A bench seat across the width of an open boat.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tier" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tier</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Vessels moored alongside each other offshore.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tiller" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tiller" title="Tiller">tiller</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A lever used for steering, attached to the top of the <a href="#rudder_stock"><span title="See entry on this page at § rudder stock" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rudder stock</span></a>. Used mainly on smaller vessels, such as <span title="See entry on this page at § dinghy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#dinghy" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">dinghies</a></span> and rowing boats.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tilt_boat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tilt boat</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A square sail <span title="See entry on this page at § ferry" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#ferry" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">ferry</a></span> operating out of Gravesend. Not less than 15 tons, carrying no more that 37 passengers, it had 5 oarsmen <span title="See entry on this page at § afore" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#afore" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">afore</a></span> the mast.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarr195137_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarr195137-75">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="timber_drogher" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">timber drogher</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Another name for a <span title="See entry on this page at § disposable ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#disposable_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">disposable ship</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="timber_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">timber ship</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Another name for a <span title="See entry on this page at § disposable ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#disposable_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">disposable ship</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="timoneer" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">timoneer</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A name given, on particular occasions, to the <a href="#steersman"><span title="See entry on this page at § steersman" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">steersman</span></a> of a ship. From the French <i>timonnier</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tin_can" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tin can</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">United States Navy slang for a <span title="See entry on this page at § destroyer" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#destroyer" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">destroyer</a></span>; often shortened to <i>can</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tinclad" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tinclad</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A lightly armored steam-powered river <span title="See entry on this page at § gunboat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gunboat" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gunboat</a></span> used by the United States Navy during the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">American Civil War</a> (1861–1865). Also called a <i>light draft</i>. A tinclad had thin iron armor, or in some cases thick wooden bulwarks rather than armor, sufficient to protect her machinery spaces and pilothouse against rifle fire but not against artillery fire. A tinclad contrasted with an <span title="See entry on this page at § ironclad" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#ironclad" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">ironclad</a></span>, which had armor thick enough for protection against artillery fire.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tingle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tingle</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A thin temporary patch.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="toe-rail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">toe-rail</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A low strip running around the edge of the <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> like a low <span title="See entry on this page at § bulwark" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bulwark" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bulwark</a></span>. It may be shortened or have gaps in it to allow water to flow off the deck.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="toe_the_line" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">toe the line</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="toe_the_mark"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>toe the mark</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">At parade, sailors and soldiers were required to stand in line, their toes in line with a seam of the <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tompion" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tampion" title="Tampion">tompion</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>tampion</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A block of wood inserted into the barrel of a gun on a 19th-century <a href="#warship"><span title="See entry on this page at § warship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">warship</span></a> to keep out the sea spray; also used for covers for the ends of the barrels of the guns on more modern ships, the larger of which are often adorned with the ship's crest or other decoration.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tonnage" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tonnage" title="Tonnage">tonnage</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Any of various measures of the size or cargo-carrying capacity of a ship in terms of weight or volume.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Builder%27s_Old_Measurement" title="Builder&#39;s Old Measurement">Builder's Old Measurement</a>, also <i>tons burden</i>: a volumetric measurement of cubic capacity used to calculate the cargo capacity of a ship, used in England and later the United Kingdom, from approximately 1650 to 1849 and in the United States from 1789 to 1864. It estimated the tonnage of a vessel based on her length and maximum <span title="See entry on this page at § beam" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#beam" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">beam</a></span>. The British formula yielded a slightly higher value than the U.S. formula.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Deadweight_tonnage" title="Deadweight tonnage">Deadweight tonnage</a>: the total weight a vessel can carry, exclusive of the mass of the vessel itself.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Displacement_(ship)" title="Displacement (ship)">Displacement</a> tonnage: the total weight of a vessel.</dd>
