<dd class="glossary">5.&#160;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Gross_register_tonnage" title="Gross register tonnage">Gross register tonnage</a>: the total internal volume of a vessel, with one gross register ton equal to 100 <a href="/wiki/Cubic_foot" title="Cubic foot">cubic feet</a> (2.8316846592 <a href="/wiki/Cubic_meter" class="mw-redirect" title="Cubic meter">cubic meters</a>).</dd>
<dd class="glossary">6.&#160;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Gross_tonnage" title="Gross tonnage">Gross tonnage</a>: a function of the volume of all of a ship<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s internal spaces.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">7.&#160;&#160;Lightship or lightweight tonnage: the weight of a ship without any fuel, cargo, supplies, water, passengers, etc. on board.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">8.&#160;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Net_register_tonnage" title="Net register tonnage">Net register tonnage</a>: the volume of cargo a vessel can carry.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">9.&#160;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Net_tonnage" title="Net tonnage">Net tonnage</a>: the volume of all cargo spaces on a ship.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">10.&#160;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Thames_Measurement" title="Thames Measurement">Thames Measurement</a> tonnage: the volume of a small vessel, calculated based on her length and beam.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="top" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Top_(sailing_ship)" title="Top (sailing ship)">top</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The platform at the upper end of each (lower) <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> of a <a href="#square-rigged"><span title="See entry on this page at § square-rigged" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square-rigged</span></a> ship, typically one-fourth to one-third of the way up the mast. The main purpose of a top is to anchor the <a href="#shrouds"><span title="See entry on this page at § shrouds" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">shrouds</span></a> of the <a href="#topmast"><span title="See entry on this page at § topmast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">topmast</span></a> that extend above it. See also <i><span title="See entry on this page at § fighting top" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#fighting_top" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">fighting top</a></span></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199035_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199035-76">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="topgallant" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">topgallant</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> or <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sails</span></a> above the <a href="#top"><span title="See entry on this page at § top" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tops</span></a>. See <i><a href="#topgallant_mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § topgallant mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">topgallant mast</span></a></i> and <i><a href="#topgallant_sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § topgallant sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">topgallant sail</span></a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115_72-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tophamper" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tophamper</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A collective term for the <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">masts</span></a>, <a href="#yard"><span title="See entry on this page at § yard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yards</span></a>, <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sails</span></a>, and <a href="#rigging"><span title="See entry on this page at § rigging" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rigging</span></a> of a sailing ship, or for similarly insubstantial structures above the upper <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> of any ship.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Unnecessary <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spars</span></a> and rigging kept aloft on a vessel′s masts.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="topman" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">topman</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A crewmember stationed in a <a href="#top"><span title="See entry on this page at § top" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">top</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="topmast" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Topmast" title="Topmast">topmast</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The second section of the <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> above the <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span>; formerly the upper mast, later surmounted by the <a href="#topgallant_mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § topgallant mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">topgallant mast</span></a>; carrying the <a href="#topsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § topsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">topsails</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115_72-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="topmast_pole" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">topmast pole</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Part of the <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spar</span></a> between the hounds and the truck.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="topping_lift" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Topping_lift" title="Topping lift">topping lift</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A line that is part of the <a href="#rigging"><span title="See entry on this page at § rigging" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rigging</span></a> on a sailing boat; it applies upward force on a <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spar</span></a> or <span title="See entry on this page at § boom" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#boom" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">boom</a></span>. The most common topping lift on a modern sailing boat is attached to the boom.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199035_76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199035-76">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="topsail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Topsail" title="Topsail">topsail</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The second <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> (counting from the bottom) up a <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a>. These may be either <a href="#square"><span title="See entry on this page at § square" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square</span></a> sails or <span title="See entry on this page at § fore-and-aft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#fore-and-aft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">fore-and-aft</a></span> ones, in which case they often "fill in" between the mast and the <span title="See entry on this page at § gaff" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gaff" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gaff</a></span> of the sail below.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="topsail_schooner" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">topsail schooner</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#schooner"><span title="See entry on this page at § schooner" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">schooner</span></a> that sets a square <a href="#topsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § topsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">topsail</span></a> on yards carried on the foremast. A <a href="#topgallant"><span title="See entry on this page at § topgallant" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">topgallant</span></a> may also be set above the topsail. (The term does not apply to a schooner setting just fore and aft topsails above gaff sails.) There is some terminological variation, both over time and place, on what square sails a vessel may set and still be termed a schooner.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECunliffe201626_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECunliffe201626-78">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="topsides" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Topsides" title="Topsides">topsides</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The part of the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> between the <a href="#waterline"><span title="See entry on this page at § waterline" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">waterline</span></a> and the <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span>. See also <i><span title="See entry on this page at § above-water hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#above-water_hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">above-water hull</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="torpedo" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Torpedo" title="Torpedo">torpedo</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Prior to about 1900, the term for a variety of explosive devices designed for use in water, including <a href="#mine"><span title="See entry on this page at § mine" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mines</span></a>, <a href="#spar_torpedo"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar torpedo" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spar torpedoes</span></a>, and, after the mid-19th century, "automotive", "automobile", "locomotive", or "fish" torpedoes (self-propelled weapons which fit the modern definition of <i>torpedo</i>).</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Since about 1900, a term used exclusively for a self-propelled weapon with an explosive warhead, launched above or below the water surface, propelled underwater towards a target, and designed to detonate either on contact with its target or in proximity to it.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="torpedo_net" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Torpedo_net" title="Torpedo net">torpedo net</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A heavy net a ship could deploy around herself using booms or <a href="#spar"><span title="See entry on this page at § spar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spar</span></a>s while at anchor, moored, or otherwise stationary to protect herself from <a href="#torpedo"><span title="See entry on this page at § torpedo" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">torpedo</span></a> attack. A torpedo net hung at a distance from the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> sufficient to detonate a torpedo without significant damage to the ship. Torpedo nets first appeared in the late 1870s and were used through the <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> era, and they were used again during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. </dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="touch_and_go" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">touch and go</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The bottom of the ship touching the bottom, but not <span title="See entry on this page at § grounding" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#grounding" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">grounding</a></span>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Stopping at a <span title="See entry on this page at § dock" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#dock" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">dock</a></span> or <a href="#pier"><span title="See entry on this page at § pier" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">pier</span></a> for a very short time without tying up, to let off or take on crew or goods.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;The practice of aircraft on <span title="See entry on this page at § aircraft carrier" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aircraft_carrier" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aircraft carriers</a></span> touching the carrier <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> and taking off again without dropping hooks.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="towing" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">towing</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The operation of drawing a vessel forward by means of long lines.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="traffic_separation_scheme" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Traffic_separation_scheme" title="Traffic separation scheme">traffic separation scheme</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Shipping corridors marked by buoys that separate incoming from outgoing vessels. Sometimes improperly called <i><a href="#sea_lanes"><span title="See entry on this page at § sea lanes" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sea lanes</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="trailboard" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Trailboard" title="Trailboard">trailboard</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A decorative board at the <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> of a vessel, sometimes bearing the vessel's name.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="training_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">training ship</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A ship used to train students as <a href="#sailor"><span title="See entry on this page at § sailor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sailors</span></a>, especially a ship employed by a navy or coast guard to train future officers. The term refers both to ships used for training at sea and to old, immobile <span title="See entry on this page at § hulk" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hulk" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hulks</a></span> used to house classrooms.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tramp_freighter" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tramp freighter</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <span title="See entry on this page at § cargo ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cargo_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cargo ship</a></span> engaged in the <a href="#tramp_trade"><span title="See entry on this page at § tramp trade" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tramp trade</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tramp_steamer" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tramp steamer</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#steamship"><span title="See entry on this page at § steamship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">steamship</span></a> engaged in the <a href="#tramp_trade"><span title="See entry on this page at § tramp trade" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tramp trade</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tramp_trade" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tramp_trade" title="Tramp trade">tramp trade</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The shipping trade on the spot market in which the vessels involved do not have a fixed schedule or itinerary or published <a href="#port_of_call"><span title="See entry on this page at § port of call" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ports of call</span></a>. This contrasts with freight liner service, in which vessels make regular, scheduled runs between published ports.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tramper" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tramper</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Any vessel engaged in the <a href="#tramp_trade"><span title="See entry on this page at § tramp trade" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tramp trade</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="transmitting_station" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">transmitting station</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">British term for a room located in the interior of a ship containing computers and other specialised equipment needed to calculate the range and bearing of a target from information gathered by the ship's spotters and range finders. These were designated "plotting rooms" by the United States Navy.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="transom" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Transom_(nautical)" title="Transom (nautical)">transom</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A lateral member fastened inside the <a href="#sternpost"><span title="See entry on this page at § sternpost" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sternpost</span></a>, to which the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> and deckplanks are fitted.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The <span title="See entry on this page at § aft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aft</a></span> "wall" of the <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a>; often the part to which an outboard unit or the drive portion of a <a href="#sterndrive"><span title="See entry on this page at § sterndrive" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sterndrive</span></a> is attached.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;A more or less flat surface across the stern of a vessel. <span title="See entry on this page at § dinghy" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#dinghy" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">Dinghies</a></span> tend to have almost vertical transoms, whereas <a href="#yacht"><span title="See entry on this page at § yacht" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yachts</span></a>' transoms may be raked forward or aft.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="transport" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">transport</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#troopship"><span title="See entry on this page at § troopship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">troopship</span></a></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="travellers" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Mechanical_traveller" class="mw-redirect" title="Mechanical traveller">travellers</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Small fittings that slide on a track, rod, or line. The most common use is for the inboard end of the <a href="#mainsheet"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainsheet" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainsheet</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A more esoteric form of traveller consists of "slight iron rings, encircling the <span title="See entry on this page at § backstay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#backstay" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">backstays</a></span>, which are used for hoisting the <a href="#topgallant"><span title="See entry on this page at § topgallant" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">top-gallant</span></a> <a href="#yard"><span title="See entry on this page at § yard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yards</span></a>, and confining them to the backstays".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199035_76-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199035-76">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">An iron ring that moves on the main horse on a sailing barge. It is fitted with an eye onto which is hooked the main sheet, of the loose-footed <a href="#mainsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainsail</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="trawler" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">trawler</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;<i><a href="/wiki/Commercial_trawler" class="mw-redirect" title="Commercial trawler">Commercial trawler</a></i>: a fishing boat that uses a <a href="/wiki/Trawling" title="Trawling">trawl net</a> or <a href="/wiki/Seine_fishing" title="Seine fishing">dragnet</a> to catch fish.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A fisherman who uses a trawl net.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;<i><a href="/wiki/Naval_trawler" title="Naval trawler">Naval trawler</a></i>: a converted trawler, or a boat built in that style, used for naval purposes.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;<i><a href="/wiki/Recreational_trawler" title="Recreational trawler">Recreational trawler</a></i>: a pleasure boat built in the style of a trawler.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="treenail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Treenail" title="Treenail">treenail</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>trenail</b>, <b>trennel</b>, or <b>trunnel</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A wooden peg, pin, or dowel used to fasten pieces of wood together, such as the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span>, <span title="See entry on this page at § gunwale" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gunwale" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gunwales</a></span>, <a href="#thwart"><span title="See entry on this page at § thwart" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">thwarts</span></a>, etc.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199035_76-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199035-76">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="trial_trip" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">trial trip</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A (usually short) voyage for a new ship to test its capabilities and ensure that everything is functioning correctly. A new ship will usually have one or more trial trips before embarking on its <a href="#maiden_voyage"><span title="See entry on this page at § maiden voyage" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">maiden voyage</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="triangular_trade" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Triangular_trade" title="Triangular trade">triangular trade</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A historical term for a pattern of trade among three <a href="#port"><span title="See entry on this page at § port" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ports</span></a> or regions in which each port or region imports goods from one of the other two ports or regions in which there is no market for its exports, thus rectifying trade imbalances between the three ports or regions as well as allowing vessels to take the best advantage of prevailing winds and currents along the three trade routes. The best known example is the Atlantic triangular trade pattern of the late 16th through the early 19th centuries, in which vessels carried finished goods from northeastern North America or Europe to Africa, slaves from Africa to the Americas, and cash crops and raw materials from the Americas to either northeastern North America or Europe. </dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="trice" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">trice</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To lift up something by means of a <a href="#rope"><span title="See entry on this page at § rope" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rope</span></a> running through a block set above it, to get it out of the way. Most commonly used in tricing up the tack of a loose-footed gaff sai to reduce sail area and (sometimes) to give better visibility to the helmsman.<sup id="cite_ref-PBO_10-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PBO-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975272_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975272-82">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="trick" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">trick</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A period of time spent at the wheel, e.g. "my trick's over".</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="trim" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">trim</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The relationship of a ship's <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> to the <a href="#waterline"><span title="See entry on this page at § waterline" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">waterline</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Adjustments made to <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sails</span></a> to maximize their efficiency.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="trimaran" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Trimaran" title="Trimaran">trimaran</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel with three <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hulls</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="trimmer" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">trimmer</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="coal_trimmer"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Sometimes <b>coal trimmer</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A person responsible for ensuring that a vessel remains "in trim" (that the cargo and fuel are evenly balanced). An important task on a coal-fired vessel, as it could get "out of trim" as coal is consumed.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tripod_mast" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tripod_mast" title="Tripod mast">tripod mast</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> introduced aboard <a href="#warship"><span title="See entry on this page at § warship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">warships</span></a> in the first decade of the 20th century, consisting of three large cylindrical tubes or columns supporting a raised platform for <span title="See entry on this page at § lookout" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lookout" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lookouts</a></span> and fire control equipment and later for <a href="/wiki/Radar" title="Radar">radar</a> antennas and receivers. In succeeding decades, tripod masts replaced the earlier pole masts and <span title="See entry on this page at § lattice mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lattice_mast" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lattice masts</a></span>. Tripod masts persisted in some navies until the 1960s, when plated-in structures began to replace them, and in other navies until the early 2000s, when <a href="#stealth_ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § stealth ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stealth</span></a> designs began to move away from any type of open mast.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="troller" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">troller</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A fishing vessel rigged to fish by <a href="/wiki/Trolling_(fishing)" title="Trolling (fishing)">trolling</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="trooping" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">trooping</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Operating as a <a href="#troopship"><span title="See entry on this page at § troopship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">troopship</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="troopship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Troopship" title="Troopship">troopship</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="troop_ship"></span><span class="anchor" id="troop_transport"></span><span class="anchor" id="trooper"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>troop ship</b>, <b>troop transport</b>, or <b>trooper</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">Any ship used to carry soldiers. Troopships are not specially designed for military operations and, unlike <span title="See entry on this page at § landing ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#landing_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">landing ships</a></span>, cannot land troops directly onto a shore; instead they unload troops at a <span title="See entry on this page at § harbor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#harbor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">harbor</a></span> or onto smaller vessels for transportation to shore.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="truck" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Truck_(rigging)" title="Truck (rigging)">truck</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A circular disc or rectangle of wood or a wooden ball- or bun-shaped cap near or at the top of a wooden mast, usually with holes or sheaves in it through which signal <span title="See entry on this page at § halyard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#halyard" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">halyards</a></span> can be passed. Trucks are also used on wooden flagpoles to keep them from splitting. The <i>main truck</i> is located on the <a href="#main_mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § main mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">main mast</span></a>, the <i>mizzen truck</i> on the <a href="#mizzen_mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mizzen mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mizzen mast</span></a>, and so on.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115_72-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A temporary or emergency place for a <span title="See entry on this page at § lookout" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lookout" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lookout</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="true_bearing" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">true bearing</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An <span title="See entry on this page at § absolute bearing" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#absolute_bearing" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">absolute bearing</a></span> using <a href="#true_north"><span title="See entry on this page at § true north" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">true north</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="true_north" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/True_north" title="True north">true north</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The direction of the geographical <a href="/wiki/North_Pole" title="North Pole">North Pole</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="truncated_counter" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Truncated_counter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Truncated counter (page does not exist)">truncated counter</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A counter <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a> that has been truncated to provide a kind of <a href="#transom"><span title="See entry on this page at § transom" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">transom</span></a>. It may have windows, serving a large <span title="See entry on this page at § aft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aft</a></span> stateroom. Popular on larger cruising yachts.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="truss" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">truss</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The rope or iron used to keep the center of a <a href="#yard"><span title="See entry on this page at § yard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yard</span></a> to the <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="trysail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Trysail" title="Trysail">trysail</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b><a href="#spencer"><span title="See entry on this page at § spencer" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spencer</span></a></b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A small, strong, <span title="See entry on this page at § fore-and-aft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#fore-and-aft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">fore-and-aft</a></span> <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> set <span title="See entry on this page at § abaft" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#abaft" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">abaft</a></span> (behind) the <a href="#mainmast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mainmast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mainmast</span></a> or other mast of a sailing vessel in heavy weather.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115_72-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tugboat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tugboat" title="Tugboat">tugboat</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>tug</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A boat that manoeuvers other vessels by pushing or towing them. Tugs are powerful for their size and strongly built, and some are ocean-going.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tumblehome" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tumblehome" title="Tumblehome">tumblehome</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> shape, when viewed in a transverse section, in which the widest part of the hull is someway below <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> level.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tuna_clipper" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tuna clipper</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A fishing boat based on the <a href="/wiki/United_States_West_Coast" class="mw-redirect" title="United States West Coast">United States West Coast</a> and used for commercial tuna fishing. A typical tuna clipper is diesel-powered, has her <span title="See entry on this page at § deckhouse" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deckhouse" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deckhouse</a></span> forward and her bait tanks aft, and is outfitted with iron racks around her <a href="#stem"><span title="See entry on this page at § stem" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stem</span></a> from which her crew uses heavy <a href="/wiki/Bamboo" title="Bamboo">bamboo</a> poles to fish for tuna.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="turn" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Turn_(knot)" title="Turn (knot)">turn</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A knot passing behind or around an object.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="turn_to_(turn_two)" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">Turn To (Turn Two)</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A term meaning "get to work", often hand-signed by two fingers and a hand motion in turning fashion.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="turnbuckle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Turnbuckle" title="Turnbuckle">turnbuckle</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><span title="See entry on this page at § bottlescrew" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bottlescrew" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bottlescrew</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="turret" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Gun_turret" title="Gun turret">turret</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Originally (in the mid-to-late 19th century), a rotating, enclosed, armored, cylindrical box with guns that fired through gunports. Turret-equipped ships contrasted sharply with those equipped with <span title="See entry on this page at § barbette" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#barbette" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">barbettes</a></span>, which in the second half of the 19th century were open-topped armored rings over which rotating gun(s) mounted on a turntable could fire.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;Since the late 19th century, an enclosed, armored, rotating gunhouse mounted above a barbette, with the gun(s) and their rotating turntable mounted in the barbette protected by the gunhouse; in 20th- and 21st-century usage, this generally is any armored, rotating gun installation on a <a href="#warship"><span title="See entry on this page at § warship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">warship</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="turtleback_deck" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">turtleback deck</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A weather deck that has a distinct convex rounded over shape, similar to the back of a turtle. Used on ships of the <a href="/wiki/Whaleback" title="Whaleback">whaleback</a> type and on the forward weather deck of <a href="/wiki/Torpedo_boat" title="Torpedo boat">torpedo boats</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-Abbot_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abbot-83">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="turtling" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Turtling_(sailing)" title="Turtling (sailing)">turtling</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">In <a href="/wiki/Dinghy_sailing" title="Dinghy sailing">dinghy sailing</a> especially (but also in other boats), a boat is said to be "turtling" or to "turn turtle" when the boat is fully inverted with the <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> pointing near vertically downwards, but may remain floating.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;A&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Oxford_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford-86">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-OxfordDictionaries_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OxfordDictionaries-87">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tweendeck" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tweendeck" class="mw-redirect" title="Tweendeck">tweendeck</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> on a general <span title="See entry on this page at § cargo ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cargo_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cargo ship</a></span> located between the <a href="#main_deck"><span title="See entry on this page at § main deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">main deck</span></a> (or <a href="#weather_deck"><span title="See entry on this page at § weather deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">weather deck</span></a>) and the <span title="See entry on this page at § hold" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hold" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hold</a></span> space. A general cargo ship may have one or two tweendecks (or none at all).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tweendeck_space" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tweendeck space</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The space on a <a href="#tweendeck"><span title="See entry on this page at § tweendeck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tweendeck</span></a> available for carrying cargo or other uses.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tweendecker" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Tweendecker" title="Tweendecker">tweendecker</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A general <span title="See entry on this page at § cargo ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cargo_ship" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cargo ship</a></span> equipped with one or more <a href="#tweendeck"><span title="See entry on this page at § tweendeck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tweendecks</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="two_six_heave" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Two_six_heave" title="Two six heave">two six heave</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A command used to co-ordinate a group of people pulling on a rope. Originally a sailing navy term referring to the two members of a gun crew (numbers two and six) who ran out the gun by pulling on the ropes that secured it in place.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="two_blocks" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">two blocks</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">When the two <span title="See entry on this page at § block" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#block" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">blocks</a></span> in a <a href="#tackle"><span title="See entry on this page at § tackle" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tackle</span></a> have become so close that no further movement is possible as in chock-a-block.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="tye" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">tye</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A chain or rope used for hoisting or lowering a <a href="#yard"><span title="See entry on this page at § yard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yard</span></a>. A tye runs from the horizontal center of a given yard to a corresponding <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> and from there down to a <a href="#tackle"><span title="See entry on this page at § tackle" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tackle</span></a>. Sometimes more specifically called a <i>chain tye</i> or a <i>rope tye</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115_72-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1098327943"/>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="U">U</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: U">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<dt class="glossary" id="unassisted_sailing" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Unassisted_sailing" title="Unassisted sailing">unassisted sailing</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Any sailing voyage, usually single-handed, with no intermediate stops or physical assistance from external sources.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="under_the_weather" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">under the weather</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Serving a <a href="#watch"><span title="See entry on this page at § watch" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">watch</span></a> on the <a href="#weather_side"><span title="See entry on this page at § weather side" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">weather side</span></a> of the ship, exposed to wind and spray.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="underway" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">underway</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>under way</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">(of a vessel) At sea; i.e. not at <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor</a></span>, made <span title="See entry on this page at § fast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#fast" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">fast</a></span> to the shore, or <span title="See entry on this page at § aground" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#aground" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">aground</a></span>. This definition has legal importance in the <a href="/wiki/International_Regulations_for_Preventing_Collisions_at_Sea" title="International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea">International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="underwater_hull" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">underwater hull</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="underwater_ship"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>underwater ship</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The underwater section of a vessel beneath the <a href="#waterline"><span title="See entry on this page at § waterline" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">waterline</span></a>, normally not visible except when in <span title="See entry on this page at § drydock" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#drydock" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">drydock</a></span> or, historically, when <span title="See entry on this page at § careened" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#careened" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">careened</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="underway_replenishment" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Underway_replenishment" title="Underway replenishment">underway replenishment</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A method employed by navies to transfer fuel, munitions, and stores from one ship to another while <a href="#underway"><span title="See entry on this page at § underway" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">underway</span></a>. Sometimes abbreviated as <i>UNREP</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="u.n.p.o.c." style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">U.N.P.O.C.</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An abbreviation for "Unable to navigate, probably on course"; a 19th-century term used in log books of vessels left without accurate <a href="/wiki/Navigation" title="Navigation">navigational</a> guidance due to poor visibility and/or proximity to the <a href="/wiki/North_Pole" title="North Pole">North Pole</a> (where magnetic compasses are difficult or impossible to use). Dropped out of common usage in the 1950s with improvements in maritime navigational aids.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="unreeve" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">unreeve</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To pull a rope from a <a href="#sheave"><span title="See entry on this page at § sheave" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sheave</span></a> or <span title="See entry on this page at § block" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#block" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">block</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="unship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">unship</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;To remove from a vessel.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;To remove an <a href="#oar"><span title="See entry on this page at § oar" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">oar</span></a> or <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mast</span></a> from its normal position.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="up-and-down" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">up-and-down</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The description given to the position of the <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor chain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor_chain" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor chain</a></span>, usually used when the anchor is being raised and indicating that the chain has been hauled in tightly such that the vessel is floating directly above the anchor, which is just about to be broken out of the ground. Used more rarely to refer to a situation where the anchor chain is slack and hangs vertically down from the <span title="See entry on this page at § hawsepipe" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hawsepipe" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hawsepipe</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_22-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="up-behind" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">up-behind</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An order to <a href="#slacking"><span title="See entry on this page at § slacking" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">slack</span></a> off quickly and run slack to a belaying point. This order is given when a line or wire has been stopped off or falls have been <span title="See entry on this page at § four-in-hand" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#four-in-hand" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">four-in-hand</a></span> and the hauling part is to be belayed.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="upbound" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Upbound" class="mw-redirect" title="Upbound">upbound</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Traveling upstream, against the current.<sup id="cite_ref-USCG_NavRules_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USCG_NavRules-89">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;In the <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a> region, traveling westward (terminology used by the <a href="/wiki/Saint_Lawrence_Seaway_Development_Corporation" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation">Saint Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-SLSDC_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SLSDC-90">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="uppers" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">uppers</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>peaks</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The <span title="See entry on this page at § brails" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#brails" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">brails</a></span> above the <a href="#mains"><span title="See entry on this page at § mains" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">mains</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="upper-yardmen" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">upper-yardmen</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Specially selected personnel destined for high office.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup></dd>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1098327943"/>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="V">V</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: V">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<dt class="glossary" id="v-hull" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/V-hull_(boat)" title="V-hull (boat)">V-hull</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The shape of a boat or ship in which the sections of the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> bottom slope downward in a straight line to the <span title="See entry on this page at § keel" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#keel" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">keel</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="vang" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Vang_(spritsail)" class="mw-redirect" title="Vang (spritsail)">vang</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">line</a></span> leading from the <span title="See entry on this page at § gaff" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gaff" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gaff</a></span> to either side of the <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span>, used to prevent the gaff from sagging.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115_72-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;One of a pair of ropes leading from the deck to the head of a <a href="#spritsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § spritsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spritsail</span></a>. It steadies the <a href="#sprit"><span title="See entry on this page at § sprit" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sprit</span></a> and can be used to control the sail's performance during a <a href="#tack"><span title="See entry on this page at § tack" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tack</span></a>. The vang fall blocks are mounted slightly <span title="See entry on this page at § afore" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#afore" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">afore</a></span> the main horse while rolling vangs are extra <a href="#preventer"><span title="See entry on this page at § preventer" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">preventers</span></a> which lead forward to keep the sail to <span title="See entry on this page at § leeward" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#leeward" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">leeward</a></span> in heavy weather.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;An abbreviation of <i><span title="See entry on this page at § boom vang" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#boom_vang" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">boom vang</a></span></i>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;An abbreviation of <i><span title="See entry on this page at § gaff vang" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gaff_vang" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gaff vang</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="vanishing_angle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">vanishing angle</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The maximum degree of <span title="See entry on this page at § heel" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#heel" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">heel</a></span> after which a vessel becomes unable to return to an upright position.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="vedette" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Vedette_(sentry)" title="Vedette (sentry)">vedette</a></dfn></dt> <p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>vedette boat</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A small naval patrol boat used for scouting enemy forces.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="veer_away" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">veer away</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To let go a <a href="#rope"><span title="See entry on this page at § rope" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rope</span></a> gently.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199036_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199036-91">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="vertical_replenishment" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Vertical_replenishment" title="Vertical replenishment">vertical replenishment</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A method of supply of seaborne vessels by helicopter. Abbreviated VERTREP.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="very_good" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">very good</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An affirmative response given by a senior to the report of a junior, e.g. if the <span title="See entry on this page at § helmsman" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#helmsman" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">helmsman</a></span> reports, "Rudder is amidship, sir," an officer might respond, "Very good."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975_22-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975-22">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="very_well" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">very well</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An affirmative response given by a senior to the report of a junior, e.g. if the helmsman reports, "Rudder is amidship, sir," an officer might respond, "Very well."</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="vessel" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">vessel</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Any craft designed for transportation on water, such as a <a href="#ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ship</span></a> or <span title="See entry on this page at § boat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#boat" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">boat</a></span>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="vessel_of_opportunity" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">vessel of opportunity</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Vessel not normally used for a specific function, but available and suitable for temporary application, often requiring temporary fitting or loading of necessary equipment.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="viol" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">viol</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>voyl</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">A large rope used to unmoor or heave up the <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199036_91-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199036-91">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="voice_pipe" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">voice pipe</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>voice tube</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><span title="See entry on this page at § communication tube" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#communication_tube" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">communication tube</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="voyage" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">voyage</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A long journey by <a href="#ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ship</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;To go on such a journey.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="voyl" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">voyl</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#viol"><span title="See entry on this page at § viol" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">viol</span></a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199036_91-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199036-91">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1098327943"/>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="W">W</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: W">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<dt class="glossary" id="waft" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">waft</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Another name for a <a href="#signal_flag"><span title="See entry on this page at § signal flag" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">signal flag</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="waist" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">waist</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The central <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> of a ship between the <span title="See entry on this page at § forecastle" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#forecastle" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">forecastle</a></span> and the <a href="#quarterdeck"><span title="See entry on this page at § quarterdeck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">quarterdeck</span></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="waist_clothes" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Waist_clothes" title="Waist clothes">waist clothes</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>armings</b> or <b>fights</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">Colored cloths or sheets hung around the outside of a ship's upper works, both fore and aft, and before the <span title="See entry on this page at § cubbridge" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cubbridge" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cubbridge</a></span> heads, used as an adornment during ceremonious occasions and as a visual screen during times of action in order to protect the men aboard.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wake" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Wake_(physics)" title="Wake (physics)">wake</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Turbulence in the water behind a moving vessel. Not to be confused with <a href="#wash"><span title="See entry on this page at § wash" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">wash</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wale" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Wale_(ship_part)" title="Wale (ship part)">wale</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A thicker <a href="#strake"><span title="See entry on this page at § strake" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">strake</span></a>, consisting of a wooden plank or group of planks, in the outer skin of the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span>, running in a fore-and-aft direction, to provide extra stiffening in selected regions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESteffy2013_3-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESteffy2013-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wardroom" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Wardroom" title="Wardroom">wardroom</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;The living quarters of a naval ship that are designated for the use of <a href="/wiki/Commissioned_officer" class="mw-redirect" title="Commissioned officer">commissioned officers</a> other than the captain.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A collective term for the commissioned officers of a naval ship excluding her captain; e.g. "The captain rarely referred to his wardroom for advice, and this led to their discontent".</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="warm_the_bell" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">warm the bell</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Royal Navy slang from the Age of Sail for doing something unnecessarily or unjustifiably early.
