Holding a half-hour <a href="#marine_sandglass"><span title="See entry on this page at § marine sandglass" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">marine sandglass</span></a> used until the early 19th century to time watches under one's coat or in one's hand to warm it allegedly expanded the glass′s neck to allow the sand to flow more quickly, justifying ringing the bell rung every half-hour to announce the passage of time on watch earlier than if the glass was cold, hence <i>warming the bell</i> and shortening the length of the watch.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="warp" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">warp</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;To move a vessel by hauling on a <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">line</a></span> or cable that is fastened to an <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor</a></span> or <a href="#pier"><span title="See entry on this page at § pier" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">pier</span></a>, especially so as to move a sailing ship through a confined or restricted space such as in a harbour.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199037_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199037-94">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A line or cable used in warping a ship.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;The length of the <a href="#shroud"><span title="See entry on this page at § shroud" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">shrouds</span></a> from the <span title="See entry on this page at § bolster" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bolster" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bolster</a></span> to the <span title="See entry on this page at § deadeye" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deadeye" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deadeye</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199037_94-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199037-94">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wash" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">wash</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The waves created by a moving vessel. Not to be confused with <a href="#wake"><span title="See entry on this page at § wake" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">wake</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="washstrake" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">washstrake</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="washstrake"></span>
<dd class="glossary">An additional <a href="#strake"><span title="See entry on this page at § strake" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">strake</span></a> fastened above the level of the <span title="See entry on this page at § gunwale" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gunwale" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gunwale</a></span> of an open boat to increase the <span title="See entry on this page at § freeboard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#freeboard" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">freeboard</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAdmiralty_manual_of_seamanship1972214_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAdmiralty_manual_of_seamanship1972214-95">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="watch" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Watch_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Watch system">watch</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A period of time during which a part of the <span title="See entry on this page at § crew" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#crew" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">crew</a></span> is on duty. Changes of watch are marked by strokes on the <a href="#ship&#39;s_bell"><span title="See entry on this page at § ship&#39;s bell" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ship's bell</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="watchstanding" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Watchstanding" class="mw-redirect" title="Watchstanding">watchstanding</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>watchkeeping</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The allocation of crew or staff to specific roles on a ship in order to operate it continuously. These assignments, known as <a href="#watch"><span title="See entry on this page at § watch" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">watches</span></a>, are divided into regularly scheduled work periods of several hours or longer to ensure that some portion of the crew is always occupying the roles at all times. Those members of the crew who are on watch at a given time are called <i>watchkeepers</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="watertender" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">watertender</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><span title="See entry on this page at § fireman" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#fireman" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">fireman</a></span></i> (definition 1).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="water_bus" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Water_bus" class="mw-redirect" title="Water bus">water bus</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A watercraft used to provide transportation on a scheduled service with multiple stops, usually in an urban environment, analogous to the way a bus operates on land. It differs from a <a href="#water_taxi"><span title="See entry on this page at § water taxi" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">water taxi</span></a>, which is a similar watercraft that provides transport service to various locations on demand rather than on a predetermined schedule, analogous to the way a <a href="/wiki/Taxicab" class="mw-redirect" title="Taxicab">taxicab</a> operates on land, although in North America these terms are often used interchangeably. A water bus also differs from a <span title="See entry on this page at § ferry" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#ferry" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">ferry</a></span>, which usually refers to a watercraft that shuttles between only two points.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="water_kite" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">water kite</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">See <i><a href="#paravane"><span title="See entry on this page at § paravane" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">paravane</span></a></i> (definition 2).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="water_taxi" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Water_taxi" title="Water taxi">water taxi</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A watercraft used to provide transportation on demand to various locations, usually in an urban environment, analogous to the way a <a href="/wiki/Taxicab" class="mw-redirect" title="Taxicab">taxicab</a> operates on land. It differs from a <a href="#water_bus"><span title="See entry on this page at § water bus" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">water bus</span></a>, which is a similar watercraft that provides transportation on a scheduled service with multiple stops rather than at the rider's will, analogous to the way a bus operates on land, although in North America these terms are often used interchangeably. A water taxi also differs from a <span title="See entry on this page at § ferry" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#ferry" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">ferry</a></span>, which usually refers to a watercraft that shuttles between only two points.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="watercraft" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Watercraft" title="Watercraft">watercraft</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Any vessel intended for transportation on water, e.g. <a href="#ship"><span title="See entry on this page at § ship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ships</span></a>, <span title="See entry on this page at § boat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#boat" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">boats</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Personal_watercraft" title="Personal watercraft">personal watercraft</a>, etc.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="waterline" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Waterline" title="Waterline">waterline</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The line where the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> of a ship meets the water<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s surface.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="watersail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Watersail" title="Watersail">watersail</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#sail"><span title="See entry on this page at § sail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sail</span></a> hung below the <span title="See entry on this page at § boom" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#boom" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">boom</a></span> on <span title="See entry on this page at § gaff rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gaff_rig" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gaff rig</a></span> boats for extra downwind performance when racing.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115_72-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="waterway" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Waterway" title="Waterway">waterway</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Any navigable body of water.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A <a href="#strake"><span title="See entry on this page at § strake" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">strake</span></a> of timber laid against the <span title="See entry on this page at § frame" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#frame" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">frames</a></span> or <span title="See entry on this page at § bulwark" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bulwark" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bulwark</a></span> <a href="#stanchion"><span title="See entry on this page at § stanchion" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stanchions</span></a> at the margin of a laid wooden <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span>, usually about twice the thickness of the deck planking.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="way" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">way</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Speed, progress, or momentum, or more technically, the point at which there is sufficient water flow past a vessel's <a href="#rudder"><span title="See entry on this page at § rudder" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rudder</span></a> for it to be able to steer the vessel (i.e. when the rudder begins to "bite", sometimes also called "steerage way".) To "make way" is to move; to "have way on" or "to have steerage way" is to have enough speed to control the vessel with its rudder; to "lose way" is to slow down or to not have enough speed to use the rudder effectively. "Way enough" is a <span title="See entry on this page at § coxswain" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#coxswain" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">coxswain</a></span>'s command that the oarsmen stop rowing and allow the boat to proceed by its existing momentum.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="way-landing" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">way-landing</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An intermediate stop along the route of a <a href="#steamboat"><span title="See entry on this page at § steamboat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">steamboat</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="way-lay" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">way-lay</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The verb's origin, from <i>wegelage</i>, means  "lying in wait, with evil or hostile intent". So to be <i>waylaid</i> refers to a ship that has been taken off its course, route, or <a href="#way"><span title="See entry on this page at § way" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">way</span></a> by surprise, typically by unfortunate or nefarious means. In <a href="/wiki/Herman_Melville" title="Herman Melville">Herman Melville</a>'s 1851 novel <i><a href="/wiki/Moby-Dick" title="Moby-Dick">Moby-Dick</a></i>, the great white whale waylaid the <i>Pequod</i> and sank it with only a few souls surviving in lifeboats.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="waypoint" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Waypoint" title="Waypoint">waypoint</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A location defined by navigational coordinates, especially as part of a planned route.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="ways" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">ways</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The timbers of <a href="#shipyard"><span title="See entry on this page at § shipyard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">shipyard</span></a> stocks that slope into the water and along which a ship or large boat is <span title="See entry on this page at § launch" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#launch" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">launched</a></span>. A ship undergoing construction in a shipyard is said to be <i>on the ways</i>, while a ship scrapped there is said to be <i>broken up in the ways</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wearing_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Jibe_(sailing)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jibe (sailing)">wearing ship</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary"><a href="#tacking"><span title="See entry on this page at § tacking" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">Tacking</span></a> away from the wind in a <a href="#square_rig"><span title="See entry on this page at § square rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square-rigged</span></a> vessel. See also <i><span title="See entry on this page at § gybe" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gybe" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gybe</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="weather_deck" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">weather deck</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">deck</a></span> that is continually exposed to the weather – usually either the <a href="#main_deck"><span title="See entry on this page at § main deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">main deck</span></a> or, in larger vessels, the upper deck.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="weather_gage" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Weather_gage" title="Weather gage">weather gage</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="weather_gauge"></span><span class="anchor" id="weather-beam"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>weather gauge</b> or <b>weather-beam</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">Favorable position over another sailing vessel with respect to the wind.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="weather_helm" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Weather_helm" title="Weather helm">weather helm</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The tendency of a sailboat to turn to <a href="#windward"><span title="See entry on this page at § windward" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">windward</span></a> in a strong wind when there is no change in the <a href="#rudder"><span title="See entry on this page at § rudder" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rudder</span></a>'s position. This is the opposite of <span title="See entry on this page at § lee helm" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lee_helm" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lee helm</a></span> and is the result of a dynamically unbalanced condition. See also <i><span title="See entry on this page at § center of lateral resistance" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#center_of_lateral_resistance" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">center of lateral resistance</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="weather_ship" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Weather_ship" title="Weather ship">weather ship</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A ship stationed in the ocean as a platform from which to record surface and upper-air meteorological observations for use in weather forecasting.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="weather_side" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">weather side</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>windward side</b> or simply <b><a href="#windward"><span title="See entry on this page at § windward" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">windward</span></a></b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The side of a ship exposed to the wind, i.e. the side facing upwind or the direction from which the wind is blowing. Contrast <i><span title="See entry on this page at § lee side" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lee_side" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lee side</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="weatherly" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">weatherly</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A ship that is easily sailed and maneuvered, or which makes little <span title="See entry on this page at § leeway" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#leeway" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">leeway</a></span> when sailing to <a href="#windward"><span title="See entry on this page at § windward" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">windward</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="weigh_anchor" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">weigh anchor</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To heave up an <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor</a></span> preparatory to sailing.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="well" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">well</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A place in the ship's <span title="See entry on this page at § hold" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hold" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hold</a></span> for pumps.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="well-found" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">well-found</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Properly set up or provisioned.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="west_indiaman" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/West_Indiaman" title="West Indiaman">West Indiaman</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A British term used in the 18th and 19th centuries for any merchant sailing ship making voyages between the <a href="/wiki/Old_World" title="Old World">Old World</a> and the <a href="/wiki/West_Indies" title="West Indies">West Indies</a> or the east coast of the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>, in contrast to an <span title="See entry on this page at § East Indiaman" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#East_Indiaman" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">East Indiaman</a></span>, which made voyages to the East Indies or South Asia. The term most frequently was applied to British, Danish, Dutch, and French ships.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wet" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">wet</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">(of a ship) Prone to taking water over her <span title="See entry on this page at § deck" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#deck" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">decks</a></span> at sea. For example, a ship that tends to take water over her <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> can be said to be "wet forward."</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wetted_area" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Wetted_area" title="Wetted area">wetted area</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">In sailboating, the portion of the <span title="See entry on this page at § hull" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#hull" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">hull</a></span> immersed in water (i.e. below the <a href="#waterline"><span title="See entry on this page at § waterline" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">waterline</span></a>).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="whaleback" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Whaleback" title="Whaleback">whaleback</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A type of cargo steamship of unusual design formerly used on the <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a> of North America, notably for carrying grain or ore. The hull continuously curved above the <a href="#waterline"><span title="See entry on this page at § waterline" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">waterline</span></a> from vertical to horizontal, and when the ship was fully loaded, only the rounded portion of her hull (the "whaleback" proper) was visible above the waterline. With sides curved in towards the ends, whalebacks had a <a href="#spoon_bow"><span title="See entry on this page at § spoon bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">spoon-shaped bow</span></a> and a very convex upper deck.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A type of high-speed <span title="See entry on this page at § launch" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#launch" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">launch</a></span> first designed for the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Air_Force" title="Royal Air Force">Royal Air Force</a> during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, or certain smaller rescue and research vessels most common in Europe that, like the Great Lakes vessels, have hulls that curve over to meet the deck, although the "whaleback" designation comes not from the curve along the <span title="See entry on this page at § gunwale" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#gunwale" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">gunwale</a></span> as in the Great Lakes vessels, but from the fore-and-aft arch in the deck.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;A sheltered portion of the forward deck on certain British fishing boats designed, in part, so that water taken over the <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> is more easily shed over the sides. The feature has been incorporated into some pleasure craft – aboard which it is known as a <i>whaleback deck</i> – based on the hull design of older whaling boats.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="whaleboat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Whaleboat" title="Whaleboat">whaleboat</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A type of open boat that is relatively narrow and pointed at both ends, enabling it to move either forwards or backwards equally well.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;On modern warships, a relatively light and seaworthy boat used for transport of the ship<span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span>s crew.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;A type of vessel designed as a <span title="See entry on this page at § lifeboat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lifeboat" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lifeboat</a></span> or "monomoy" used for recreational and competitive rowing in the San Francisco Bay area and coastal Massachusetts.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">4.&#160;&#160;Informally, any <a href="#whaler"><span title="See entry on this page at § whaler" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">whaling ship</span></a> of any size.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">5.&#160;&#160;Informally, any vessel engaged in <a href="/wiki/Whale_watching" title="Whale watching">whale watching</a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="whaler" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Whaler" title="Whaler">whaler</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;Also <b>whaling ship</b>. A specialized vessel designed for catching or processing <a href="/wiki/Whale" title="Whale">whales</a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A person engaged in the catching or processing of whales.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;In the Royal Navy, a <a href="/wiki/Montagu_whaler" title="Montagu whaler">Montagu whaler</a>, a <a href="#ship&#39;s_boat"><span title="See entry on this page at § ship&#39;s boat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ship's boat</span></a> often used as a <a href="#seaboat"><span title="See entry on this page at § seaboat" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">seaboat</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wharf" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Wharf" title="Wharf">wharf</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A structure on the shore of a harbor or on the bank of a river or canal where ships may dock to load and unload cargo or passengers. Such a structure includes one or more <span title="See entry on this page at § berth" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#berth" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">berths</a></span> (i.e. mooring locations), and may also include <a href="#pier"><span title="See entry on this page at § pier" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">piers</span></a>, <a href="/wiki/Warehouse" title="Warehouse">warehouses</a>, or other facilities necessary for handling the ships. The term "wharf" is generally synonymous with <a href="#quay"><span title="See entry on this page at § quay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">quay</span></a>, although the solid foundations of a quay contrast with the closely spaced piles of a wharf. When "quay" and "wharf" are used as synonyms, the term "quay" is more common in everyday speech in the United Kingdom, many <a href="/wiki/British_Commonwealth" class="mw-redirect" title="British Commonwealth">Commonwealth</a> countries, and the Republic of Ireland, while "wharf" is more commonly used in the United States.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wharfage" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">wharfage</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A collective term for <span title="See entry on this page at § dock" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#dock" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">docks</a></span>, <a href="#pier"><span title="See entry on this page at § pier" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">piers</span></a>, <a href="#quay"><span title="See entry on this page at § quay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">quays</span></a>, and <a href="#wharf"><span title="See entry on this page at § wharf" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">wharfs</span></a>.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A collective term for all wharfs in a given port, area, country, region, etc.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;A fee charged for the use of a wharf.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wheel" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Steering_wheel_(ship)" class="mw-redirect" title="Steering wheel (ship)">wheel</a></dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="ship&#39;s_wheel"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>ship's wheel</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The usual steering device on larger vessels: a wheel with a horizontal axis, connected by cables to the <a href="#rudder"><span title="See entry on this page at § rudder" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rudder</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wheelhouse" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">wheelhouse</dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>pilothouse</b> and often synonymous with <b><span title="See entry on this page at § bridge" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bridge" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bridge</a></span></b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">The location on a ship where the <a href="#wheel"><span title="See entry on this page at § wheel" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">wheel</span></a> is located.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="whelkie" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">whelkie</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A small sailing <a href="#pram"><span title="See entry on this page at § pram" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">pram</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wherry" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Wherry" title="Wherry">wherry</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of boat traditionally used for carrying cargo or passengers on rivers and canals in England, particularly on the River Thames and the Norfolk and Suffolk Broads.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="whiff" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">whiff</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A chiefly British term for a narrow <span title="See entry on this page at § clinker-built" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#clinker-built" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">clinker-built</a></span> <a href="#skiff"><span title="See entry on this page at § skiff" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">skiff</span></a> having <a href="#outrigger"><span title="See entry on this page at § outrigger" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">outriggers</span></a> and designed for one oarsman.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="whip" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">whip</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A small single <span title="See entry on this page at § block" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#block" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">block</a></span> <a href="#tackle"><span title="See entry on this page at § tackle" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tackle</span></a>, used to raise light loads from a hold.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199037_94-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199037-94">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="whip_upon_whip" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">whip upon whip</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Connecting two <a href="#whip"><span title="See entry on this page at § whip" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">whips</span></a> together. This runs more smoothly than using a double block with single block tackle, which would have the equivalent purchase. Can be used for <a href="#topsail"><span title="See entry on this page at § topsail" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">topsail</span></a> and <a href="#top-gallant"><span title="See entry on this page at § top-gallant" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">top-gallant</span></a> <span title="See entry on this page at § halyard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#halyard" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">halliards</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199037_94-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199037-94">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="whipping" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">whipping</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The binding with twine of the loose end of a <a href="#rope"><span title="See entry on this page at § rope" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">rope</span></a> to prevent it unravelling.<sup id="cite_ref-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary_2-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thames_Sailing_Barge_glossary-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="whipstaff" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Whipstaff" title="Whipstaff">whipstaff</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vertical lever connected to a <a href="#tiller"><span title="See entry on this page at § tiller" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tiller</span></a>, used for steering on larger ships before the development of the <a href="#wheel"><span title="See entry on this page at § wheel" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">ship's wheel</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="whiskers" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">whiskers</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Spreaders from the <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> to spread the <span title="See entry on this page at § bowsprit" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bowsprit" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bowsprit</a></span> <a href="#shroud"><span title="See entry on this page at § shroud" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">shrouds</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="whiskerstay" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">whiskerstay</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">One of the pair of <a href="#stay"><span title="See entry on this page at § stay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stays</span></a> that stabilize the <span title="See entry on this page at § bowsprit" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bowsprit" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bowsprit</a></span>, horizontally affixed to the forward end of the bowsprit and just aft the <a href="#stem"><span title="See entry on this page at § stem" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stem</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="white_horses" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">white horses</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="whitecaps"></span>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Also <b>whitecaps</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">Foam or spray on wave tops caused by stronger winds (usually above <a href="/wiki/Beaufort_scale" title="Beaufort scale">Force</a> 4).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="white_ensign" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/White_Ensign" title="White Ensign">White Ensign</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A British flag flown as an <span title="See entry on this page at § ensign" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#ensign" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">ensign</a></span> by certain British ships. Prior to 1864, ships of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a>′s White Squadron flew it; since the reorganisation of the Royal Navy in 1864, it has been flown by all Royal Navy ships and <a href="/wiki/Shore_establishment" class="mw-redirect" title="Shore establishment">shore establishments</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yacht" title="Yacht">yachts</a> of members of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Yacht_Squadron" title="Royal Yacht Squadron">Royal Yacht Squadron</a>, and ships of <a href="/wiki/Trinity_House" title="Trinity House">Trinity House</a> escorting the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">reigning monarch</a> of the United Kingdom.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wide_berth" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">wide berth</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">To leave room between two ships moored (berthed) in order to allow space for manoeuvring.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="williamson_turn" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Williamson_turn" class="mw-redirect" title="Williamson turn">Williamson turn</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A type of <a href="/wiki/Man_overboard_rescue_turn" title="Man overboard rescue turn">man overboard rescue turn</a>. Other variations include the Anderson turn, the quick turn, and the Scharnow turn.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="winch" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Winch" title="Winch">winch</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A mechanical device for pulling on a rope (such as a <a href="#sheet"><span title="See entry on this page at § sheet" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">sheet</span></a> or <span title="See entry on this page at § halyard" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#halyard" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">halyard</a></span>), usually equipped with a <a href="#pawl"><span title="See entry on this page at § pawl" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">pawl</span></a> to assist in control. It may be hand-operated or powered.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wind-over-tide" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">wind-over-tide</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Sea conditions in which a tidal current and a wind are moving in opposite directions, leading to short, heavy seas.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="windage" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Windage" title="Windage">windage</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The wind resistance of a boat.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="windbound" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">windbound</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A condition wherein a ship is detained in one particular station by contrary winds.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="winding_tackle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">winding tackle</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#tackle"><span title="See entry on this page at § tackle" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">tackle</span></a> formed of two triple <span title="See entry on this page at § block" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#block" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">blocks</a></span> or a triple and a double, used to raise heavy loads such as guns and anchors.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199037_94-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199037-94">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="windjammer" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Iron-hulled_sailing_ship" title="Iron-hulled sailing ship">windjammer</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A large iron- or steel-hulled <a href="#square_rig"><span title="See entry on this page at § square rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square-rigged</span></a> sailing ship of the late 19th and early 20th centuries with three, four, or five <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">masts</span></a>, built mainly between the 1870s and 1900 to carry cargo on long voyages.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="windlass" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Windlass" title="Windlass">windlass</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A <a href="#winch"><span title="See entry on this page at § winch" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">winch</span></a> mechanism, usually with a horizontal axis, designed to move very heavy loads. Used where mechanical advantage greater than that obtainable by <span title="See entry on this page at § block and tackle" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#block_and_tackle" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">block and tackle</a></span> was needed (such as raising the <span title="See entry on this page at § anchor" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#anchor" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">anchor</a></span> on small ships).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199037_94-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199037-94">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="windsail" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">windsail</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A wide tube or funnel of canvas used to convey a stream of air into the lower compartments of a ship for ventilation.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="windward" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Windward_and_leeward" title="Windward and leeward">windward</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">In the direction that the wind is coming from. Contrast <i><span title="See entry on this page at § leeward" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#leeward" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">leeward</a></span></i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wing" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">wing</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">An extension on the side of a vessel, e.g. a <i>bridge wing</i> is an extension of the <span title="See entry on this page at § bridge" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bridge" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bridge</a></span> to both sides, intended to allow bridge personnel a full view to aid in the manoeuvring of the ship.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="wiper" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Wiper_(occupation)" title="Wiper (occupation)">wiper</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The most junior rate among personnel who work in the engine room of a ship, responsible for cleaning the engine spaces and machinery and assisting the engineers as directed. A wiper is often serving an apprenticeship to become an <a href="#oiler"><span title="See entry on this page at § oiler" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">oiler</span></a>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="working_up" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">working up</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Training on a warship to achieve the best possible effectiveness, usually after commissioniong or a refit.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975293_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer1975293-97">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="worm,_parcel_and_serve" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Worm,_parcel_and_serve" title="Worm, parcel and serve">worm, parcel and serve</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Often collectively called <b>service</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">To apply a multilayered protection against chafing and deterioration to a section of <span title="See entry on this page at § line" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#line" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">line</a></span> by laying <a href="#yarn"><span title="See entry on this page at § yarn" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">yarns</span></a> to fill in the <span title="See entry on this page at § cuntline" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cuntline" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cuntlines</a></span> (<i>worming</i>), wrapping marline or other small <a href="#stuff"><span title="See entry on this page at § stuff" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stuff</span></a> around it (<i>serving</i>), and stitching a covering of canvas over all (<i>parcelling</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199038_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199038-98">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> It can be applied to the entire length of a line, such as a <a href="#shroud"><span title="See entry on this page at § shroud" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">shroud</span></a>, or selectively to specific parts of a line, such as over the spliced ends of a <a href="#stay"><span title="See entry on this page at § stay" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stay</span></a>, where the chafe on the middle section of the stay precludes complete protection.</dd>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:USCGC_Eagle_cable_preservation_sample2.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/USCGC_Eagle_cable_preservation_sample2.JPG/220px-USCGC_Eagle_cable_preservation_sample2.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="99" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/USCGC_Eagle_cable_preservation_sample2.JPG/330px-USCGC_Eagle_cable_preservation_sample2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/USCGC_Eagle_cable_preservation_sample2.JPG/440px-USCGC_Eagle_cable_preservation_sample2.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2359" data-file-height="1065" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:USCGC_Eagle_cable_preservation_sample2.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Example of the preservation of a <span title="See entry on this page at § cable" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#cable" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">cable</a></span>, showing different sections serviced by various techniques, including <b><a href="#worm,_parcel_and_serve"><span title="See entry on this page at § worm, parcel and serve" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">worming, parcelling and serving</span></a></b></div></div></div>
<dt class="glossary" id="wrecking_tug" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">wrecking tug</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Another name for a <a href="#salvage_tug"><span title="See entry on this page at § salvage tug" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">salvage tug</span></a>.</dd>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1098327943"/>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="X">X</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: X">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<dt class="glossary" id="xebec" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Xebec" title="Xebec">xebec</a></dfn></dt>
<p class="glossary-hatnote"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"/><span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref">Variously spelled <b>zebec</b>, <b>xebeck</b>, <b>xebeque</b>, <b>xebecque</b>, <b>zebeck</b>, <b>zebecque</b>, <b>chebec</b>, or <b>shebeck</b>.</span></p>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A Mediterranean sailing ship, usually employed for trading, that is propelled by a combination of <span title="See entry on this page at § lateen rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#lateen_rig" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">lateen sails</a></span> and oars and characterized by a distinctive hull with a pronounced overhanging <span title="See entry on this page at § bow" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#bow" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">bow</a></span> and <a href="#stern"><span title="See entry on this page at § stern" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">stern</span></a>; early xebecs had two <a href="#mast"><span title="See entry on this page at § mast" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">masts</span></a> and later ones had three.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;A small, fast <a href="#warship"><span title="See entry on this page at § warship" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">warship</span></a> of the 16th to 19th centuries similar in design to a trading xebec and used almost exclusively in the Mediterranean Sea. This kind of xebec was slightly smaller than a contemporary <span title="See entry on this page at § frigate" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#frigate" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">frigate</a></span> and mounted slightly fewer guns.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="xebec-frigate" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">xebec-frigate</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A European warship that appeared late in the history of the <a href="#xebec"><span title="See entry on this page at § xebec" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">xebec</span></a>. It was fully <a href="#square_rig"><span title="See entry on this page at § square rig" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id="">square-rigged</span></a> but otherwise designed like a xebec.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="x.o._(or_xo)" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">X.O. (or XO)</dfn></dt><span class="anchor" id="XO"></span>
<dd class="glossary">An abbreviation for <span title="See entry on this page at § executive officer" class="glossary-link-internal" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed #86a1ff; color:initial;" id=""><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(A-L)#executive_officer" title="Glossary of nautical terms (A-L)">executive officer</a></span>.</dd>


<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1098327943"/>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Y">Y</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Y">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<dt class="glossary" id="yacht" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Yacht" title="Yacht">yacht</a></dfn></dt><dd class="glossary">A recreational boat or ship; the term includes <i>sailing yachts</i>, <i>motor yachts</i>, and <i>steam yachts</i>.</dd>
<dt class="glossary" id="yard" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">yard</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;<a href="/wiki/Yard_(sailing)" title="Yard (sailing)">Yard</a>: The horizontal spar from which a square sail is suspended.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199038_98-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199038-98">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;The spar on which a <a href="/wiki/Lug_sail" title="Lug sail">lugsail</a> or <a href="/wiki/Gunter_rig" title="Gunter rig">Gunter sail</a> is set.<sup id="cite_ref-Leather_1979_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Leather_1979-99">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup></dd>
<dd class="glossary">3.&#160;&#160;A <a href="/wiki/Dockyard" class="mw-redirect" title="Dockyard">dockyard</a> or <a href="/wiki/Shipyard" title="Shipyard">shipyard</a>.</dd>

<span class="anchor" id="Yard_number"></span><dt class="glossary" id="yard_number" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">yard number</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Each <a href="/wiki/Shipyard" title="Shipyard">shipyard</a> typically numbers the ships that it has built in consecutive order. One use is to identify the ship before a name has been chosen.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="yard_tackle" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">yard tackle</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Tackle to raise boats<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199038_98-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiddlecombe199038-98">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="yardarm" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Yard_(sailing)" title="Yard (sailing)">yardarm</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">The very end of a yard. Often mistaken for a <i>yard</i>, which refers to the entire spar. As in to hang "from the yardarm" and the sun being "over the yardarm" (late enough to have a drink).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115_72-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnderhill1955115-72">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="yar" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">yar</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary"><i>Of a vessel, especially of a sailing vessel</i>: Quick, agile, and easy to steer, <i>hand</i> (<i>q.v.</i>), and <i>reef</i> (<i>q.v.</i>).</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="yarr" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">yarr</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">Acknowledgement of an order, or agreement. Also <i>aye, aye</i>.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="yaw" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Ship_motions" title="Ship motions">yaw</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A vessel's rotational motion about the vertical axis, causing the fore and aft ends to swing from side to side repetitively.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="yawl" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Yawl" title="Yawl">yawl</a></dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">1.&#160;&#160;A fore-and-aft rigged sailing vessel with two masts, main and mizzen, the mizzen stepped abaft the rudder post.</dd>
<dd class="glossary">2.&#160;&#160;An un-decked boat, often beach-launched, worked under both oar and sail. Generally clinker built. Used for fishing, serving ships in anchorages, salvage work, etc. Those from the northern parts of Britain tended to be double ended.<sup id="cite_ref-McKee_1983_21-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McKee_1983-21">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 74">&#58;&#8202;74&#8202;</span></sup></dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="yawl_boat" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">yawl boat</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A rowboat on davits at the stern of the boat.</dd>

<dt class="glossary" id="yeoman" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary">yeoman</dfn></dt>
<dd class="glossary">A US Navy enlisted rating (YN) responsible for administrative duties.</dd>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1098327943"/>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Z">Z</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glossary_of_nautical_terms_(M-Z)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Z">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<dt class="glossary" id="zebec" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Xebec" title="Xebec">zebec</a></dfn></dt><dd class="glossary">An alternative spelling of <i>xebec</i> (<i>q.v.</i>).</dd>
<dt class="glossary" id="zulu" style="margin-top: 0.4em;"><dfn class="glossary"><a href="/wiki/Zulu_(fishing_boat)" class="mw-redirect" title="Zulu (fishing boat)">zulu</a></dfn></dt><dd class="glossary">A type of Scottish sailboat introduced in 1879, used for fishing. A zulu is <a href="/wiki/Carvel_(boat_building)" title="Carvel (boat building)">carvel</a>-built (<i>q.v.</i>), with the vertical stem of a <a href="/wiki/Fifie" title="Fifie">fifie</a> (<i>q.v.</i>) and the steeply raked stern of a <a href="/wiki/Skaffie" class="mw-redirect" title="Skaffie">skaffie</a> (<i>q.v.</i>); two masts rigged with three sails (fore, mizzen, and jib); and a longer deck and shorter keel than previous Scottish fishing boats, allowing greater maneuverability. The term "zulu" came from the <a href="/wiki/Zulu_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Zulu War">Zulu War</a>, which the United Kingdom fought in 1879 at the time the zulu was introduced.</dd>
